CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 24, 2018
CommentsContent: There must be many thousands of digital versions of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. I got this because I wanted to compare it with another that I had, and didn't realize until it was on my kindle that the name of the author on the cover page is  incorrect!! The author is NOT Charlotte Bronte!!!!! This is so inexplicable and appalling a mistake, I had to write and mention it so that it can (hopefully) be corrected. The rest of the text is fine. I don't want it on my kindle, and have deleted it. How anyone could have confused Jane Austen and Charlotte Bronte (author of Jane Eyre) is beyond me.

CommentsTitle: "Pride and Prejudice" is one of the best sociological studies about early nineteen century British loyalty and ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 13, 2018
CommentsContent: After reading the first few chapters (The chapters are very short) of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" I wondered how anyone could be interested in such pompous, egotistical, aloof and self serving characters?After reading on I said, "Wow! How could I be so interested in such characters?"Getting toward the middle of the book, I was hoping that it would never end.By the end of the book, I fully realized what a magnificent piece of writing I had just read."Pride and Prejudice" is one of the best sociological studies about early nineteen century British loyalty and society I have ever read - where title, rank, fortune, and good looks are in many ways the requirements of an approved marriage, much, much more than love. In fact, this wonderful book might not be as relevant today as two hundred years ago, but there are still many traces of such societies throughout the world, today. It was not all that long ago in America, where marrying outside of your religion, or ethnicity, was looked down upon.The book is full of wonderful characters, but Elizabeth (Lizzy) Bennet is, in my opinion, the star. Her character is so wonderfully and fully realized that at times I felt her jumping off the page and directly into my life.Liza, a fellow member and friend on Goodreads, informed me that she had read the book twice and still was not sure if the ending was 'sad' or 'funny.' To me, it was funny and exceptionally rewarding but sad to think that a lady's livelihood depended more on the wealth and rank of your partner than love.Quite an amazing book.

CommentsTitle: Apparently Google translated into Swahili and back again
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 14, 2019
CommentsContent: Ssomeone apparently decided that Pride and Prejudice needed "updating" into gibberish (see screen shot). A few representative sentences: "Her mind changed into much less tough to expand." "It is extra than I have interaction for, I guarantee you." "Why, my pricey, you should understand, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken by using a young guy of huge fortune from the north of England." There are many sentences just like this on every page. It's amusing for a short while, and then it's not.

CommentsTitle: "Pride and Prejudice" by Jane Austen started off annoying me and ended up enchanting me
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 5, 2016
CommentsContent: "Pride and Prejudice" by Jane Austen started off annoying me and ended up enchanting me. Up until about page one hundred I found this book vexing, frivolous and down right tedious. I now count myself as a convert to the Austen cult.I must confess I have been known to express an antipathy for anything written or set before 1900. I just cannot get down with corsets, outdoor plumbing and buggy rides. Whenever someone dips a quill into an inkwell my eyes glaze over. This is a shortcoming I readily own up to but have no desire to correct. So I admit to not starting this book with the highest of hopes. I did really enjoy Ang Lee's "Sense and Sensibility" however and so when my friend threw the gauntlet down I dutifully picked it up.Boy did I hate him at first. To get anywhere with this book one has to immerse oneself in the realities of life and marriage in the nineteenth century. At first all this talk of entailment and manners just left me cold. I liked the language to be sure. Austen's dialogue is delightful through out but dialogue alone (no matter how delicious) does not a great novel make.A hundred pages or so in though I started to see what a shrewd eye for character this Austen woman had. Mr. Collins was the first person I marvelled at. His character springs forth fully formed as a total but somehow loveable ass. From that point on I found much to love about this book. I was so into it by the end that I was laughing at some characters, sympathizing with others and clucking my tongue at an unhappy few. In short I was completely absorbed.In conclusion I must now count myself a fan of Miss Austen's novels (and not just their fim adaptations) and do so look forward to acqauinting myself with more of her work in the future. "Emma" anyone?

CommentsTitle: For those that want the Peacock Edition Paperback...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 29, 2020
CommentsContent: I love Pride and Prejudice. This review is not about the novel, but this specific edition. There was a beautiful, illustrated version of Pride and Prejudice published in 1894. This paperback is a poor replication of it. In all I paid about $20 for this copy. There were less than 300 copies printed of the original and can be found online for thousands of dollars. That is a pretty big financial commitment, so I started looking into replicas. I discovered this one and figured it was a nice way to dip my toes into this illustrated version. Overall, it is an okay copy. Some of the images are very pixelated, as shown in the photo. I have a screenshot of a scanned version of the original compared to what I received. The images in this paperback have far less detail than the original. There is a huge range in the quality of the images. However, this copy satisfies me enough and fulfills my wish of having this version. I wish more care was taken into the design of the front and back covers. The outside could have been truly beautiful instead of looking like a cheap knockoff.There is another publisher that does a hardcover copy of this 1894 edition that looks stunning. That one is priced at like $300 so I might upgrade to that in the future as a treat. I desperately want to get more copies of this book that are stunning. If you can afford it from the get go, I would probably go with that. If you cannot and are desperate for the peacock edition like I was, stick with this for now.

CommentsTitle: A time capsule for an era
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 10, 2020
CommentsContent: I'll admit, the thing that made this novel easier for me to figure out was that I'd watched Pride and Prejudice (2005) starring Keira Knightley. I'd put off reading the actual Jane Austen novel for most of my life. This is not my usual fare, at all, but because a good friend of mine, Helen Moffett, is seeing the release of her P&P sequel Charlotte, I figured I'd better get reading so that I could have the background.Historical fiction written during contemporary times is one thing, but actual fiction from more than hundred years ago is quite another. Austen writes for an audience that would take conventions in clothing and the environment for granted, focusing instead of dialogue and mannerisms. So we're left with a kind of shallow, limited third person that doesn't feed readers who're used to a deeper point of view. So it helps immensely for folks like me, who honestly don't have a clue, to have watched that film. It gave me useful context. Don't be ashamed to watch the film before reading the novel.I believe it does the book a disservice to evaluate it using contemporary standards. Authors these days have a deep well of literary conventions to draw from, so applying those to Austen will rob the book of much of its character. For me, P&P exists as a time capsule, offering a glimpse into particular cultural and social mores prevalent within English society at the time. We step into a world where characters are trapped by their status within society, and while it can be argued that many of Austen's characters are shallow (um, hello, Mr Collins much), I feel that Austen is taking stabs at society. And it makes me also realise how much society has changed, and what we, as women, take for granted in terms of our liberties and empowerment in contemporary times.While I didn't gain the same sort of enjoyment from Pride and Prejudice as I would from the usual titles I'll slide onto my Kindle, I nonetheless walked away from this novel feeling as if I'd gained a better understanding as to why Regency-era stories have carved themselves such a beloved niche among readers. It's easy to loathe some of the characters, and at a glance, people like Mrs Bennett seem facile and annoying, but if you dig a little deeper, the social commentary becomes crystal clear. Sure, Mrs Bennett's obsession with marrying off her daughters seems exhausting, but if you understand her very real fears that she would not be able to care for them if they never got married – for there were no prospects for a woman in those days to have a career – then it's possible to be more sympathetic towards her. Despite each character having perceived privileges, they themselves are trapped by their social standing. And don't get me started on Mr Collins, and especially his appalling commentary when one of Elizabeth's sisters elopes.It took me some time to get used to Austen's style, and now that I'm done with the novel, I also realise it's a story that begs being reread at some point. The beauty of the telling lies in what the characters have to say to each other, and how they respond to circumstances, and I feel on the first read through there were many subtleties that I may have missed.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 14, 2017
CommentsContent: The print quality of this book was disappointing.  The headers and footers were cut much too fine with the print almost on the edges of the paper but worse was the breaks in the printed lines where a sentence would beak part of the way across the page leaving a large blank space before continuing on the line below.  All the text was there but it made for very disjointed reading spoiling the pleasure of reading this old classic.  This was a regular occurrence throughout the book.The whole point of large print books is to make reading easier for the sight impaired, this book although large print because of the poor layout and lack of attention too detail did not make for the pleasant reading experience I had looked forward too.  The story is as good as ever but this book as printed is very poor.  I've probably been generous to give it four stars and only did so because it is hard to find large print books.

CommentsTitle: Never seen a font so small in a book
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 4, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought "Pride and Prejudice" from them and when the book arrived it was the size of a magazine. I've never seen such a small font in a book.  It was like trying to read the back of a medicine bottle.  Then I bought "Animal Farm" from them and didn't start reading it until the return window had passed.  I get to page 116 and find I'm missing 32 pages ... next page after 116 was 133.  So now what?  It was only $9 but sheesh. I won't be buying any more books from theses people.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 12, 2019
CommentsContent: This is a lovely collection, and I made sure to grab it early because at 10,000 copies each I knew they would sell out. I appreciate that they came with a plastic jacket to protect the book, but it is very cheap cellophane and is not meant to be kept on the books. The die cuts are EXTREMELY delicate and you have to be careful when pulling them off of the shelf when they are next to each other. One die cut can grab another on a second book and rip. I wish that they had come with better quality covers, I'm definitely going to need to cover them myself. In addition, there were slight brown marks on my books, and much more browning on the inside of the dust jackets, where it appears that the die cutting machine got too hot and actually burned the paper. I've contacted several other book collector friends who confirmed that their set was the same. But for the price, they are a decent collection. I hope that when the future seasons books come out that they will address these issues.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 31, 2016
CommentsContent: A favorite that is listened to year after year!  I was first introduced in an English Lit class in high school and I have read and reread this beautiful story at a rate of once or twice a year since.The characters are so well drawn, the follies so well orchestrated and the times captured in so much detail it almost takes your breath away.  The writing is truly beautiful and flows over the reader like the softest piece of silk.  The sentences are intricately constructed yet easily comprehensible and the meaning is not lost even though a single sentence might cover a third of a page.  Jane Austen's mastery of the English language is more remarkable today in this age of acronyms and sentence fragments than it was in her own time, I am sure.The story itself is incredibly detailed and the characters are drawn in a depth that is not commonly seen today.  Eliza Bennett understands herself incredibly well and is able to recognize when she has made a mistake and rectify it in a gracious way that does not occur today.  She is also able to repel unkind inquiries and remarks just as graciously.  What she is not so easily able to do is forgive the chance hearing of an unkind remark said in a moment of pride.  Hearing an unkind description of her appearance that is said by Mr. Darcy at a dance, she takes an instant dislike to him and from then on proceeds to be as unkind to him as her generous nature will allow.  Mr. Darcy, however, after uttering these fateful words that he does not know were overheard, begins to have an attraction to Elizabeth that he fights for months afterwards.  When he finally surrenders to his strong feelings for her, Eliza rejects him so utterly that he is shocked beyond recognition.  He sets about trying to rectify her perceptions of him and is making a sound beginning when the unthinkable occurs.  Can he overcome his pride?  Can she overcome her prejudice?Listening to an excellent narration of this classic was almost as fun as understanding the story with the help of Mrs. Martindale, my saintly English Lit teacher, all those years ago.  Rosamund Pike does a rather astounding performance.  All of the voices she creates are well done, singular, and fun to listen to.  I couldn't stop listening and enjoyed every second of it!

CommentsTitle: Forget the setting, this is the best dialogue and character development you'll find in any era
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 6, 2018
CommentsContent: I read this book as part of my concerted effort to fill in literary gaps in my reading history. And, to be honest, reading the current crop of new novels and works of non-fiction was starting to get me down. I needed a break. With few exceptions, it seems, the literary edges are all pretty sharp these days.And what a break this was. I can’t remember the last author I read that was as gifted at dialogue and character development. After every page I asked myself, “How did she do that?” The characters are nuanced, and they do grow, at least some of them, but Austen is able to maintain consistency and continuity within each character throughout the story and the abundant dialogue. Few authors of any era have accomplished that.The theater is the English landed gentry of the late 18th Century and the language, on the surface, reflects the theater, but the focus is the diverse cast of characters. She provides enough description to give the story context and realism but this is definitely a story about people and it could be people of any era. You will dislike some, laugh at the absurdity of others, and identify positively with a few. You will, however, feel them all come to life.And while it’s far from a glowing portrayal of the culture of the day it is not just a social commentary either. There is a message, but she tells a story, and, again, there aren’t many authors who have ever been able to pull that off. They usually succeed at one or the other.In the end, it was an uplifting read, not because of the storyline or the commentary, however. I’m not that interested in the culture of the British landed gentry of the 18th Century. I think I would go so far to say that I feel fortunate I was not born in the era in any class of society. It was the prose itself that was uplifting. That someone could write that effectively is really quite inspiring for a book lover.I highly recommend it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 26, 2020
CommentsContent: I loved the cover of this book and when it showed up I was horribly disappointed. This is not produced by a large publisher, but rather printed by an individual with no concept of how to design a book.The text on the cover is blurry and pixelated. The pages inside have the tiniest font because they were obviously trying to keep the page count down to reduce the cost to print.Since this book is in the public domain, beware of the copies you buy. This one (the paperback that is pink with light yellow leaves) is complete trash and I'm returning it to Amazon.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 29, 2019
CommentsContent: This is an odd purchase. It uses terms like "my expensive Mr. Bennet" instead of "my dear Mr. Bennet." What? This was written in english, but there seems to have been a translation to another language, then back to English? Also, the formatting is bad for my Kindle. I don't know why this also costs $4 when there's a free version available. Scam? I don't know. Don't purchase this eBook/Kindle book. I just got a refund.

CommentsTitle: Hate to love relationship. Don’t contemplate just read it!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 14, 2019
CommentsContent: The story is amazing and one of my favorites. I don’t think I need to say much about the story since almost everybody is acquainted with it. The cover looks cute. But it is definitely a must read for all you romantic people who love a story that evolves from disdain to love.Note: It came with a slight scratch on the upper-left corner but I don’t mind it. It has a great cover and it’s the same size as the penguin classics so it’s not a small-sized book.

CommentsTitle: So much more fun, and more accessible, than a 19th century romance has any right to be
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 18, 2020
CommentsContent: I haven’t read Pride and Prejudice since college, I don’t think, but what I remember is how much more I enjoyed the book than I expected to. For all of Jane Austen’s reputation as a romantic writer, what I took away from Pride and Prejudice was clever wit, barbed social observations, and a sense of fun and enjoyment that so many books don’t have. It’s a novel where almost all of the stakes are social ones, not world-changing ones (although the way 19th century England was, the two were basically interchangable); it’s a romance, yes, but not your typical story of star-crossed lovers or idealized people. No, Pride and Prejudice is the story of an intelligent girl who doesn’t quite fit into her society, but knows how to get along, and an arrogant man who hates most of the people around him – and with good reason, if we’re being honest. So many of them are shallow, or vapid, or both, that it’s hard to not dislike them as much as Darcy does.And yet, you can’t do that in 19th century England; nor can you throw yourself into society without some sense of pride and dignity…and there’s the conflict of the novel. But what I thought at the time would be some stuffy comedy of manners is legitimately funny and fun to read, with memorable characters to spare (Elizabeth’s condescending, mocking father is my favorite, even if he’s exacerbating every situation). And what’s more, this is a relationship that’s fun to watch develop. There’s no brooding men, no idealized human being that’s better than everyone; Elizabeth and Darcy bicker, and trade barbs, and judge each other, before both begin to realize their own arrogance and blindness in the situation. And what’s more, Austen writes the book in such a way that we’re caught up in it too, judging things based off of incomplete information and rumors, just like the characters in the novel.Add to that the numerous ways that Austen pokes at the rules and traditions of her society, while still living in it, and you have a book that’s so much more accessible, and so much more enjoyable, than its reputation might lead you to believe. I picked it up again worried that I had misremembered its pleasures, and instead was surprised by the fact that I might have, in fact, sold it short. What a joy to read.

CommentsTitle: Do NOT buy the kindle version of this book!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 7, 2019
CommentsContent: Wish I had started reading shortly after receiving because I would have returned it.  The transcription is HORRIBLE!  I don't know who/what did the transcribing, but it made no sense.  They kept mentioning ebooks, and then garbled sentences.  I tried to use my imagination to figure out what was being said, but part way thru, I had to give up.... I couldn't even try to guess what made sense in the sentence or context.HORRIBLE!!!  Don't waste your money.  Get the paperwork book, it is much better to understand the actual story!

CommentsTitle: What are you doing reading comments when you could be reading Pride and Prejudice?
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 24, 2019
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is brilliant. Once you pick it up, you won’t put it down until you’re done. After you’re done you’ll pick it up again and start over. Just like your favorite movie, no matter how many time you read it, you can always read it just one more time. It’s one of those books that has you smiling like an idiot and there is nothing you can to stop it. I read Pride and Prejudice at 13 and I found it totally comprehendible, so by all means, give this to your middle schoolers. I found Pride and Prejudice to be a read-for-fun type of book as opposed to the we-study-this-in-class type, so don’t shy away from it because it’s older! The characters in Pride and Prejudice stand out and a entertaining to get to know, especially Darcy. Austen did a magnificent job of keeping up interesting, 3D characters and maintaining a captivating plot at the same time (lots of other books I’ve read can only seem to do one or the other).  Against what seems to be popular opinion, I don't think it starts out slow. We had a reasonable amount of time dedicated to meeting the characters, but within the first few pages a new neighbor moved into town and there was a dance. I would say grab a snack and a copy of Pride and Prejudice and prepare to be up all night!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 15, 2020
CommentsContent: I’m in love with the movie of this starring Kiera Knightly so I thought I should probably actually read the book. I have not finished it yet but the storyline is great. Physically the book is very pretty and love having it on my shelf.

CommentsTitle: If I could only ever read one book, this would be it
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 16, 2020
CommentsContent: Well I’ve just finished my annual re-read, there’s a reason I’ve read this book soooo many times.  Not just because it’s my favourite book of all time, my ultimate read.  No, there’s another reason.  One word.  Darcy!  My ultimate book boyfriend.  He’s the one that all future book boyfriends have had to live up to, my first, my last, my everything.  The smoulder, the arrogance, the fact that he doesn’t suffer fools gladly and the fact that when you’re in with Darcy, you’re in, he’ll do anything for you.  That heart of his, he loves with so much passion.  Then we have Elizabeth Bennett, a true heroine, I love her so much, she too doesn’t take fools gladly, no one mess with her, she’s headstrong, loving, and independent to the core, she too loves with all her heart.  These two really are a match made in heaven once you get past all the stubbornness and formalities.  If I could only ever read one book, this would be it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2019
CommentsContent: I bought two different books in this Winter edition, Pride & Prejudice and Wuthering Heights. The covers are beautiful, intricate cut cover images laid over the blue binding. There's a protective plastic cover over the paper covers, and while you could remove it.. I'm not sure that I will. I'd rather keep the covers from being damaged, so your mileage may vary on that. The number of your particular book (out of 10,000 total) is on the inside of the book. Printing is beautiful and clear, the books are nicely made, and have an included ribbon bookmark attached. I buy a lot of ebooks these days. It's rare that a physical book is so beautiful that I really need to buy the physical copy, but it certainly was necessary in this case. These are stunning, keepsake hardcovers, and if you love classic literature the way that I do, they are a wonderful addition to a collection.

CommentsTitle: The original and still the best
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 9, 2017
CommentsContent: I own this book in hardcover because I reread it regularly. I decided to buy the Kindle version, just in case. I'm not an Austen lover per se, I don't care for any of her other novels save for the unusual short "Lady Susan". But of all the fiction I've read over the last 60 years, there is nothing like P&P. It is a classic, and will forever remain so! (Note: this Wisehouse Classics edition differs from the other Kindle edition available as this one has some nice art interspersed through the story)

CommentsTitle: The very essence of a novel -
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 31, 2020
CommentsContent: It is perfect.  Like other novels by Jane Austen, on the surface it is a love story.  However, do some research on the political and social history of England in the first quarter of the 19th century and this novel explodes into a huge metaphor and a discussion of the morality of attitudes an practice and decisions made in the land.With all Austen's novels metaphors abound and metaphors are contained within metaphors.  The physical landscape they travel over - directions, hills and dales, pouulations centres and country - underlie the mood and the changes in moral stanpoints in the novel.  And then there is the structure - the beginning, the middle and the end - and the coda.  It is just brilliant.The crux of the novel - the middle of the middle - is atthe 50% mark of the length of text.  For readers who know the novel this is when Elizabeth reads and comprehends Darcy's letter and pride and prejucice swap places.  Consider to spot where he hands her the letter - the lane beside the great park of the severe aunt whose being upholds the sucked in pretensions of wealth and a social order and aspiration to higher status all funded by so much a year from exploiting labour and land in the Carribbean and the East India Company's rape of the wealth of India.  So we have an alingnment outside and a change of alingnment that then furthers the rest of the story and that part where there is chaos centreed around the false Redcoat that is Whickam  and his move to the Blue coats.  Remember to what the Nation did with Redcoats and why there were Bluecoats and remember the Peninsular Wars ending with Waterloo and the ooccupation of colonies in the Americas and Australia.Ah - I shiver with how extraordinarialy apposite Austen's seemingly simple romance metaphor was making comment on the social norms and underlying faults of her time and place.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 12, 2017
CommentsContent: This is one of my favorite books ever, one which I re-read over and over. I downloaded this one on my Kindle because I have lent out or given away my other copies and my friends are reading it again. The same wonderful writing, but this Kindle edition is a disgrace! It appears that someone had it on a disc and downloaded it without even looking at it and left it to arrange itself willy nilly on the pages. Many, many words that perhaps were divided at the end of a line are now appearing in the middle of the line. They contain a hyphen in the middle of words that never would be hyphenated in that place. Many pages are only half pages for no reason, plus this must be a completely different book from the ones mentioned with all the wonderful pictures, because there is nothing like that in my copy. This is a book which I ordinarily love and it is ruined by all the weird things done to it on every page. My editor mind keeps screaming for a blue pencil instead of enjoying the dry humor and precise sentences of the story.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 20, 2019
CommentsContent: I'm ashamed to admit it but I started and stopped Pride and Prejudice at least four or five times before this final (successful) attempt.I saw the movie in theaters when it first came out and loved it from the first (it is still one of my favorite movies) but I couldn't for the life of me get into the book.Classics are hard for me to stick with but after struggling through Withering Heights I figured there was no better time to attempt it and I was right.The wit, the magic, the grandeur of Austen are more than I imagined. Mr. Bennett and Elizabeth frequently had me laughing with their dry witticisms.I love the language and the lightness, the verbal sparring, the balls, the decadence. More importantly I love the themes present throughout the book. Forgiveness. Familial love. Secrets bringing misfortune. Snap judgements.I loved this book so much. It's exactly the kind of wholesome content I needed.

CommentsTitle: Simply the best edition for the price
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 3, 2019
CommentsContent: Jane Austen's best known classic requires no editorial comment; I am reviewing the edition itself.  My own company, Devon Book Printing, makes custom hard cover gift editions in luxury bindings, especially leather.  I am not comparing this mass produced edition against custom-made.  That would be unfair.  But as a commercial high-volume publisher,Everyman's Library editions are superb, reasonably priced hard cover reprints of classic works, like Pride and Prejudice.  The books are small enough to be comfortable in the hand (unlike those over-sized 'collectible' editions, which are too heavy to hold for long); the editing and introductions are superb; the page layout is excellent; the font is readable; the paper and print quality is fine for the price.  Like most commercial printers, the Everyman's tends to skimp a bit on the gutter margin and the quality of the binding, but for the money, this is a good reading copy and highly recommended.

CommentsTitle: Everything I had hoped for, and much more!!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 19, 2020
CommentsContent: Although I never had read a book by Jane Austen, I have seen every movie made based on her books, every biographical and historical film about her and the times in which she lived; and I had read three biographies of her life. As much as I had admired her accomplishments and respected the manner in which she lived, I couldn't find the patience nor summon the concentration to read her books.  Then, along came Amazon and the ability to read classic literature on my Kindle. With "Pride and Prejudice" at my fingertips, I gave myself to the already much loved story of Elizabeth Bennet, her family, and Mr. Darcy.  Although the intricacies of Austen's writing tired my mind at times, her beautifully descriptive language, dynamic interactions among her marvelous characters, knowledge of the human heart, and sympathetic humor for the ridiculous side of social mores kept me going until there was no way I could put the book down.  Reading this novel was like being a confidante to Elizabeth and Jane, and I found myself rooting for their happiness even though I already knew the outcomes of their situations.At this time, I find myself in the company of millions of other Austen fans who count Elizabeth Bennet among their favorite female protagonists.  Not many people are as willing or able as she to see their own faults even more clearly than those of others. The conceit and pride which prompted her prejudice against Darcy was, in time, recognized, reviewed, and corrected without any knowledge or expectations of her efforts by him. Through his acquaintance with her, Darcy also was able to transform his pride and unfair prejudices, thus becoming more approachable, humble, modest, and open to the world.  Though seeming opposite in character and disposition when they met, both characters were willing to change and grow, thereby not only finding each other's love and respect, but mine as well!!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 18, 2019
CommentsContent: This is, as virtually everyone knows, a classic for the ages; but this Penguin edition has some excellent notes that bring the writing to life. One I remember offhand is a description of how, in England of the time, the cultivation of a garden was a moral undertaking -- that is, your garden should reflect a respect for the randomness of nature as well as provide beauty. Other excellent notes described how these folks ate -- nothing until 10, then a huge breakfast, then dinner in the late afternoon, and after music and games, supper. Also, the book is written and spelled as Austen spelled, so for example, "choose" is spelt "chuse" (and spelled is spelled spelt). Not everyone will be charmed by this, but it brought the much-loved and oft-read book to life for me in a new way.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 28, 2020
CommentsContent: First of all, pride and prejudice is my second favorite jane Austen book. I lost my other version when I moved. This new version has horribly small print. I have perfect vision and had to use my husbands reading glasses due to eye strain

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 4, 2016
CommentsContent: "It is a trope universally acknowledged that a romantic hero and heroine who loathe each other will eventually fall passionately in love."Hundreds of romance novels penned since Pride and Prejudice feature a sparring couple who fall in love despite a strong initial dislike of one another. However, I've never read one that used this trope as wonderfully as Jane Austen's masterwork.I came to Pride and Prejudice relatively spoiler free, and although it did not engage my emotions like Sense and Sensibility did, and it started out slowly for me, I was soon enthralled by Austen's characters, their witty observations and the story of prejudiced Elizabeth Bennett and proud Mr. Darcy.Austen had an unerring eye for human foibles, and her writing about them is so spot on I wanted to stand up and cheer."For what do we live, but to make sport for our neighbors, and laugh at them in our turn?""We all love to instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing.""Elizabeth found that nothing was beneath this great lady's attention, which could furnish her with an occasion of dictating to others.""Marriage ... was the only provision for well-educated young women of small fortune, and however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest preservative from want."I enjoy the occasional fluffy romance as much as anyone, but the real strength of Pride and Prejudice was Austen's refusal to sugarcoat. She laid bare the hypocrisies of her society and the obstacles it put in the path of individual happiness - especially the happiness of women.Her clear-eyed realism made me believe wholeheartedly in Elizabeth and Darcy's romance across all barriers of class and understanding.Kate Reading was a pleasant reader with the ability to distinguish characters with slight variations of pitch and tone and a knack for playing up the novel's most sardonic moments.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 27, 2018
CommentsContent: I purchased the audio version for less than $1.00, you get what you pay for. The audio is poor quality and the narrator sounds like a beginner. The whole book sounds like a podcast (which it very well may be). Chapter 6 and 9 play simultaneously (don’t ask me how) and chapter 11 played chapter 12’s audio. I’ve had to find a print copy to read the chapters that were messed up. I’m only on chapter 15 of 61 and experienced these issues, so there may be more surprises in store.*Edit: Chapter 26 audio also plays 27 simultaneously...

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 24, 2020
CommentsContent: It is an infrequent occasion I have to be grateful for my naïveté and previous ignorance; having delayed ANY consumption of the work of Jane Austen into halfway through my third decade of life is such an occasion for gratitude.The flowery prose and subject matter of the work as a “romantic” novel would have blinded me to the deeper subtlety and context of the novel, had I approached it earlier in my life.Jane Austen is an author I had written off and I’m happily humbled to have enjoyed this work the way I did. Unquestionably an absolute masterpiece.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 12, 2020
CommentsContent: Great book! I’m not sure I understand the complaints about the small print or the lack of esthetics. I read this book as a young girl and my original book was damaged so I bought this one to replace it. I love that’s it’s slim so I can take it with me easily. No issues with the print. Love it! I’ll be buying more in the series from this line.

CommentsTitle: Printed Clothbound Classics by Penguin- (with Labels that pull off design!)
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 18, 2020
CommentsContent: I am collecting all of Jane Austen's novel in these clothbound editions. They are beautiful editions, each a different color with a beautiful imprinted design on each book. Unfortunately, each one has had a code label on the back of each book. When the label is pulled off, it pulls off part of the imprinted design. Such a shame, to sell these editions with this condition. I know I am not the only customer who had this problem, just look at the reviews. I would venture to say all the Penguin Clothbound editions are like this. It is a shame the vendor feels that they can sell these editions, that have been ruined as collector books, by someone placing these damaging labels on them . There should be a disclaimer.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2021
CommentsContent: I think this is the fourth time I’ve read this and it was the first time I wanted to give it 5 stars. I think the audio book was a huge factor. It felt almost luxurious to have the story read to me. But it still hasn’t moved up in my ranking of Austen stories (right in the middle).This is such a fun cast of characters. Yes, the Darcy and Lizzie romance is well-done, but it isn’t my favorite. The sisterly bond between Jane and Lizzie is perfection. Their love for each other jumps off the page. And the relationship between Jane and Bingley gets me in the feels. I feel so bad for Jane-probably because she’s so nice.It took me so long to finish this because I wanted to savor it. I’ll definitely be listening to this again.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2020
CommentsContent: I’m not a big fan of the classics, per se, and I don’t typically read Victorian romance novels. But I’ve watched the 2005 movie with Keira Knightly many times, and finally decided to read the book. I’m glad I did. The movie follows the book quite closely, so you don’t need to read the book to get the “real” plot. Apart from all the cultural differences between then and now, the book highlighted for me the evolution of the language of books, of simple storytelling literature. I don’t think “write for a 7th grader” was a rule back then, and Austin’s language is refreshing. She uses “every body” and “some thing” too much for my taste, but her typical dialog almost seems written for the screen, providing clear insight to the conflicting thoughts and feelings of the characters. And her first chapter really is a study in how to write a beginning that sets the stage and grabs the reader.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 3, 2020
CommentsContent: I have been a high school/middle school English teacher for close to two decades. Amazingly, I had never read "Pride and Prejudice." I finally did, and blasphemous as it will seem to many, I don't see what the great fuss people make about this book is all about. The story was fine, and I got a chuckle out of some of the characters and situations, but overall, the story did not move me. I struggled with her style and the language of her day with which she wrote, AND I'M AN ENGLISH TEACHER! I can only imagine how difficult it would have been for my students had I ever taught this. But now that I have read it, I now know that I will never teach it, if I don't have to do so. Sorry all of you fans. Just not my cup of tea (English allusion/pun intended)

CommentsTitle: Will always be a favorite in our house
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 28, 2017
CommentsContent: Beautifully written!  I love that this is still relevant in these times. The snarky humour and wit make me smile to myself when I read the lines.  What Elizabeth thinks of her mother, Bingley's sisters, her cousin Mr. Collins and Charlotte Lucas all make me think that I'm a bit Lizzy'ish myself.Lydia is a riot: boycrazy, impulsive, poor manners, and a drama queen.Although I've seen 3 screen adaptations, I still prefer to read the book, at least once every couple years.Jane Austen was quite young when she wrote this, but she had an amazing understanding of human nature and class distinctions.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 1, 2021
CommentsContent: The was in bad condition. The pages are smashed in some places. The Spine has gouges in it and the entire book itself is just "off." It does not sit straight when laid down and the pages do not line up on top of one another as they should. When holding the book open, the pages look slanted. The shipping package was fine, so I am assuming that the book was liked this before it was shipped and was shipped out to me anyway. I keep and collect my books, so I ordered a replacement to swap this one out. I hope my replacement is ok and this one was a fluke. I will update my review once I received my second one.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 8, 2020
CommentsContent: This is a review of the paperback Peacock edition, revived. I am loving re-reading Pride and Prejudice with all of Hugh Thomson's delightful illustrations. They are black and white, and a few are a bit blurred, but most are very clear. I never realized there were so many illustrations, or that they were so fun! The capital letter beginning each chapter is drawn as a little cartoon, and most chapters have one or two pictures. Most are humorous, and closely related to the text. I'm so glad I bought this edition, even though I have the book in other versions. There are far more illustrations here than you will find scanned online. Enjoy!

CommentsTitle: Chiltern Classic Edition - Beautiful, but with quirks/flaws.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 21, 2020
CommentsContent: The Chiltern Classic Edition has an absolutely beautiful cover, silver edges, and is a dainty size. However, the paper quality is really strange -- very glossy and shiny, pretty much like a textbook or children's picture book in terms of thickness and shine. It took me by surprise, as it is definitely not the "feel" of what I would expect from a classic novel. Additionally, there are some strange editorial discrepancies -- Jane is referred to as Miss Bennett in some places where it doesn't make sense, some strange variations in spelling of words such as "chuse" vs "choose" in some other places which is strange inconsistency. Overall, an OK and pretty book to have in a collection, but not perfect. A little disappointing for the price.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2021
CommentsContent: The basic political thought behind Communism is simply laid out in this pamphlet. It is interesting in that I read this during college and this reread on my part helps solidify my thoughts around why communism did not work prior to the writing of the manifesto as noted in the manifesto and why it will never work after in that it does not factor in human nature,

CommentsContent: really cute LITTLE book with gold edged pages. super adorable as decoration. real depends on you if you’ll like the actual book. i couldn’t finish it because it was obvious what was going to happen within the first 60ish pages (of like 400 because it is quite small). my grandma read it and hated it, she said it was just really boring and dragged on. my english teacher actually recommended i read it because she thought i’d like it (and she knows how much i dislike reading) so i might try again but you just have to read it to know.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 31, 2020
CommentsContent: I would have normally rated Pride & Prejudice *****, however this version is some pixelated inauthentic printed version. If you look at the photo, the cover is blurry and it's not from my phone. Its as if someone took the book, tried to fit as many words as possible to minimize pages and made some horrible cover. The size is 7.5, very difficult to read. I have to return this version and get a different version to finish the book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 21, 2019
CommentsContent: Dear God, this version is horrible!  it is NOT the original text, someone has paraphrased it and thed writing is horrific…so upset that so many people have read this and think it is the original

CommentsTitle: High quality, better than expected, and beyond worth the price
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 9, 2019
CommentsContent: I am very pleased with the quality of this book. I already loved the story of "Pride and Prejudice" before buying this copy, but the quality of the book itself made reading it even better. The slip cover has two beautiful pictures of an artist's depiction of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy. The hardcover is a beautiful floral imprinted light blue fabric, the pages are gold-edged, and there is a ribbon bookmark embedded in the spine. The print is crisp and clean, with some lovely illustrations added throughout the book. It's a smaller sized book, so it's easy to hold in the hands and carry in a purse or other bag.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 14, 2019
CommentsContent: The book is nice for only being $3. You definitely get what you pay for though.  This is the way the book looked out of the box when I received it today.  It's supposed to be new but it looks very used and had little crumbs almost stuck on the front that left grease Mark's when I took it off.  The binding and the cover and back are all torn and marked up.  I didnt expect to get pictures inside.  Overall it's not bad,but I'm definitely not happy with the way the book is on the outside.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 30, 2019
CommentsContent: Seasons Edition “Winter” collection, these books are absolutely gorgeous, perfect for Christmas gifts, I purchased “Little Women and Pride and Prejudice” for friends for Christmas, I purchased “Wuthering Heights (my favorite book) and Pride and Prejudice” for myself! Perfectly readable beautiful copy.

CommentsTitle: Returned to this classic-what a delight!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 27, 2019
CommentsContent: Go back and read or reread a classic such as Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen to appreciate and experience superb writing as a reader.  Elizabeth and Darcy shows us how people from different backgrounds and social standings exhibit their own reasoned out pride and prejudice toward each other, the social and cultural classes that divide them.  Each stands their ground until, over time, they get closer to the middle in accepting and understanding the social world they live in, thereby; allowing them to blend together with true love, and not forever set them apart. Beautiful, feisty, and a most enjoyable read.  Quotable lines, I wish I could put to permanent memory.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 28, 2020
CommentsContent: Print is so small and chapters are weirdly divided from page to page. Not very nice for readers who enjoy the aesthetics of the inside of a book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 18, 2017
CommentsContent: After many attempts and too many distractions I have finally read this brilliant classic. Jane Austen was way ahead of her time. She created characters with sophisticated nuance and gave them witty dialogue. She perfectly captures the power of love over pride and humility over prejudice. Any reader finding the language difficult to grasp should think of the rhythm of her words which creates a flow so indicative of Austen's period. Also an e-reader helps with the more obscure language.Read this masterpiece, you will love it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2021
CommentsContent: Having trouble finding editions with illustrations (I craft with them) I was delighted to see the title of this edition:  Pride And Prejudice: Illustrated With Both 1894 And 1895 Edition IllustrationsIt must be an inside joke, as there are no illustrations at all.  Very disappointed.

CommentsTitle: it was supremely boring for me as the whole book is about the ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 9, 2018
CommentsContent: So, I don't read classics much. But I am a romance reader and I needed something cheaper in audiobook format to listen to. I've always wanted to read Jane Austen, but I just never did. At first, it was supremely boring for me as the whole book is about the marriage market with very little romance with it. But by the time Mr. Darcy was becoming obviously interesting, I did thoroughly enjoy the story. My rating is just personal taste as it was difficult to get used to the way it was written, understandably. It was written a very long time ago. But I actually really liked Darcy and Elizabeth and so wanted more in depth attractions because of the romances I'm used to. I really enjoyed the listen, though, and only wished I could have liked it more as it is more than deserving!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 18, 2014
CommentsContent:
Pride and Prejudice
By: Jane Austen
Rating: 4 stars
Ages: 13 and up

I adore the movie inspired by this book, Pride and Prejudice. Jane Austen created fascinating, wonderful characters that I adore. Pride and Prejudice has been a long-time classic loved by generations of girls like myself. What makes this story so fascinating? The enthralling romance. Tons of dialogue. Incredibly real-in-their-decisions characters - Pride and Prejudice is undoubtedly fun. I found myself anticipating the wonderful conclusion, smiling and laughing at some of Mr. Collin's rediculousness, and really wanting to watch the movie. :)

Pride and Prejudice is quite fascinating. The story moved along easily and (if you read over a hundred pages in one day, like I did), moved quickly. The story was dynamic, sweet, and interesting.

Characters:

Elizabeth Bennet (main character) was vivacious, to say the least. She was bold and showed it quite often. She's reasonable, and her actions and sentiments were very understandable. A great heroine.

Fitzwilliam Darcy ('hero' of the story) was such a different kind of male character than what I see in books today. At first, he seems proud and self-centered, and he looks down at others for inferiority of birth, lack of wealth, etc. But underneath is such a loveable character. The true Mr. Darcy finally comes out in the last third of the story, leaving you smiling. He changed so much from the first page he entered the story to the last.

Mr. Whickam (most villanious character) is eventually proven to be a blackguardly fellow, but doesn't appear to be so. He was more dimensional than most villians are created to be. Really, though, I didn't like him.

Mr. Collins (Elizabeth's cousin) was so much more annoying in the movie! In the book he was actually a tall young man. (In the movie he is short, has a nail-on-chalkboard voice, and isn't very handsome.) An interesting character who added to the plot and was memorable.

Mrs. Bennet - a most irritating and disturbing character. The only important thing in her life is to see her daughters married well-off - that is practically her only focus at all. Terrily rude, nervous, and so changing in attitude. The poor girls who had her as a mother!

Lydia Bennet (Elizabeth's youngest sister) was most bothersome and...annoying. Most annoying. Really, she was a cringe-worthy character.

Overall:

I enjoyed the book, but not as much as the movie. I am very glad I read it. I would recommend it to classical literature readers.

Also, two of the quotes I like from Pride and Prejudice are:

"A lady's imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love to matrimony in a moment." (Mr. Darcy)

"Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my opinion."

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 2, 2021
CommentsContent: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife." And so goes the famous first line of my favorite book of ALL TIME!  Pride and Prejudice is a universal classic for a reason... countless versions, movie adaptations, spin-offs, etc.  I was quite delighted to find this copy for my Kindle app and found it quite serviceable for my 4th or 5th reading of Darcy and Elizabeth, et al.

CommentsTitle: this novel is mediocre at best. It is a novel
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 20, 2015
CommentsContent: After reading Austen’s Emma, and seeing all the rave reviews of Pride and Prejudice, I expected to be blown away by this novel. I was not. To me, this novel is mediocre at best. It is a novel, that for the most part, has a whole lot of nothing happening up until about a little over halfway through it. While it does a superb job of showing the customs and mindsets of the time period, for me, it did not do much of anything else to draw me in. The plot can be summarized as Elizabeth going, “I hate him,” with Mr Darcy thinking, “I love her,” then go back and forth a bunch of times. In all honesty the book never becomes entertaining until Wickham as a character begins to develop and show his attitude towards the world. Now, I would be lying if I did not admit that eventually I was cheering for the relationship of Darcy and Elizabeth, but I did not find myself doing that until much further into the plot, and that is why I give  this read a three out of five review. It is ok.

CommentsTitle: College course went great because I bought the book
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2021
CommentsContent: I had to read Pride and Prejudice for my college English class. It was good. A little hard to grasp at first because I went into it knowing nothing of the book. Towards the end it was easier to read. If you have to read it for school do yourself a favor and find the BBC adaptation to watch along with it. It really hones in on the personalities of the characters. They also use many direct quotes from the book, which is always good.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 22, 2014
CommentsContent: Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice", first published in 1813, is considered her best novel. It continues to be a fertile source of material for television and film adaptations. It is the classic romantic comedy, even if the setting is Regency-era England."It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a good wife." So begins the story, as the five eligible young Bennet daughters and their scheming mother learn of the arrival in their small English village of a wealthy young man and his wealthy friends. A village dance provides the opportunity to meet the newcomers. Elizabeth Bennet, the spirited and headstrong second sister, meets and immediately dislikes the haughty Mr. Darcy. Her dislike will prompt a scathing response to a surprise marriage proposal.Fate, however, keeps throwing the two young people together. In a chance meeting at Mr. Darcy's home of Pemberly, Elizabeth learns that perhaps there is more to Mr. Darcy than her first impressions. When Elizabeth's younger sister scandalously elopes with a penniless militia officer, the ensuing crisis threatens the future of Elizabeth and all her sisters. The surprising resolution of the crisis leaves Elizabeth hoping for an impossible second chance with Mr. Darcy.Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" features a engaging plot, lots of excellent dialogue and two classic romantic characters in Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy, a combination that holds up astonishingly well two hundred years on. It is very highly recommended to fans of the various Jane Austen film productions as the entertaining original source of the story.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 26, 2019
CommentsContent: I primarily use the Audiobook of the novel, although Jane Austen’s written work, which I have in paperback and ebook,  is unparalleled in richness and beauty. Rosalind Pike’s, the narrator, has an extraordinary ability to sound like the characters.  How she manages to sound like the fastidious Dr. Collins one minute, the condescending Lady Catherine de Bourgh or the childish Mrs. Bennett not to mention all the others,  is beyond me! I listen to the audiobook over and over to relax. It’s a great romantic story.
