CommentsContent: The Russian and Chinese totalitarian regimes and the bad experience that communism exibits to the world needs to be tempered with successful socialist government of the north of Europe where it is working mostly flawlessly. This was the basic guide to get away from industrial revolution's dominance of government in the late 1800's early 1900's which enslaved the working man.  Good read, mostly in black and grey.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 18, 2019
CommentsContent: The Book is absolutely beautiful and vibrant, The “gold” edges are beautiful and eye catching. The words are big and it’s the perfect book to take on a spring picnic.

CommentsTitle: "Pride and Prejudice" Winchester Austen Edition is a physical delight.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 19, 2013
CommentsContent: This is not a review of the novel itself, (which is wonderful) but of the Winchester Austen Edition (henceforth WAE) of Pride and Prejudice, published by Word Press in 2007. After buying a copy of WAE "Emma" in Costco, I knew I had to have "Pride & Prejudice" in WAE as well.  Here's why:-The WAE versions of Jane Austen's books are hardcover and physically comfortable in that they are printed on smooth white paper rather than typical beige rough paper and the typeface is solid roman type that is easy on the eyes.-The size is approximately 5X8. The corners of the pages are rounded giving it a soft look.  The covers of all WAE, are  completely black, except for the title and author and  also have rounded corners.  Attached to the back cover is an elastic band that  goes around the height of the book and you can use this as a book mark or as a way to keep your book closed.-Each WAE novel has colorful inside covers depicting a scene from the novel and there are nice color drawings included in the introduction.-Each novel has at least three sets of notes written by Austen scholars.  Most of the notes are the same in all the novels, but each novel has one additional note section peculiar to that novel.  The notes that all editions have are a timeline in color of Jane Austen's world and a color map of Austen's England. In P&P the additional notes is the illustrated Army in Austen's time.I bought used copies of WAE novels because even used, they are sturdy and comfortable.  I am very hard on books by intention.  I read while I eat, before I sleep,  while waiting on lines, etc. But mainly, I like to embellish my books with beads, ribbons and lace, and even some rubber stamping on the white spaces in the text itself.  I wouldn't have the heart to do that to an expensive hardcover.If you like the "feel" of books, I highly recommend the Winchester Austen Edition of any of Austen's novels.  Let me know what you think.

CommentsTitle: Why is the font so tiny?
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 4, 2020
CommentsContent: I'm not sure who made the decision to make the paperback font an alarmingly small size, but why?You could have made it a normal size and then the book could have had a normal page count instead of being the thickness of a children's chapter book. The cover design also isn't fantastic, but I'd be fine with that if I could read the book without squinting. I'm returning it.

CommentsTitle: Always a bright spirit can be found in Austen.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 24, 2020
CommentsContent: I discovered Austen late in life; this is my sixth time through P&P and  she never fails to delight and illuminate. What a guide for living, P&P shows us that self pride is an easy addiction and that first impressions are especially dangerous.  Of course Lizzy is herself an addiction; wit and charm, sarcasm and subborness. While she and Darcy may be destined to marry, their happiness is not, without the work they must first put in. If you have not read P&P in years let yourself have the next dance.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 13, 2019
CommentsContent: i have been wanting to get more into literature and after reading a novel series called After by Anna Todd that mentioned it a lot, i immediately wanted to read P&P. it was SOOOO good! and the cover is so pretty lol! <3

CommentsTitle: The most widely read novel in the English language for a reason
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2016
CommentsContent: This story is absolutely superb, truly the definitive romance novel. The only negative, for modern readers, is that, being written over 200 years ago, the language is somewhat flowery and antiquated. But for those willing to read Pride and Prejudice, they will find Jane Austen to be a truly wonderful author. Her wit is subtle, but sharp as a razor. Virtually every modern romance novel and movie has roots in Pride and Prejudice.Pride and Prejudice is the most widely read novel in the English language for a very good reason: Jane Austen simply knocked it out of the park.If you don't want to read the book, or love the book and want to see a good movie adaptation:The absolute best adaptation is the 1995 BBC miniseries starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.A good, but abbreviated, adaptation is the 2005 movie starring Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2014
CommentsContent: First off I love Jane Austen. Pride and Prejudice is one of my favorite novels of all time. The three stars is for Oxford World's Classics' edition.-The introduction reads like a high school student's final. There is a lot of info with no point made.-The appendices are good and I am sure would be helpful to anyone less familiar with the social conventions of the time.-I could not stand the explanatory notes. This may be a personal preference though. When novels use words or phrases that are now obsolete I like nice, succinct footnotes so I can glance down get the meaning and move on. If there are notes about how a certain line /might/ be referencing something from literally two hundred years ago or how a line was different in the novel's second print, they can be thrown in the back. In this edition archaic words/ phrases are numbered along with little factoid lines and all the information is thrown in the back which means flipping back and forth and searching whenever a little number note pops up. It keeps the reader from immersing fully (well this reader anyway).

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 8, 2016
CommentsContent: I have always wondered about Pride and Prejudice, and if all the praises I heard were true. I was told that Mr. Darcy was charming, but I found out that he was a proud man. And quite annoying. To many Elizabeth Bennet was the role model of women, but I discovered that she was prejudiced, even when she might be right.But at the end this was a really interesting tale. There was no one moment when I wanted to quit it, because I needed to know how things would develop. There were some surprises on the journey, and by the end I really enjoyed the story.Expectations that weren't fulfill: so.... I thought Elizabeth was a bookworm.... I didn't see her but pick up one book. Mary was more of the reader.The romance was totally lacking. I thought I would see more of it than the last 3% of the book. But I do understand why people praise Pride and Prejudice as a masterpiece of its time.

CommentsTitle: Exhausting, time consuming, and at times humourous
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 4, 2015
CommentsContent: I liked the story, BUT, it was very difficult to get through it.  I have to pride myself that I actually got through the whole book even though it took more than a month to read.  It was so wordy!  So descriptive! and the English language that Jane Austin used was most difficult to understand at times because she kept rambling on and on and on and on about anything and everything.  I had to read it very slowly.  If this is a true account of 18th century times, I'm so glad I don't live in an egotistical world as those where only title and rank in society and how much money you make as a person and as a family is the only thing that matters.  I have to admit that there were times when I had to chuckle at the ridiculousness of the events and conversations that were taking place.  I especially enjoyed Mr. Bennett's banter with his silly, willy, wife.  I have also bought Sense and Sensibility but I'm not sure I'm going to read it, at least not for a long while.

CommentsTitle: What romantic can resist this story?
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 29, 2015
CommentsContent: Who doesn't at least like Pride & Prejudice? It is delightful. I consider the pairing of Lizzie and Mr. Darcy an intriguing story. The first time I read it (about 50 times ago) I had no idea what the story could be. To say there is no sexual content, is to say there is nothing like we of the 21st century are accustomed to in that regard.This book tends toward finer feelings at a time when marriage was more a financial issue than one of the heart. Lizzie's mother is cognizant of the necessity to marry her five daughters to men who will be able to support them, because the girls' small incomes will not adequately pay their way through life. Lizzie, however, does not see how she could bear marrying just for sustenance. She and her elder sister Jane discuss these issues in their daily conversations. They are of marrying age, but who among their acquaintance would be a good husband? A change to their dreary routine comes in the form of a young gentleman who lets a nearby lodge. Suddenly, life's events become less predictable and more exciting.

CommentsTitle: Excellent Audio Narration One of English Fiction's Greatest Love Stories
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 5, 2020
CommentsContent: Marvellous love story set in late Georgian England. A classic.The story is easy to listen to narrated by Rosalind Pike. Well worth listening to even if you've seen the mini series. The original novel has much more detail and Elizabeth's thinking and feelings. I use it as bedtime sleep reading because if I fall asleep I know the story so well it doesn't matter if I miss some.

CommentsTitle: An abridged version and therefore returned
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2021
CommentsContent: The book I received was in good condition and written in English as far as I could tell although I could nor stand to read very much of it.It was an abridged version designed for a pre-teen or even younger. The sentiments, vocabulary, and grammar had been altered from Jane Austen’s to those readers. All the magic seems to have been removed.This was not clear on the web site.The book has been returned.

CommentsTitle: Classic Story of 19th Century British Courtship
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 16, 2014
CommentsContent: Jane Austen wrote great stories which were commentaries on society at that time, and this is no exception.  It's the story of an aristocratic family in England in the 1800s trying to marry off 5 daughters.  This is the story with Mr. Darcy in it (he's been in a lot of movies in the past couple of years).  Despite having been written nearly 200 years ago, it still feels witty and entertaining.  I actually have physical copies of this book, but I love it so much that I wanted it on my Kindle so I can read it while traveling, if the mood moves me.This edition is different, in that it contains commentaries.  Some are informative, such as the notation that since Mr. Darcy had an extensive library at home, this is proof that he was quite wealthy.  Some are just humorous, like the notation after the initial description of Darcy to the effect of ,"yes, sounds like Colin Firth." or the footnoted comment that from Darcy's introduction to disliked character took a bit over 500 words.  Sometimes these comments were distracting, but they were informative and sometimes entertaining, and might have been helpful to a first time reader who isn't a longtime fan of early 1800s literature.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 12, 2019
CommentsContent: I wish I could give this zero stars because one is too many. I've read Pride and Prejudice before and loved it, but as I started this edition I found the language so difficult and convoluted that something had to be wrong. There is.  I compared it with the Penguin edition which is excellent and the gold standard, readable and apparently close to the original.  This one from Amazon services simply reads like a bad translation and I can't believe that it actually has lots of five-star reviews.  Also, I'm angry with Amazon for only showing me this edition on my Kindle which was far more expensive than the other editions (Penguin's was 59 cents and others were free). Why didn't more options show up on the Kindle?  Bad job, Amazon.  I want my money back!

CommentsTitle: Not just well done, but done very well!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 17, 2014
CommentsContent: Wonderful, insightful, integrated "in-text" notes, which enhance the readers enjoyment marvelousl; they are the chief reason this edition is so special.  They provided a deeper understanding of the story and its epoch, without disturbing the completely pleasurable reading experience. This book has the feel of a novel written more recently with its short yet elegant chapters and subtle humor.  I recommend this edition for first-time and returing readers of this terrific novel.  I am a 65 year old, retired, male who has been a baker, truck driver, U.S.Navy Corpsman, medical Certified (and registerd with the A.R.R.T.) Radiologic Technologist, a car salesman, a closer, a deskman, motivational speaker, F. and I. manager, adult Sunday school teacher, Baptist deacon and lay preacher.  I mention this because I am not part of the usual demographic that make-up the readership of this novel and to encourage and perhaps widen the readership of this novel to folks who are on the border of deciding whether to read it or not.  This edition is worth the price of admission!  Buy, read and enjoy.

CommentsTitle: I love this edition - it's gorgeous
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 15, 2015
CommentsContent: This is just a review for the Word Cloud Classics edition.I love this edition - it's gorgeous. The colors are vibrant and the cover is smooth and silky and wonderful. The overall design is lovely and the end papers are cute and in general it's a nice book to look at and definitely one for fan's of Jane's work or collectors of multiple editions (like myself.) The only reason I knocked a star off is because the book show dirt very easily. They pick up every little smudge and speck of dirt and seem like they're not meant to be handled. For someone who plans on reading Pride and Prejudice, if you want to keep this edition in good condition, read a different edition.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 5, 2018
CommentsContent: This was a good book.  It took me a while to get used to Jane's dialect because of the time in which it was written but overall I enjoyed it nonetheless.  I think many women today are like Elizabeth Bennett.  Her infectious personality and freedom of speech makes her timeless and radiant!  I knew I would love this book and I have always wanted to read it!  Thank your Jane for this masterpiece and exquisite work of art!  I will cherish this one forever!

CommentsTitle: The invention of the intelligent romance novel.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2020
CommentsContent: This novel starts so slow that many gave up on it in HS English. Rereading it years later with better knowledge of history and plot structure is quite a different story. The intelligent building of the plot, the character development and the fascinating early 18th century language made this a fascinating adventure! Penguin’s history of the British timeline associated with Jane Austen’s life just made it better.The most amazing factor, to me, is how understandable and relatable it is in 2020 America.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 4, 2012
CommentsContent: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife."That's probably one of the most famous opening sentences of a novel, along with Moby Dick. Pride and Prejudice is also probably one of Jane Austen's most famous novels. I certainly liked it much more than Northanger Abbey. It is the story of Elizabeth Bennet, who lives with five sisters, and an odd pair of parents at Longbourn. Her mother is constantly scheming about marrying off her daughters to wealthy young men, so when Netherfield Park is let to the rich Mr. Bingley, she is very excited indeed. (Mr. Bennet's estate will be entailed away from the immediate family upon his death, so at least one of the sisters has to marry well to provide for them.) And Mr. Bingley brings his very proud friend, Mr. Darcy. The book is about the courtships, and, of course, has many twists and turns. Mr. Darcy, Mr. Bingley, Mr. Wickham, and I suppose, the detestable Mr. Collins (who the estate will be entailed to) are the main men of the story.I really loved this one; it had humor and wit in it, and great characters. I enjoyed Mr. Bennet and his sarcasm very much, though Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are really too silly sometimes. So stupid. And of course, Elizabeth. She is really a very smart and spirited young woman, who will not be ordered around. I also watched the 1995 TV series from BBC, and I must confess, Mr. Darcy...never mind.Anyway, all the characters were well portrayed, and while the TV series is wonderful, it doesn't quite have the subtlety of the conversations in Pride and Prejudice itself. The TV series did have excellent casting though; all the Bennets, Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Collins were portrayed very well. (Yes, I suppose this is sort of a double review.) I would say though, that Caroline Bingley should have been a little prettier; she was just hideous, and Mr. Bingley was kind of silly-looking. But everywhere else, they did very well.Back to the book. As I said, there were many twists and turns which made this one a thoroughly enjoyable read. And really great characters. Though she is certainly less descriptive and florid than Dickens, Austen still manages in this one, to portray everyone extremely well. Mr. Collins really is detestable, Bingley overly-cheerful and positive, and Darcy stiff and stern (though he has his reasons, of course.) Mrs. Bennet is an extremely foolish woman, as is Lydia, the youngest Bennet. The pride and prejudice of the story refer, I believe, to Mr. Darcy's pride and Elizabeth's prejudice (though it is certainly debatable.) Mr. Darcy is very proud indeed at the beginning of the story, and Elizabeth's prejudice prevents her from seeing his true character for a while.I will just add that I read the Penguin Classics Deluxe Edition from 2009, and while it has a very nice design, it does not have any analysis or introduction, so if you want that you'd be better off reading the Penguin Classics regular edition or Oxford World Classics. However, my Penguin Classics Deluxe edition arrived slightly damaged on the spine, which was a disappointment.[...]

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 11, 2019
CommentsContent: Well made edition with colorful paperedges. To protect the lasercut-cover a plastic cover was positioned over the hardcovers, which I was very pleased to see; it will keep my book beautiful for ages to come. I appreciated the bookplate on the inside letting me know which copy of the 10,000 I received.

CommentsTitle: My favorite Jane Austen book so far
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 2, 2019
CommentsContent: I decided to read all of the Jane Austen books. I never read them as a teenager, and I know that my sister is a huge fan. She's read all of the books and has seen all of the movie adaptions. I really liked book, and as a man it's always nice to hear the female perspective on love and marriage.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 17, 2021
CommentsContent: I love anything by Jane Austin!  Her novels are well written, page turners for me.  But then I love anything British. It may be slow for some people but that is why the characters are so well developed. Definitely should be on everyone's reading list, especially high school university age.  It teaches about personal integrity.  Much needed in today's world.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 8, 2020
CommentsContent: This book was a real pleasure to read!  I had downloaded it a while back just out of curiosity but never got around to reading it. I picked it up again after deleting the current book I was reading because I felt that the author really had his own agenda rather than my entertainment.  It was a little daunting to begin with, but as I continued on, it became a real pleasure. I loved the characters and could only wish for some of the manners and politeness in today’s society that was shown in the book. Again, a great read!

CommentsTitle: Will Elizabeth ever get married? What about her four sisters?
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 5, 2015
CommentsContent: It's a classic, of course. Everyone should read it. Austen is wry, a keen observer. The story is a bit cliched by now, but then it was written in the late 1700's. Girl thinks rich guy is stuck up, doesn't like him. But, toward the end of a long story, things change. Interesting view of social norms in the late 18th century. Still interesting and surprisingly easy to read today, the story has been made into movies and TV specials. Mr. and Mrs. Bennett live in a community in rural England not far (but a good long ride by horse or carriage then) from London. They have five daughters. Since he has no son, Mr. Bennett's estate will go to a distant male cousin when he dies. The daughters must find husbands or they will be destitute. Those are the curious conditions of English law at the time, and they set up the story. We thus understand the importance of having an eligible bachelor with a substantial income and property to dinner, of who he dances with at a "ball," a social event at a gracious, private home in the community or a nearby one. So it's not an action-packed adventure story, but it's not necessarily just for girls. It is written by a woman who tells us the story through the eyes of the Bennett's second daughter, Elizabeth. Both are clever, independent-thinking women with keen eyes for social nuance and little tolerance for hypocrisy and foolishness. Elizabeth is such a good observer and so independent and outspoken, you'll think she'll never get married in the society Austin describes. The story's been around now for more than 200 years, but I'm still not going to tell you how it comes out.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 16, 2012
CommentsContent: I decided to reread this classic because I wanted to read PD James' new novel which continues the story of Darcy and Elizabeth after their marriage when there is a murder. I wondered if I would enjoy this book after reading it some decades ago and seeing at least one movie version of it. To my delight, I found the rereading fun. The statement that a classic is a classic because people enjoy reading it is true. The book is filled with humor and witty social comments. Jane Austen pocks fun at the generally uneducated women of her age, their silliness, their interest in looking beautiful, men, marriage, and family, the strong difference between them and the men in their lives, and how some very intelligent women, such as Elizabeth Bennet, stand out despite not being as beautiful as her sisters, and accomplishing more than them. This was a time when a woman walking three miles was unusual and women reading non-fiction was extraordinary. The story focuses on Elizabeth and on Darcy's pride. He is very good looking, rich, more intelligent than most of the people he encounters, and sees their foolish behavior and thoughts as a waste of time and absurd. His first impression of Elizabeth is negative. Looking only at her surface, he sees a young woman who is not as beautiful as others at a party. As a result, he makes a remark that Elizabeth overhears, that disparages her. Later, he sees the beauty of her character and intelligence. But Elizabeth has become blind to his worth because of the prejudice created by his remark, and she avoids him. The story becomes even more interesting when other characters are introduced and we read about the five Bennet girls and their parents' reactions to them. Some seem good or bad at first, but are they, and why do they seem like they do?

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 1, 2009
CommentsContent:
Pride and Prejudice is Jane Austen's most popular novel and it is remarkable that it has sustained such a high popularity 200 years after it was originally published. The primary plot of the story follows Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy in a highly contentious courtship that begins with mutual contempt but evolves quite unexpectedly for both into very different feelings. Subplots involve her sister Jane and Mr. Bingley in a courtship of their own as well as the romantic entanglements of various other sisters and friends. The story is a bit of a roller coaster ride with soaring hopes and crushing disappointment in store as events unfold. I won't reveal the ending for the handful of people who haven't read it but suffice to say that the novel concludes in a way that leaves the vast majority of readers well satisfied.Darcy and Elizabeth are complex and multi-layered characters who both grow and change somewhat as the book progresses. They are the heart and soul of the book and about as well fleshed out as any characters you are likely to see. The supporting characters, however, are considerably less deep and are more caricatures than anything else. Some are good and kind like Jane and Mr. Bingley, and others are ridiculous and vain like Mrs. Bennet but none are remotely as substantial as Darcy and Elizabeth. So, does this ruin the book? Hardly. These secondary characters offer a wealth of material for the author as she plays them off of Darcy and Elizabeth.This novel is almost certainly the one where Austen best displays her sharp-edged wit both through Elizabeth's dialogue and in the narrative voice describing some of these characters and their actions. If some of them were less ridiculous, the potential for the satire would be weakened considerably. And make no mistake, Pride and Prejudice is as much a satire of the time it was written, as it is a romantic drama. Even today, the prose is quite funny and enjoyable.As much as I love Pride & Prejudice, I must admit that some of the words are now archaic and some of the references have become obscure due to the passage of time.  The 

  
Pride and Prejudice (Enriched Classics)









  
  
    
   edition provides helpful footnotes to help readers understand the nuances of the novel more completely.In summary, this is a great novel. Admittedly, there were a few times where I thought a character's behavior was a bit over-the-top but the overall story is so riveting and the book so compelling that I just can't find any serious fault with it. Pride and Prejudice is deserving of its reputation and I highly recommend it to Austen fans and newcomers alike.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 29, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this book for my twelve year old daughter, she loved the movie so much I knew she'd love the book even more.I was absolutely right. the books presentation was great. it's a small half sized paper back with it's own stringed book mark, and it's micro size is a parts of it's charm. she has read thru the book twice now, her enjoyment is all that matters and I couldn't be happier.

CommentsTitle: 5 stars for the content, 2 stars for the kindle version
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 27, 2015
CommentsContent: I have a physical version of Pride and Prejudice, but I often take my kindle with me to work to read at lunch so I bought a kindle version since I love this book and read it at least once a year. There is so much information on it that I won't review the content here, except to say read it at least once in your life. Now for the kindle version itself...It is poorly formatted and edited. If this is your first reading of Pride and Prejudice, borrow a physical version from the library or a friend or buy a copy. For me, since I've read it many times, I'm not completely sorry I have the kindle version since I can have it at my fingertips anywhere, but if editing errors and poor formatting annoy you, don't download this version.

CommentsTitle: Probably a bit girly for me but an enjoyable read
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2019
CommentsContent: It’s not surprising that a girl recommended this to me and insisted that while I wouldn’t find my ‘book boyfriend’ in Mr Darcy, I’d still love it… love it, I’m not sure about that but it was enjoyable.Jane Austen’s portrayal of middle/upper class society at that time in England was interesting and stirred nostalgic feelings of a time long past, however, Elizabeth’s mordant personality and clashes with Mr. Darcy remind you that nothing much has changed between the relationship between men and women! Mr. Bennett’s character sustained me through the overwhelming female overtones, God knows how he endured Mrs Bennett.It probably is a bit girly for me, I’d prefer Dickens for that Victorian period, but not a total waste of time.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 22, 2007
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is Jane Austen's most popular novel and it is remarkable that it has sustained such a high popularity 200 years after it was originally published.  The primary plot of the story follows Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy in a highly contentious courtship that begins with mutual contempt but evolves quite unexpectedly for both into very different feelings.  Subplots involve her sister Jane and Mr. Bingley in a courtship of their own as well as the romantic entanglements of various other sisters and friends.  The story is a bit of a roller coaster ride with soaring hopes and crushing disappointment in store as events unfold.  I won't reveal the ending for the handful of people who haven't read it but suffice to say that the novel concludes in a way that leaves the vast majority of readers well satisfied.Darcy and Elizabeth are complex and multi-layered characters who both grow and change somewhat as the book progresses.  They are the heart and soul of the book and about as well fleshed out as any characters you are likely to see.  The supporting characters, however, are considerably less deep and are more caricatures than anything else.  Some are good and kind like Jane and Mr. Bingley, and others are ridiculous and vain like Mrs. Bennet but none are remotely as substantial as Darcy and Elizabeth.  So, does this ruin the book?  Hardly.  These secondary characters offer a wealth of material for the author as she plays them off of Darcy and Elizabeth.This novel is almost certainly the one where Austen best displays her sharp-edged wit both through Elizabeth's dialogue and in the narrative voice describing some of these characters and their actions.  If some of them were less ridiculous, the potential for the satire would be weakened considerably.  And make no mistake, Pride and Prejudice is as much a satire of the time it was written, as it is a romantic drama.  Even today, the prose is quite funny and enjoyable.  The Enriched Classics edition is also nice because it includes footnotes explaining some of the language and/or references that were well known at the time but confusing today's readers.In summary, this is a great novel.  Admittedly, there were a few times where I thought a character's behavior was a bit over-the-top but the overall story is so riveting and the book so compelling that I just can't find any serious fault with it.  Pride and Prejudice is deserving of its reputation and I highly recommend it to Austen fans and newcomers alike.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 24, 2020
CommentsContent: My husband recommended this book to me years ago, and I finally read it as part of the #mmdchallenge2020 (a classic I never read in school). Of course, I already knew the story, but I really enjoyed the book. I like Jane Austen’s writing style and use of language, and I found certain characters (especially Mr. Bennett) to be hilarious. And I am a sucker for a good love story!

CommentsTitle: Compare today to the past, so very interesting
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 25, 2019
CommentsContent: Although an avid reader, I had never read this classic and finally decided to do so and I am so glad I did. Although the times were much different from today, it was very interesting to learn how people thought and reacted to situations in days gone  by. Every thing was so formal in those days, and it was a delight to read about it as compared to today’s way of life. I liked the book so much, I decided that I will probably read the story again because I loved the interaction between Elizabeth and Mr Darcy. Everyone should read this book, and now I know why it is considered a classic. Loved it

CommentsTitle: One of my all-time favorite classics with a fun new cover!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2010
CommentsContent: I admit I'm one of those bibliophiles who collects the different editions of favorite titles, and I could not resist this cover by artist Ruben Toledo. The book itself is a classic, and timeless in its appeal. Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is a well-written satire on the hypocrisies of Regency society as exposed through her various well-delineated characters. Mrs. Bennet is eager to marry off her five daughters - the beautiful and quiet Jane, the strong-willed Elizabeth, Mary, Kitty and flighty Lydia. So when a young man of means moves into neighboring Netherfield Park, Mrs. Bennet is determined that one of her daughters should snag the gentleman in question, Mr. Bingley. Mrs. Bennet's character is truly a caricature and an almost scathing portrayal of the society of the time - mothers desperate to see their daughters married off, especially given the Bennets' predicament - with no male heir, the family home and fortune would be entailed away from the Bennets' in the event of Mr. Bennet's death.It is also a harsh criticism of the hypocrisy and pride of the ruling classes as well-embodied in the character of Fitzwilliam Darcy, whose pride makes him look down upon the Bennets and the rest of society not equal to his own station, though of course he doesn't count upon his own traitorous feelings when he falls for Elizabeth Bennet (whose prejudice against Darcy almost blinds her to the flaws in another). The lively and almost fiery exchanges between Elizabeth and Darcy are one of the most interesting and captivating aspects of the novel. There are a host of other characters that make this novel an engrossing read - the haughty Lady Catherine de Bourgh who is hell-bent on marrying off her sickly daughter to Darcy, the comical and 'greasy' Mr. Collins who reveals his own mercenary tendencies despite being a man of the cloth, the morally bankrupt Mr. Wickham, and many others. It is a delightful tale of the battle between the social classes, and a wonderful character study. Though the language takes some getting used to (it can appear quite stilted to those unused to reading this style of writing - the flowery, stuffy sort), the story itself is compelling enough to make it a worthwhile read. In fact, having fallen in love with the novel about two decades ago, I've since re-read it countless times!As for this particular cover by Ruben Toledo, I have to say it makes for a fun interpretation of the dynamics between Elizabeth and Darcy, the novel's two main characters. Illustrated in black and white with the characters presented in silhoutte, this is a fun and inspired take on the classic which will extend this novel's appeal to a younger generation of readers. This is a novel to be savored time and again - highly recommended!

CommentsTitle: PRIDE AND PREJUDICE by Jane Austen
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 12, 2009
CommentsContent: It is beneficial at times to step away from our classics of literature, to take them down from their high pedestals and look at them without pretension. No novel, no matter how well-regarded, is universally esteemed - Twain, Emerson, and Charlotte Bronte all savaged Pride and Prejudice in print - so let us, for a few moments, stop treating it as holy writ and just look at it as a novel, at how it holds up to a modern casual reader.Pride and Prejudice (1813) is Jane Austen's novel of manners - it thoroughly explores the ins, outs and economics of nineteenth-century courtship. The novel's central character is Elizabeth Bennet, one of five daughters, whose family lives in a country village. Two wealthy, eligible bachelors move to town, and romance, confusion and animosity ensue.Austen populates her novel with all manner of flawed characters. Many of them are annoying - that is, they behave badly and are antagonistic toward the main characters - but they all show at least some depth. No one here is without flaw, but no one here is without virtue, either (except Mr. Collins, the most ludicrous of them all). And this is why the novel works: because Austen treats her characters and their social milieu gently, delicately (well, except Mr. Collins). If she had done otherwise, if she had been more cutting, she would have lost the sympathy in the reader that many of these characters engender.To the modern audience, Austen's plotting is rather sluggish, although it must be recalled that novels moved at a rather more leisurely pace then. At any rate it often seems that there is one too many side plots, or perhaps one too many visits to relatives, and there are patches that can be quite hard to get through. But you don't go to Austen for plot - you go to her for clever dialogue, for a delightful turn of phrase. That is what she thrives at, and that is what she is best remembered for. And in spite of the novel's overlength, Austen delivers a full and completely satisfying payoff. Rarely is a happy ending so fulfilling, and it may not be until the last few pages of the book that it becomes evident to the reader how masterfully Austen has set it up. And this is a large reason why the novel has such enduring appeal.Much of the nuance in Pride and Prejudice may be lost on casual modern readers. For example, the character of Mrs. Bennet is the object of great scorn from many readers, and this has only been exacerbated by the film adaptations of the novel. But while marrying for love is the norm today, then, it was not; Mrs. Bennet is the only one looking out for the Bennet family's financial future.Pride and Prejudice is, on the whole, a satisfactory and clever novel, and, at present, one whose merits are diminished mostly by readers too far removed to understand it in its fullness, or whose tastes have diverged too far.

CommentsTitle: A Must Read Book For Anyone!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 11, 2016
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is an amazing book! It is a classic that everyone needs to read. The writing, in Austen's words, is "light, bright, and sparkling," and she could not be more correct! The characters are complex, multifaceted, and well developed.  Her proper English style is something that you cannot find in today's conventional novels, and it is a lovely refresher. You feel like you are reading a sophisticated piece of classic literature without the burdens of heavy writing. You are invited to dissect and discover the plot as much as you with, but even from the surface it is a great book for anyone, from teenagers to seniors.

CommentsTitle: I can't believe how much I LOVED this book
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 27, 2009
CommentsContent:
Prior to reading Pride and Prejudice, I had seen excerpts designed to paint Jane Austen's writing as stuffy, obtuse, and generally boring. One joke says that Ms. Austen's novels are like active mysteries that engage the reader in trying to find the hidden verb in each sentence. But these criticisms are not only unfair, they're entirely inaccurate: just a few pages into Pride and Prejudice, Austen's writing style ceased being an obstacle to my enjoyment and began being a central part thereof. The manner in which she builds sentences and paragraphs is pure a delight to the modern reader, even 200 years after the fact.Austen's true accomplishment here is that she makes a novel in which "so little" happens, by modern standards at least, so darn interesting! As one critic put it, this is a 367-page story in which the central events are a man changing his manners and a lady changing her mind. But oh how the web of intrigue is weaved! The subtleties of character development and plot construction are never forced and always as natural as they are glorious. This truly is a literary triumph, and the first great novel that places women and their happiness at the center; that focuses on dialog and feelings more than swordplay and seafaring. Its interlocking characters are so rich and well-defined, unlike anything in the preceding novels on 

  
The Well-Educated Mind









  
  
    
  's reading list. And even though the story ends up exactly as you know it will from Page 1, it's still all so satisfying!Is the book pretentious? Elitist? Maybe. But consider it a study of a particular class of people during a particular point in history. That's what it is. The heroine, with whom I agree with the author when she described her to be "as delightful a creature as ever appeared in print," is bucking social conventions, but she can only do so much. She can't emancipate Woman in one fell swoop, nor is that her motivation. But Elizabeth's actions and this novel in general were one small step for Woman, at least, and an incredibly enjoyable read if nothing else. Five stars all the way!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 31, 2008
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is Jane Austen's most popular novel and it is remarkable that it has sustained such a high popularity 200 years after it was originally published. The primary plot of the story follows Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy in a highly contentious courtship that begins with mutual contempt but evolves quite unexpectedly for both into very different feelings. Subplots involve her sister Jane and Mr. Bingley in a courtship of their own as well as the romantic entanglements of various other sisters and friends. The story is a bit of a roller coaster ride with soaring hopes and crushing disappointment in store as events unfold. I won't reveal the ending for the handful of people who haven't read it but suffice to say that the novel concludes in a way that leaves the vast majority of readers well satisfied.Darcy and Elizabeth are complex and multi-layered characters who both grow and change somewhat as the book progresses. They are the heart and soul of the book and about as well fleshed out as any characters you are likely to see. The supporting characters, however, are considerably less deep and are more caricatures than anything else. Some are good and kind like Jane and Mr. Bingley, and others are ridiculous and vain like Mrs. Bennet but none are remotely as substantial as Darcy and Elizabeth. So, does this ruin the book? Hardly. These secondary characters offer a wealth of material for the author as she plays them off of Darcy and Elizabeth.This novel is almost certainly the one where Austen best displays her sharp-edged wit both through Elizabeth's dialogue and in the narrative voice describing some of these characters and their actions. If some of them were less ridiculous, the potential for the satire would be weakened considerably. And make no mistake, Pride and Prejudice is as much a satire of the time it was written, as it is a romantic drama. Even today, the prose is quite funny and enjoyable.In summary, this is a great novel. Admittedly, there were a few times where I thought a character's behavior was a bit over-the-top but the overall story is so riveting and the book so compelling that I just can't find any serious fault with it. Pride and Prejudice is deserving of its reputation and I highly recommend it to Austen fans and newcomers alike.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 8, 2019
CommentsContent: The screen shots of this version were so ridiculous, that I bought it just to be able to laugh in the future.  ("My expensive Mr. Bennet ...")Unfortunately, I got Jane Austen's version, not the teen version.I already have "the real thing," so I returned this purchase because it wasn't the awful one I'd hoped for.What a crazy world - I returned a book because it was too well-written!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2021
CommentsContent: This is a gorgeous cover for a book and im so in love with it! Brand new, has the smell of a new book and the pages are so nice and crisp!Pride and Prejudice is a favorite movie of mine; I'm finally starting it and this is a book that feels great in my hands! Can't wait to get into some more details on Mr. Darcy!!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 11, 2007
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is Jane Austen's most popular novel and it is remarkable that it has sustained such a high popularity 200 years after it was originally published. The primary plot of the story follows Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy in a highly contentious courtship that begins with mutual contempt but evolves quite unexpectedly for both into very different feelings. Subplots involve her sister Jane and Mr. Bingley in a courtship of their own as well as the romantic entanglements of various other sisters and friends. The story is a bit of a roller coaster ride with soaring hopes and crushing disappointment in store as events unfold. I won't reveal the ending for the handful of people who haven't read it but suffice to say that the novel concludes in a way that leaves the vast majority of readers well satisfied.Darcy and Elizabeth are complex and multi-layered characters who both grow and change somewhat as the book progresses. They are the heart and soul of the book and about as well fleshed out as any characters you are likely to see. The supporting characters, however, are considerably less deep and are more caricatures than anything else. Some are good and kind like Jane and Mr. Bingley, and others are ridiculous and vain like Mrs. Bennet but none are remotely as substantial as Darcy and Elizabeth. So, does this ruin the book? Hardly. These secondary characters offer a wealth of material for the author as she plays them off of Darcy and Elizabeth.This novel is almost certainly the one where Austen best displays her sharp-edged wit both through Elizabeth's dialogue and in the narrative voice describing some of these characters and their actions. If some of them were less ridiculous, the potential for the satire would be weakened considerably. And make no mistake, Pride and Prejudice is as much a satire of the time it was written, as it is a romantic drama. Even today, the prose is quite funny and enjoyable. The Enriched Classics edition is also nice because it includes footnotes explaining some of the language and/or references that were well known at the time but confusing today's readers.In summary, this is a great novel. Admittedly, there were times where I thought a character's behavior was a bit over-the-top but the overall story is so riveting and the book so compelling that I just can't find serious fault with it. Pride and Prejudice is deserving of its reputation and I highly recommend it to Austen fans and newcomers alike.
