CommentsTitle: First impressions are not always accurate
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 24, 2009
CommentsContent: The manuscript for Jane Austen's best novel, originally titled First Impressions, was rejected and returned to the author. After some revisions, the novel was published as Pride and Prejudice. It has remained one of english literature's most popular novels.  Pride and Prejudice did have its share of critics, perhaps one of the most notable of those critics was Charlotte Bronte, author of Jane Eyre, who called Austen's novel a disappointment. I wager many people would heartily disagree.Even people who have never read Pride and Prejudice have heard the names Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy. The main protagonists of the novel have become trademarks of the British Regency era. In the novel, Lizzy and Mr Darcy appear to be the epitome of opposites. Upon their first encounter, Elizabeth Bennet believes herself perfectly aquainted with Mr Darcy's character and hopes she will never find herself in his miserable presence again. The phrase "don't judge a book by its cover" aptly applies to Mr Darcy.Pride and Prejudice is one of the finest novels I have ever read. I love it not only for the romance (which is unparalleled), but also for its humor. The televised adaptations of this novel, some dating back to 1940, are excellent. The BBC version starring Colin Firth, and the 2005 movie starring Keira Knightley are amazing.  I don't think I could pick a favorite if my life depended on it. If I had to be stranded on an island with just one book, it would be Pride and Prejudice. If I could dream a fictional character to life, it would be Mr Darcy. Pride and Prejudice, an unforgettable book filled with unforgettable characters.

CommentsTitle: Only some of the best literature ever written ....
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 22, 2016
CommentsContent: Hey -- it's Jane Austen!  If you don't know the worth of her writing, 200 years later, then get into it.  Even as society, morals, mores, standards change, there are some human dynamics and types that are the same as they've ever been. Satire here is subtle and fabulous, amusing and painful, and her characters are drawn so realistically that there's no way you won't discover some of their characteristics in people you'll get to know in life. THere's also historical value -- girls and young women will thank their lucky stars to NOT be living in such a restricted, low-opportunity time as the Bennet sisters lived, and will, upon thought or because somebody will tell them, appreciate how Austen herself rose above all that and gave us the huge and beautiful gift of her mind and creativity -- and hard work.  Read Austen -- the best-selling fiction of two centuries (so far), for excellent reason.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 22, 2007
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is Jane Austen's most popular novel and it is remarkable that it has sustained such a high popularity 200 years after it was originally published.  The primary plot of the story follows Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy in a highly contentious courtship that neither wants in the beginning but both can scarcely resist by the end.  Other subplots involve her sister Jane and Mr. Bingley in a courtship of their own and the various doings of family and friends.  This novel is almost certainly the one where Austen best displays her sharp-edged wit both through Elizabeth's dialogue and in the narrative voice describing some of the characters and their actions.The two main characters are probably as well fleshed out as any you are likely to see.  They are certainly complex and multi-layered and they both grow and change somewhat as the book progresses.  The supporting characters are considerably less deep and are almost uniformly caricatures more than anything else.  Some are good and kind like Jane and Mr. Bingley, and others are ridiculous and vain like Mrs. Bennet but none are remotely as substantial as Darcy and Elizabeth.  So, does this ruin the book?  Hardly.  Pride and Prejudice is as much a satire of the time it was written as it is a romantic drama and these secondary characters are all part of the tapestry that allowed Miss Austen to skewer her contemporaries so effectively.  There are a few times where I thought a character's behavior was over-the-top but the overall story is so riveting and the book so compelling that I just can't find any serious fault with it.  Pride and Prejudice is deserving of its reputation and I highly recommend it to Austen fans and newcomers alike.

CommentsTitle: Classic book design to complement your collection!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 27, 2012
CommentsContent: This is the unabridged 1945 Hardcover (cloth) Book Club edition - which means it's just as great as it should be, since it IS Pride & Prejudice, but also that the book club-iness makes it not as valuable as it looks.  This version has full page colored pictures of the characters through-out, and has that traditional deckled edge (uneven cut pages - makes it easier to turn pages imho).The book is a cute love-story about Elizabeth Bennett and Fitzwilliam Darcy set in that classic early 1800's English period where manners and one's dictated social existence means far more than independence and general happiness.  You HAVE to take into the account the current society of the time period / location to understand the predicaments.  The story is witty, albeit wordy but still very enjoyable even after ~200+ years.THIS is the version I was looking for, hard cover, ancient looking and good quality!  Perfect for my personal PHYSICAL library!  I have the Kindle version and yes, that comes with a huge amount of spelling errors and paragraphs broken up mid-sentence.  BUT the Kindle edition is FREE a good deal of the time so you end up getting what you paid for... ;)

CommentsTitle: Worst book I've ever read in my whole life... INCREDIBLY BAD
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 21, 2019
CommentsContent: That says it all. Hundreds of books. Some wonderful. Some almost wonderful but not quite. Some not great but still worth reading. Some you wish you'd not bothered with. Some simply awful. And then there's this one. NOTHING in my lifetime matches how rotten it is! Jane Austen? NEVER AGAIN!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2001
CommentsContent: As much as I would like to, I don't reread books as a rule, even the most favorite, because life is short and there are a billion books to go before we sleep.  I do make an exception for PRIDE AND PREJUDICE however.  It is a masterpiece, a guiltless entertainment.  There are lots of laughs, some melodrama and romance which make it easy to knock back, like chocolate or a good wine.  There is, of course, much more to it, which makes it more than an indulgence.  Austen gets so much right:  she sets up a entire world and explains exactly how it works, what happens when it tips to its own excesses or when its players break its rules.  You could pitch a hardball at her window and it would bounce off, shattering nothing, that's how strong and clear it is.  She gets romantic love right, as well as all the mistakes everyone makes trying to get it right.  She spears bad behavior and holds it up on a stick.  She is very witty but never casual.  She burns up the page with truth-about her society, family interactions, human nature and the fact that no matter how civilized we become, we as a species are still at square one when it comes to managing the heart.  I see that some younger readers don't appreciate the depths this novel or its relevance for contemporary life:  maybe it's the way it is being (not) taught, but it could also be that readers have to be ready to appreciate the idea of an insular world that can bear timeless truths, and for younger adolescents, the world as yet has no edges but truth is limited to immediate circumstances.

CommentsTitle: EMMA is my favorite of Jane Austen's novels
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 24, 2017
CommentsContent: EMMA is my favorite of Jane Austen's novels, but I love this one too. It teaches the importance of looking beneath the surface. Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy both mistake the other for being worse than they truly are because they were too quick to judge each other. Both of them judge others either better or worse than they truly are based on surface relationships. And of course, the absolute ludicrous behaviors of certain characters makes this book hilarious in a cringe-worthy way.

CommentsTitle: Jane Austen's work of literary excellence.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2001
CommentsContent: I recently bought "Pride and Prejudice" for my daughter. She didn't want to read it, so I did. As I dug right into it, I realized that my daughter, being only ten years old, was probably still a little young for it anyway. In fact, it was tough enough for me...Well, at least I can admit it.It amazes me that some books, such as this one written almost 200 years ago, are filled with such style and prose. It seems that in our modern day world, with our stereos, TV's, computers and toys, that many of us unfortunately, don't seem to have the time to broaden our vocabulary, and grammatical abilities as well as some did 200 years ago. I guess,.. in some ways, we have certainly regressed in the natural progression of our intellects. Interesting ... It does make you want to read more books that were written long ago,..and broaden your mind a tad.This was an interesting book, although a little slow at times; probably because of the huge gap in our cultural differences. I can see why it could possibly be considered a bit out of sync with the world of today. The book displayed what now would be considered an imbedded chauvinistic society's way of thinking; young women sitting around all day with the most important thing on their minds being, "Who's going to come courting me today?" But, I don't think that was any of Jane Austen's fault.All in all, it was a very well organized and written story of life and mannerisms of old British Regency.

CommentsTitle: Warning: SCAM! NOT Pride and Prejudice!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 1, 2019
CommentsContent: THIS EBOOK IS A SCAM. This ebook is filled with word salad gibberish that only vaguely resembles the actual text of Pride and Prejudice. Do not buy it!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I'd seen the movie and so I wanted to read the book.  This book is smaller than usual but is a beautiful keepsake kind of thing, complete with a ribbon page holder.  Could be a great gift for a Jane Austen fan of a book collector.  The writing is atill good and remarkable after all these years.  I've read all the author's works and IMHO this is the best one.

CommentsTitle: Pink hardback: good condition minus dents and a ripped page
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2021
CommentsContent: Hardback version: Book was in good shape for the most part. Some dents that look like it had been poked several times on the front cover, can't really see it unless in direct light or sunlight. Spine was in good shape. Everything looked okay until I opened it to find that a page in the middle of the book had been ripped in half and crinkled...going to try to tape it carefully. Dissapointed since there is no return or replacement policy for it or I would ask for a refund, or a replacement with no damages at the least. Good think I've read it already and I'm only really using the book at a display now! Beautiful book!

CommentsTitle: The Watercolor pictures added greatly to the ebook experience
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 18, 2018
CommentsContent: It's one of the drawbacks of ebooks: Turning pages, feeling paper, touching cover and binding. These are missing. This is why I enjoyed this copy of Pride & Prejudice more than I expected. I wanted to have a copy of the master, Jane Austen, on my Kindle and didn't think much for the  added watercolor illustrations until I started reading. They were graphical reminders of the attire, furniture and decorations of the Regency Period of Great Britain. The pictures added depth to an already- enjoyable story.

CommentsTitle: This is a fantastic novel for anyone who loves romance!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 9, 2017
CommentsContent: This book was quite a shocker! I was reading this book for my British Literature class and was just astonished at the literary technique that Jane Austen put into this book to make it a tear-jerker! (and I do NOT cry often when reading books so this book is on my list of favorites now!)  I would highly recommend this book to anyone who has a liking for romantic/heart-wrenching novels as this one has truly made my heart race and fill with warmth due to the relaxing nature of this book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 28, 2020
CommentsContent: This is one of my favorite Jane Austen novels. It's written beautifully and is a timeless love story. Elizabeth Bennett is a lovable heroine, yet quite stubborn. It's wonderful to watch her grow and mature throughout the course of the novel. I highly suggest this book to anyone who is interested in the classics.

CommentsTitle: Reads like a newspaper, smaller print
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 14, 2020
CommentsContent: This book is is thin and the print is small. I had no issue reading it, but someone with vision problems may struggle with the print. Content wise, this is a great story. There are a lot of details in this book that are not included in any movie version I have seen thus far (and I have watched them all).  Overall, a good way to add this story to any classic collection.

CommentsTitle: A Classic Every Girl Should Read
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 14, 2011
CommentsContent: *happy sigh. I mean, really, do I need to say much more than that? I can't quite put my finger on what it is about Pride and Prejudice's happily ever after that goes above and beyond your average HEA. It could be because it has quite a few of my favorite plot devices in it. Austen certainly balances them all very well. At no point does one seem to outweigh the other. In one novel you have: a grievous assumption of character, manipulative sisters, a scandalous elopement, a dysfunctional yet mostly lovable family and the heroine who marries up.I think my favorite story arc is the same as everyone else. I love watching Elizabeth Bennet get smacked upside the head by love. I adore Darcy for not being aggressive in trying to win over Elizabeth. Instead he showed her who he could be. In one instance he wasn't guaranteed Elizabeth would ever know about his act of kindness. In fact he didn't want anyone to know. Their love story is both epic and legendary.I'll admit it took some time to understand the dialogue. Once I did, I found one of the greatest love stories ever written.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 14, 2020
CommentsContent: The book is so multifaceted. Relationships were started and stopped for outside reasons.  Love was found in unsuspecting ways. When it was written that Darcy was in the middle of being in love before he realized the start, that's how true love happens. People start out as friends and somehow somewhere down the road they realize they have fallen in love. Darcy bailed out a family from woes because of his love for Elizabeth.  Watch the movie with Keira Knightly as Elizabeth. If that doesn't make you want to read the book,sorry.

CommentsTitle: Size of text is extremely small and the cover looks grainy.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 15, 2020
CommentsContent: The story of Pride & Prejudice is, of course, lovely. What appalls me is the size of the print. The cover text and images look grainy. The quality of the book itself is normal, but I couldn’t overlook the size of the text and cover images. You have to squint to read the words, which most people find highly annoying. It’s as if reading a dictionary.

CommentsTitle: Get a microfiche - the text is around 3 point type!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 20, 2020
CommentsContent: As always, I love Amazon's service and delivery.  However, I would recommend to buy a different edition/version of this classic.  The type is so tiny that I will need both my readers and a magnifying glass - no joke.  This looks like it was meant to be read with a microfiche machine!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 21, 2019
CommentsContent: This is a beautiful book. It was worth the wait. I bought the deluxe edition with leather bi ding and couldn’t be happier with it. The pages are nice and it looks great on my bookshelf. I love this book and will read it time and time again.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 5, 2020
CommentsContent: I have finally, at the age 43, given up my prejudice against this book and have read, or at least listened to it. I like it even better than the movies, for the book can express the characters thoughts and contemplations better than a movie can.  Before ever reading or watching this work, I worried it might be frivolous at best and man-hating feminist at worst. But after seeing the film and the BBC miniseries, I chose to read it and was not disappointed in doing so. In fact, even more delighted!

CommentsTitle: Don't we all love Mr. Darcy?
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 23, 2014
CommentsContent: My absolute favorite of all of Austen's books. Because, aren't all women looking for their own Mr. Darcy? A man who displays confidence and intelligence, but is till in want of a woman to make him gentler? And Elizabeth is the perfect lively match for serious Darcy. The sisterly affection between Jane and Elizabeth is just so quaint and sweet...and steadfast. Mrs. Bennett is the perfect example of a busy body mother without much refinement who is worried about the fate of her three daughters. She brings many a groan with her brash words and emotional outbursts, but still manages to bring a smile to your face when you understand how much she loves her children and truly wants the best for them.A lovely story about misconceptions, miscommunication and a happy ending all wrapped into one. You will get lost in the beautifully woven story of life, love and family.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 3, 2017
CommentsContent: What more can one say about the contributions Austen contributed to the development of the novel.  Internal thoughts, giving rise to stream of consciousness  writing;  multiple characters sustained througout the novel;  plot development instead of letter exchnages. On the simplest level the story is so richly written that even after the surprises are over on the first reading, one wants to return to enjoy the characters.  This is true as evidenced by the continuing stream of spin offs in movies and novels.  Elizabeth Bennett would run for president if she were alive and real.

CommentsTitle: The handwriting and paper are satisfactory, and the packaging is exquisite.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 10, 2020
CommentsContent: The handwriting and paper are satisfactory, and the packaging is exquisite. The writing is also very clear, the size is moderate, the book has no peculiar smell and has the ink scent of a new book. I am very satisfied to be able to swim in the ocean of knowledge as I wish. The content in the book satisfies my thirst for knowledge and makes me feel that the power of knowledge is infinite. Through reading this book, I feel that I have gained a lot of knowledge, and reading makes me feel happy.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 19, 2012
CommentsContent: This is a classic, a favorite among my family and peers and a story that never gets old.  In a time when being proper was taught, and social standing was what you were born into somehow true love sometimes prevails.  Jane Austen, although never married, can write with the soul of a true romantic. She uses wit and twists on what was considered "normal" in her time period and made a masterpiece that lives on through the ages.  This is a love story about a girl named Elizabeth Bennet, who lives in a less than grand social stature with her sisters, her father, and her outspoken mother.  She is witty, lovable and in a word headstrong. Although she does not realize it, the love of her life, Mr. Darcy is fighting with his own sense of propriety and moral guidelines to put a halt to the love he feels for this young woman.  Engaging, with characters you love and in some cases cannot help but love to hate bring together a truly remarkable novel that will be  hard to put down,

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 23, 2015
CommentsContent: Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice is a classic novel based in the early nineteenth century that focuses on many issues at the time such as women’s roles in society and society’s unattainable standards in general. So basically, if you like petticoats and large words nobody has heard since 1832, you’ll love reading this novel in your parent’s basement with your cat as you dream of a dashing young man with a British accent whisk you away on in his horse-drawn carriage.  I’m kidding. Well, partially any way. Many high school students are assigned to read Pride and Prejudice, and the outdated language along with the early nineteenth century setting are usually a big turn off to us young-ins. Quite frankly, we’d rather watch Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen make out in the 2005 movie version. The story begins with Mrs. Bennet talking to her husband about potentially marrying off one of her daughters to a man she hasn’t even met yet. Ultimately, her goal is to marry off all five of her daughters (you would think she would have at least popped out one boy- yeesh.) to wealthy men who she doesn’t know. What a good mother. Actually, this was a typical mother’s desire of her young daughters during this time period, and ironically, Mrs. Bennet would probably been seen as a “good mother” in society’s eyes. Young women were expected to marry off to wealthy men of a high social class because obviously they couldn’t possibly take care of themselves. Oh, and if you’re poor and on the low end of the social class scale, looks like you’re screwed for life because a man with a high social class would never be seen with the likes of you! What would people say and think? After lots of meddling by the one and only Mrs. Bennet, Mr. Bingly finds himself to be quite fond of Jane, one of the five daughters. However, (as I described previously) Mr. Bingly was pretty high in terms of social class, and Jane was a bit lower than him. But don’t worry, he eventually comes to his senses and realizes that happiness is more important than what other people think. You won’t see that coming, I promise. Likewise, Miss Elizabeth Bennet’s beauty has caught the eye of handsome, wealthy, arrogant Mr. Darcy. But it won’t be until she rejects him multiple times that he starts to take notice in her. Eventually, after two marriage proposal rejections, Lizzy consents and they fall in love. They give society the big middle finger and choose happiness over standards. You won’t see that one coming either. As for the other three daughters, Lydia, Kitty, and Marry, well, their story isn’t so happily ever after- depending on how you look at it I guess. Lydia ends up marrying some rude soldier guy who turns out to be poor too. He actually married her because he thought he’d get a sweet deal out of it. Too bad she was poorer than him. They live the rest of their lives in unhappiness because they don’t actually love each other. Kitty and Marry don’t end up getting married. Perhaps they too were waiting for their night in gold-plated shining armor just like every other young woman in the early 1800’s. What they didn’t realize is that marrying someone purely for the sake of marrying them wouldn’t make them happy either, and until they realized that, they would forever be unhappy. In all honesty, I think Pride and Prejudice has a bad rap within my generation. Maybe it’s the language, or maybe it’s the setting that we just can’t get past, but I think if we really push through the surface, we would find out that Jane Austen was a pretty bad ass lady for writing this during her time, and that maybe it’s not just all about big words and petticoats. I give this novel three out of five stars. Not just because the characters are easy to make fun of, and therefore amusing to read, but mainly because Austen fearlessly published a book about how awful society’s standards were not only for women, but everyone. You go girl. But I’d still recommend the 2005 movie version- it’s way faster and the words aren’t as big.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 21, 2020
CommentsContent: The book is fine. It is an Easton Press edition, but it is a different one than is pictured. It is all red, with gold lettering, but does not have the square black accents on the spine. I am fine with keeping the book as is, but the picture should have been of the actual book being pictured, especially since it is a used item.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 29, 2016
CommentsContent: I love Jane Austen's writings. She uses words and sentence structure that are not familiar to me in my everyday life. On my kindle download of the book I can quickly look up the meanings of words I don't know. After all, the first edition was in 1813 and she was in England. The story goes forward fast enough to keep me interested and it easily takes me to another place and time by her descriptive phrases. So far in reading, I've found nothing that would make me blush or put the book aside.The book itself is average paperback quality. I bought it for my daughter's English class, so it did not have to be of high wear quality. It's what I expected in a paperback. The chapters are in Roman numerals. I find that interesting. There is about an inch of or inch and a half at the bottom where she can write her study notes. There is spacing between the chapters but the new chapters do start on the same page as the previous chapters.I like the story and the layout of the book.  I like the price of this Dover Thrift Edition.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 15, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this for my daughter who loves Jane Austen. She already has a copy of this book but fell in love with the design of the cover. If you have a reader who truly loves books, the design, the feel, everything, then this would be an awesome choice. The cover is sturdy yet elegant. Truly a book I know she will cherish for years to come.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 28, 2008
CommentsContent: A friend of mine knew that I was working my way through the classics that I didn't read in school, and got me a copy of P&P for Christmas.  Personnally I think this is one of the best works Jane Austen came out with!  It took a couple of pages for me to adjust to the antique english, but once I did, I loved immersing myself in a culture long gone.  Once or twice I even caused my husband's brows to raise when I accidentally answered him in Olde English!  Austen gives just enough detail (thankfully not enough to bore you), allows her main characters to be fallible, and whisks you off into a tale that is wonderfully wrapped up at the very end.  None of that here's-the-last-page-sorry-you-still-have-questions nonsense (fine for a series, but definately not a stand-alone)!  If you too are looking for an extremely well-written, entertaining classic with a happy ending, don't let all the collegiate level stuff scare you!  Give yourself a chance to get used to the old phrases, and give P&P a chance!A.L. TravisAuthor of The Pillar of Light: The Legends of Milana Series[..]

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 29, 2019
CommentsContent: This was awful.  I can only think it was translated from some other language back into English.I tried to read it and it made no sense whatsoever.  I couldn’t believe I actually bought it.I ended up reading the free kindle unlimited version.I actually give it no stars, but it made me give it at least one star.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 30, 2020
CommentsContent: This was an abomination in printing!  The print is microscopic and it’s laid out with 3 columns per page !  To explain how small the print is the total number of pages in this unabridged text is only 67 pages!  This should be a 300-400 page book! Unbelievable!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 16, 2018
CommentsContent: I never read this in high school like so many others might have but I think not having been forced to read it drastically improved my opinion on the subject. I truly enjoyed this book, it was a little difficult at first to adjust to the vocabulary but I adapted. I did not like however how this version was formated for kindle. Every other page was blank except for the page number and the line spacing was inconsistent. Naturally I tried adjusting the settings but with little success.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2016
CommentsContent: Classic and must read for everyone!  Jane Austen is one of my favorites.  The stories are long and slow, but Jane has such a good style of writing.  I don't like to write too much in book reviews because I feel that in order to adequately write a review, I would have to give away information that would be key to plot. I don't like to be the person to give away spoilers. Therefore my book reviews are always very short and only say a few things in order to tell you, book reviews are much to subjective and I never read a book review before I read a book. I read a book based on what the book is about which I don't read a review to get. If you want more information, buy the book and read it. :)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 17, 2014
CommentsContent: This with good cause is the most popular and well-beloved novel written by a clever and insightful author. Each character is well defined and developed without resorting to stereotyping. Indeed they are so believable they seem to walk off the pages and into one's living room. One thing I treasure about this author is her insight into human nature and the gentle irony with which she treats the foibles and idiosyncrasies of her characters. She is sympathetic with her characters, treating even the most undeserving cad in a way that hopes for improvement. It is also a pleasure to retreat from the coarse language and dark outlook that plagues so many novels into pages where language is skillfully manipulated to express the full range of human emotion and experience. It takes a bit of effort to fall into the language of this era-a new reader would be well advised to procure and watch the excellent video created by PBS.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 24, 2011
CommentsContent: As I find with most "classics" this novel took some time to completely capture my interest. Once it did, however, I was completely enchanted. Our 21st century need for speed and immediate gratification takes a backseat as we move with Jane Austen through the every day lives and loves of her characters. The slow but steady pace of the novel allows the time to actually get to know and connect with the characters. Austen brings you fully into her world of 19th century England: with no difficulty you can feel the joys and sorrows, happiness and tribulations of the Bennet sisters and especially Elizabeth and Jane.Classic themes: scheming mothers, class distinctions, vanity, pride,false assumptions and misunderstandings abound...until by the novel's conclusion I could not help but find myself rooting for Elizabeth and Darcy.I thoroughly recommend this to anyone who loves classics and doesn't mind the slow pace that generally characterizes them.

CommentsTitle: One of my favorite books, now in a beautiful hardcover
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 7, 2014
CommentsContent: One of my favorite books, now in a beautiful hardcover.  It also has a connected ribbon bookmark, so now I don't have to worry about it falling out when people flip through it.I was never into reading when I was a child.  Okay, I absolutely loathed it.  It turns out that I just didn't like to be forced to read horribly dull books only to have to write an essay or take a test on it later.  After I hit my twenties, I decided to give reading a second try with this book.  It is truly a page turner, even reading it for the 3rd time.  The characters are relatable and lovable.  Austen also doesn't bore with impertinent details.  I absolutely recommend this book, even if you think you hate to read.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 9, 2006
CommentsContent: It is, to put it simply, unequalled.  Not many books come as close to perfection as this one does.  Flawless prose, crackling wit, good drama, fully developed characters and a perfect plotline make this the best novel in the English language.  You may argue with me if you wish, there is no other book that satisfies like this one.  Jane Austen was a woman for all time and she was a genius in every sense of the word.  She understood people.  We are blessed to have with us this remarkable work.  How did she pull it all off so beautifully?I do not write much because I think that you, dear reader, should get your hands on this one pronto and stop reading this brief, rather trite review that does not come anywhere close to revealing Ms. Austen's creativity.  I have returned to Longbourne, Netherfield and Pemberley several times in my life and will continue to do so.  If I have the good fortune to meet Ms. Austen in the after-life, I hope that she will give me an autograph.  Or at the very least, give me a nod in my direction.

CommentsTitle: A fun look back into life in Englad
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 22, 2019
CommentsContent: I read this at the same time I was watching the PBS series.  It was remarkable how exact the dialogue was in the movie version.  It was stimulating to read the descriptions and beautiful use of the English language. We have given up the ability to really exchange thoughts and feelings with words in conversation as in these books.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 7, 2017
CommentsContent: Incredibly sloppy Kindle edition riddiled with word break hyphenations and--worse--em dashes!!!!Austin most definitely did not write with em dashes. Sacrilege to add them to the original text. Do not waste your money here.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 19, 2014
CommentsContent: I first read pride and prejudice in high school by necessity, and I just didn't get what all the fuss was about. I thought it was hopelessly dull, thought the characters'actions and beliefs were archaic and not relatable, and I definitely skimmed most of the second half of the book.This experience couldn't have been more different! I finally understood and appreciated the subtle sense of humor with which Jane Austen writes, and I actually found myself laughing out loud often. The relationships between the characters were so clear and so entertaining that I found myself wishing for certain conversations to occur just so I could hear more. Far from stuffy and inane their concerns were human and emotional. So glad I read this again!

CommentsTitle: Better than the movie. Of course.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2016
CommentsContent: Unfortunately, I watched the movie first. I had a hard time shaking those impressions in order to form my own honest ones for the first several chapters. I could see nothing but the actors' faces and the glorious set of the most recent and popular Hollywood rendition of this story. I felt cheated of the joy that imagination gives; that can only be got at by reading. I was anxious that the rapture I had felt (and still do) over the movie all those years ago could not be superseded this time by the book. This was unfounded, thankfully. I have a feeling I will be back to visit these characters frequently by book just as surely as I have had the pleasure of their company by movie.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 10, 2021
CommentsContent:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.










  
  
    
   The book came wrapped up, protected with bubbles, and in a box instead of an envelope, so they appear to have corrected the shipping issues that were mentioned in previous reviews. However, mine came printed completely backwards. To read it, I have to hold the book upside down. It's still Pride and Prejudice, so I'm still going to keep it. But if it had been a gift, I would have been very disappointed. I'm looking forward to reading it in public so I can make people wonder about the crazy lady reading a book upside down.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 3, 2014
CommentsContent: I had seen and loved the movie, so I finally got around to reading the book. This is the free Kindle version, so I'm not 100% sure it's completely original. The text was very annoying, it seemed like there was a capitilized word at least three times per page. I didn't think it was necessary as the readers can tell when emphasis is being placed on a certain word without being in caps. The annoying text did not alter the fact that this is an excellent book. It's a wonderful look back in history and the characters are charming and likable. I just love the love between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy, one of the all time classic loves. I'm glad I finally got around to reading this. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys historical period books or great love stories.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 21, 2015
CommentsContent: The BBC movie (1995) of Pride & Prejudice follows this book real close.  I loved the book but, of course, I love the BBC series a lot better because it put actual images in your mind and gave you an idea what Mr. Darcy (oh my God) looked like and Lizzy and all the other characters.  I cannot imagine having lived during that time.  There are quite of other books out that can be bought on Amazon pertaining to Mr. Darcy and Lizzy. Also, one book 'Return to Longbourn' is after Mr. Bennett dies and what happens.  I have read some and everytime I do the image of Mr. Darcy (Colin Firth) and Lizzy (Jennifer Ehle) comes to mind.  I am sure that just about everyone has read Pride & Prejudice. Loved it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 25, 2004
CommentsContent: Jane Austen obviously chose the titles to her novels with care, for this book truly is about pride and prejudice, explored through the eyes of the book's main character: Elizabeth Bennett, as well as the rest of the Bennett family, Elizabeth's best friend Charlotte and the upper crust families with which they rub shoulders.Set in the England of King George III, "Pride" details Elizabeth's coming of age and her exploration of her own romantic nature. As the second eldest of five daughters, and most beloved of her father, Elizabeth is used to being the quickest wit around, and fancies herself an expert of human nature. When Elizabeth finds herself sought after by several men, consecutively, she finds perhaps she isn't quite the expert she'd believed herself to be.Austen is a master of character study, and "Pride" is certainly no exception, being the finest example of her work. While a romance novel in earnest, Austen never hesitates to ruffles feathers with her quick wit.Characters such as Lady Catherine de Bourgh, Mr. Collins, and Lucas family and, of course, all the Bingleys, provide an excellent assortment of personalities and conflict that Elizabeth must navigate in order to remain true to her nature and find her position in English society of the time.Herself the daughter of a clergyman, Austen was no stranger to the lifestyle of which she wrote, and "Pride" provides excellent insight into her time.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 30, 2015
CommentsContent: I have read this book more than one hundred times from age eleven until my present age of seventy years. I never tire of it. The interpersonal dynamics depicted by Austen are timeless and brilliantly perceptive. Society has its claims upon us all, no matter how trying. This satire has helped me survive the many unpleasant but necessary associations which are required by simply being a human being. Sadly, I have come to the conclusion that I , in my dotage , resemble Mrs Bennett far more than I would care to admit. Fortunately, I also feel akin to Mr Bennett, so my life has not been a total loss. It's wonderful to have such a book in one's life. Amusement is to be had for readers of all ages.

CommentsTitle: Beautiful edition! Be cautious of sticker.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 28, 2020
CommentsContent: Truly beautiful books. These cloth bound editions are a modern, yet timeless approach to the classics. They’re dynamic and feel expensive.My only complaint is that the sticker on the back of the book peels off the design on the book cover if you try to remove it. It’s easy to peel, but does damage the book. I got several different books in this series and it happened each time.

CommentsTitle: An eloquently written novel that stirred my heart.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2020
CommentsContent: I will be honest. This isn't my typical type of reading. After watching the movie I couldn't get enough. I purchased the book and couldn't put it down. I'm completely hooked and look forward to reading more of Jane Austen's work.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 25, 2020
CommentsContent: The story is of course a classic. For all those that have seen the movie(s) it is still worth reading the book. It details so much better the process that lead each character from one feeling to another. The editing of this copy of Pride and Prejudice isn’t perfect but it doesn’t ruin the story.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 24, 2019
CommentsContent: Beautiful.  Only complaint is the cover is pink and the ribbon bookmark is red- those colors clash.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Book received in perfect condition! Happy to finally own a book for a story I've loved for years.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 31, 2019
CommentsContent: The story is a classic and very entertaining.  The only thing I did not like of this Kindle version is that you could not select chapters.  You had to scroll to the chapter you want to go to.  I have an audible version of the book and like to read along.  I like to skip around the book and you cannot do this with this version of the book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 2, 2019
CommentsContent: It’s ok

CommentsTitle: Another great novel by Jane Austen
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 8, 2020
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is another great novel by Jane Austin.  The witty banter juxtaposed to the constant manipulation through layers of civility required in “proper society” give a humorous view of an otherwise stilted group of people

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I’ve loved this book since I was a young bookworm, enamored with Mr. Darcy. It feels like it’s dragging on in the middle of the book, for about 30% of the book, but it picks up again and quickly resumes the suspension and hilarity of the Bennett affairs.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 7, 2008
CommentsContent: I don't know how it came about that - after avoiding it in high school and watching two movie versions of it - I found myself reading PRIDE AND PREJUDICE. I didn't think that the book would be able to much surprise me. But, my goodness, this book is one of the most delightful, compellingly readable pieces of fiction I have ever found. And, oddly enough, knowing the story through the movies made the surprises that the book has to offer all the more valuable.The language Austen uses is fantastic. The book is charming and very funny. The characters are all fully developed and funny, from the annoying Mrs. Bennet to the startling, judgmental Mr. Collins. And the romance is wonderful.Elizabeth Bennet and Fitzwilliam Darcy are great characters, and I'm glad to finally be acquainted with them in their original form.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 7, 2019
CommentsContent: I have read this book numerous times and it has always been a favorite of mine. I am currently teaching this book to my 11/12 grade class. Even though some of the language isn't what they are used to, they are enjoying the novel as well. If you haven't read this classic yet, please do!The highlight feature in the Kindle app adds a great touch while writing a paper on the novel!

CommentsTitle: Timeless, charming, endearing, captivating, cheeky, snarky . . .
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 10, 2016
CommentsContent: What can I say that hasn't already been said except, this is a must read book before you leave this earth. The story crosses all generations, proving itself to be a timeless testament to the intricate workings of the human personality and all of its virtues and vices. You'll fall in love with Elizabeth. You'll want to give Mrs. Bennet a Xanax and Mr. Bennet a free pass. And you'll be sure to love to hate to love Mr. Darcy.Jane Austen has given us so many wonderful lines to ponder, savor and remember, therefore I will read this more than once.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 24, 2020
CommentsContent: Bought a hard cover thinking that the font will be bigger than the mass paperback. However the book is tiny, paper is thin and the font is small! It is an aesthetically appealing book but not practical for a student to annotate/highlight.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2004
CommentsContent: A mother's driving force is getting her five daughters married quickly; it hardly matters to whom. A suitor proposes, is summarily rejected and marries someone else within days. A woman doesn't like men but wants to get married anyway. A sixteen-year-old runs off with a man and doesn't marry him right away, much to the chagrin of both her parents and sisters. A mother has no use for her daughter's suitor but happily accepts him into the family because he is wealthy. The less money a family has, the more important it is that all their daughters marry and quickly. If the family lives in the country, they must work harder to get these daughters married.  Sound like your favorite sitcom and/or your favorite cousin and her family? Well, it's Jane Austin's timeless PRIDE AND PREJUDICE. I recently reread this comedy of manners that I hadn't read since high school. Here we have much ado about getting the daughters married. Even though we in the U. S. have lived through the 60's and the "Women's Movement," sixty percent of law students now are women, and many things have changed about the way young women are brought up and what they do with their lives, I still saw a lot of families I know here. Everything changes; yet everything remains the same.Everybody points out what is so unique about this novel as well as the rest of Austin's works. She does very little to place them in any given time. They are quite wonderful in what they don't tell us. Austin doesn't give us a lot of specificity about a lot of things. For example, The Bennetts are always entertaining yet we don't know much about what they eat other than "venison" or "meat." While people often "color" when they blush, the only color named in the entire novel is blue; Wickham may wear a blue coat when he gets married. The young women often play music but we are never told the names of the pieces they play. We do know that Elizabeth plays rather badly. I kept thinking that these young girls have too much free time on their hands. They need more hobbies or part-time jobs. Of course young women of a certain station in Austin's day didn't work. The ironic first line of the novel is well-known: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife." With that great opener, we are off and running.Parts of this novel will make you smile; others will make your laugh. My favorite character is the father, Mr. Bennett, who is quick to see and point out his wife's and others' foibles but never sees his own.

CommentsTitle: Earns its place as a classic
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 9, 2014
CommentsContent: Among the most famous love stories ever written, second only to Romeo and Juliet, this classic piece of english literature earns every accoclade it has.  Jane Austen's scathing wit keeps virtually every scene interesting and the dialogue between the characters, especially the two leads, stand as her finest writing achievement in her illustrious, if sadly brief, career.The book is in many ways a critique of both the qualities of the landed gentry and their shortcomings.  Austen recognizes all the virtues of gentlemanly conduct, civility towards neighbors, and still manages to level scathing criticisms of at the mercenary character of some individuals and the vanity of others.This book is remembered as a classic love story, and I would argue one of the key reasons is that as the two lead characters are developed, alongside their relationship, they both become better people.  Darcy's interaction with Elizabeth awaken a more civil manner in his treatment of people with lower social connections, while Elizabeth sheds some of her own prejudices as she learns more about Darcy's generous nature.  The civility of both is improved.It is, in my mind, the 'Casablanca' of classic literature.  I have found many classics to be difficult to read, but Pride and Prejudice was engaging, both for its excellent characters, intriguing stroy, and especially, its social critiques.

CommentsTitle: Beautiful edition of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 13, 2018
CommentsContent:
This edition of Jane Austen's classic novel "Pride and Prejudice" is simply gorgeous with all these tiny golden and white details and decorations on the cover. The only small problem is that there are small stains on the outside of the book (kind of like blue ink, see pictures 4-7) but since the book was new and sealed I suppose that it might be a manufacturing error. Apart from that I just absolutely love these Barnes and Noble Collectible Editions and was so glad to find this book at such a reasonable price. I would absolutely recommend these books to everyone on the search for beautiful books that aren't too expensive.

  
Pride and Prejudice

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 13, 2018
CommentsContent: I bought this book a while back and finally got a chance to pick up a read, BUT I have to say I am disappointed. There are way too many misspellings, ie. words being meshed together. I understand mistakes happen, but this is just way too many. It is extremely distracting, and makes reading the book no fun! I really wanted to love this.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2019
CommentsContent: Fuzzy cover letters and overall quality not worth the $16+ I paid for. And I missed my return opportunity. Collectors, not one to add to your collectiom for sure.

CommentsTitle: Loved the book, loved the movie
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 29, 2009
CommentsContent: OK, so I'm a big fan of British actor Colin Firth. Especially so after seeing his BBC movie "Pride and Prejudice" (or maybe it was the other way around). Anyway I loved that movie. I watched it so many times it made me want to read the book. I bought a hard copy edition but never took time to read it, just kept watching that movie. Kindle had a free edition, I said what the heck and I loaded it. Knowing the story already, I delved into the book. Happy was I to see that the movie was almost totally in sync with the book! I absolutely love the story. The "prejudiced" Lizzy reluctantly falling in love with the "proud" Darcy, and the Darcy who had too much Pride to get over his Prejudice towards her "lowly connections."I will read it again definitely; it's got to be my favorite book, especially in the classics.

CommentsTitle: Good rendition of Jane Austen's masterpiece
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 10, 2008
CommentsContent:
Pride and Prejudice has long been my favorite, and most read, book, so I am completely familiar with the text.  I consider it to be the greatest romance ever written and Jane Austen's wry sense of humor shines.With the caveat that I haven't heard other audio versions of P&P, I thought that Josephine Bailey did a creditable job of reading this classic.  Her male voices were less than convincing but P&P mostly has female dialog and those voices were fine.  Her narrative voice, flow, and pace were excellent.A technical note:  This Tantor eBook CD includes an MP3 version of the audio book as well as the entire text in Adobe PDF format, so that one can follow the text while listening.  It totals about 628 MB in size, nearly all of which is the MP3 audio book.  However, the written PDF text on my disc includes a duplicate of Chapter 33, listed as "Chapter 34".  After that, the remaining chapters are off by one number.  Nevertheless, the entire written text is present and this flaw is not found in the MP3 audio book, where the chapters are entirely correct.Because of this technical mistake in the PDF text, I gave this eBook only four stars.  But for an enjoyable audio version of Jane Austen's masterpiece, this disc is a fine purchase.I'd like to put in a plug for what I consider the best screen adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, the 1996 BBC/A&E version:

  
Pride and Prejudice [Blu-ray









  
  
    
  ]

  
Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E, 1996)









  
  
    
  

  
Pride and Prejudice (10th Anniversary Collector's Set) (A&E, 1996)









  
  
    
  If there are any fans of P&P who haven't already seen this excellent screen version of the novel, I would highly recommend doing so.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 19, 2020
CommentsContent: Beautiful love story about a strong woman .  Back in times when women were not allowed to be strong.  She was brave, determined, and not afraid to give her opinion.  Really enjoyed this book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 7, 2018
CommentsContent: Great book, just as good this time as when I first read it in HS. I've always loved the BBC film (series) from 1995 with Colin Firth, Jennifer Ehle, Crispin Bonham-Carter, et al,  but until I reread P&P I didn't realize how closely that production follows the book. At any rate that film spoiled me for any other version. I try to watch them, but they just don't hold a candle.

CommentsTitle: Sad version of the Peacock Edition
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 5, 2017
CommentsContent: This is what I consider to be one of the best novels ever written.  I collect copies of it.  I was excited when they released the new Peacock edition, since the originals are collectible and very expensive.  But I was very dissapointed.  It's paperback only, not hardcover.  And the design is only on the front, not the spine or back.  So sitting on the shelf, it just looks like a cheap paperback with a plain black spine.  Sad.

CommentsTitle: Great Quality for a Great Classic
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2020
CommentsContent: The book arrived quickly and in good shape. The cover and the pages have no folds, crumples, marks, or tears. It feels and smells just like an untouched book! All the words are readable and the pages are perfectly dry.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2019
CommentsContent: This edition is beautiful but either it was used before or was damaged on the way to delivery. The book seems to me to be used and since I bought it as a NEW I don't think it's fair. It has some signs that was used, it had a stain on the back cover that I was able to clean and it also has a little damage on the cover. I'm a perfectionist with my books, I look at all their details, and despite those details that made me a little upset, I loved this edition, it’s very beautiful.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 10, 2020
CommentsContent: I enjoyed the story, and it gave a glimpse of what life was like during the 1800s. The sentence structure and some vocabulary are unfamiliar, and it takes a little while to get used to adapting to the differences.

CommentsTitle: Pride and Prejudice with illustrations by Hugh Thomson
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 6, 2015
CommentsContent: This is a good ebook version of Austen's "Pride and Prejudice". I am surprised it doesn't have more reviews by now. It includes an introduction by John Bailey and the Hugh Thomson illustrations.Hugh Thomson's work is elegant and sharp and befitting the style of Austen's work. Especially in Pride and Prejudice. When the novel is more somber, his choice of scenes can get a bit awkward. But for some reason I do not understand, kindle Austen ebooks contain illustrations by Brock. Now, I am not one to speak of taste, though in truth I do not like the Brock ones, but the amount of illustrated editions and the sparsity of Hugh Thomson ones was alarming.Why bother? When I looked into it I was a new owner of a kindle paperwhite. P&P is one of my favourite books and my favourite reading copy the one by Collector's Library. A small hardcover with the illustrations by Hugh Thomson... I wanted a kindle copy that would smooth out the difference. It turned out quite a difficult task... Till I found this one...!For anyone interested, there are currently two more options. The one by Defoe and Poe and the one by Dover. When I made the purchase, there were only this one and the one by Defoe and Poe. The other one did not include all the scenes. This one does! I do wish they looked sharper on my kindle paperwhite... They look a bit vague. But at least there are all of them here...And the one by Dover? Well, the kindle version was not available then. But I already own the Dover 1894 facsimile hardback... Wonderful! The cover is unassuming, it's a pity they didn't go for the 1894 cover, but within? Simply gorgeous!Ok, info time. The first Hugh Thomson edition of Pride and Prejudice was published in 1894. It included line drawings of scenes of the book. But it also had several small... em... decorating details throughout. Like the headings in every chapter and the illustrated version of the first letter of every chapter. (that is going to be awkward in ebook!). The standard, when an edition claims to have the Hugh Thomson illustrations, is to include only the scenes but ALL the scenes. Dover makes the exception of publishing the 1894 facsimile, which means everything...! Still a little bit bulky for a reading copy. But beautiful within...That's it. Happy choosing! And do not forget Pride and Prejudice itself! Elegant yet sharp, light yet socially ironic, don't miss it!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2012
CommentsContent: The book was a great read- I hardly put it down for the 4 days I spent reading it.  It does differ from the movie in that Mr. Darcy really was haughty and prideful in the beginning instead of merely misunderstood, and Elizabeth Bennett was prejudiced, but both of course reconciled and became better people for each others' accusations.  Also, there were a couple additional characters and some of the dialogue was switched between characters, which made more sense than even in the more recent version of the film.  There was one notation at the closing of every (mailed) letter that I did not understand, but otherwise did not see many mistakes that would not have been in the original manuscript as other reviews reported.  I thoroughly enjoyed the book.

CommentsTitle: I can't believe how much I loved this book.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 1, 2012
CommentsContent: I'm slightly embarrassed to say that it took me this long to get around to reading Pride & Prejudice. I don't like romance novels and I'm generally wary of anything that is too popular. And yet here I am, giving P&P one of the few 5-star ratings I've ever bestowed. Jane Austen is, without a doubt, among the wittiest, cleverest, most talented authors I've ever read. I laughed out loud repeatedly, thoroughly enjoyed many of the characters (the protagonists were refreshingly frank and the stupid ones were delightfully annoying), and don't you tell anyone but I had tears in my eyes when Darcy and Elizabeth finally sorted things out. I'll be thinking about this book for a long time, and I imagine that I'll be delving into Austen's other books in short order.

CommentsTitle: Great book, poor Kindle format, but good reading!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 4, 2011
CommentsContent: I just finished reading the book about half an hour ago. I read it in almost two weeks, since the complexity of my life's schedule did not let me finish it in less time. Let me assure you that it is a good title, and I look forward to reading more on Jane Austen. I enjoyed the reading so much in my Kindle that one day was reading at the University, waiting for some Registration assistance, and I began laughing on the occurrences of Lady de Bourgh at Longbourn.I gave this title a 4 star review since some formatting problems on the Kindle edition; including capital letters where there was no need, word and line spacing, and not coming with a list of the Chapters to be read.Although I found these errors sometimes annoying, I enjoyed quite much the experience of reading this ebook, since I never thought I would enjoy an 1800's title.Enjoy your reading!

CommentsTitle: but it bored me to tears
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 13, 2018
CommentsContent: I know it's a classic, but it bored me to tears!  It's tough getting used to her writing style and the story wasn't engaging enough for me. Sorry, I wish I loved it, but NOT SO MUCH!

CommentsTitle: Great.  It is what I expected
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 27, 2020
CommentsContent: Great book.  Enjoyed reading it after having read it many years ago.  Forgot that there were  some conclusions to each person's lives that you don't see in the movie versions.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 11, 2017
CommentsContent: Wonderful look at a world long gone - it's difficult to grasp, in view of today's lack of manners and decorum, that there was once a time when people were polite, civil to each other, and, for the most part, educated.But the most amazing thing of all, to me, is that writers of that time - indeed util the advent of the typewriter and the computer - wrote these long novels by hand - pen and ink!!  How on earth did they - could they - make corrections and additions!

CommentsTitle: Because I wanted to know the whole story
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 13, 2018
CommentsContent: It was hard, deciding on 4 or 5 stars. I already knew the story, the players, the outcome, but I wanted to know the details too. Though I am a voracious reader, I've become spoiled by contemporary writing styles. Fast paced and with little depth or description, Jane's style requires one to slow down the pace to catch all the information and description. There were several places where I had to re-read passages because I forgot what she was trying to relate, but that is common in most older books. If the story wasn't so well known and cherished, it would rate a 4 star for a sometimes ponderous pace, but past the 50% mark, the story practically leaks the page.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 3, 2007
CommentsContent: This is a love story that is slow developing, at least for Elizabeth Bennett. Because she is prejudice of Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy, she cannot see his fascination with her, nor can she see his true disposistion, which is delightfully uncovered over time. His fascination stems from her lack of desire to cater to his apparant haughtiness. She mistakes his shyness for rudeness and his disdainment for silliness as resentment towards others.And we musn't forget dear Mrs. Jane. Her love for Mr. Bently and his for her, make this book even more enthralling, especially as it all unfolds.Mrs. Bingly is a vital character in this book as well, as she covers jealousy, treachery to certain extent, caniving, and even back-stabbing. Of course she wants Mr. Darcy for herself.Jane Austen created memorable characters that each become a major part of this story! From her Father, Mr. Bennett, to the rediculous Mr. Collins and from Mrs. Bennett to the very silly Lydia. She even goes into detail about how things end up for the characters she created, at the end of the book! Great writing!This story also is an awesome detail of what it was like in the 1700's for families and women. Jane did not deal with the political side of life in this book. Some reviews from famous author's were disappointed that the book did not contain any information about what the men did for a living, but that was not Jane's intention. It didn't matter what they did for a living. They "went to town on business" was enough information. You come to understand that women didn't marry for love much, as in the case of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett. It was a convenience to be married for many. It also showed how important it was for families to have sons.I highly recommend this book, and the movie. You will not be disappointed. It is a great read, over and over.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2019
CommentsContent: I was prejudiced that this would be a silly, childish and boring narrative without value of any sort. I am proud to say that  I found my prejudices to be totally unfounded. This is a serious, mature and provocative tale reflecting the hierarchy of high society in the 1770's. I found this to be quite entertaining and informative.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 7, 2020
CommentsContent: I ordered the "penguin classics" version of this book, but when it arrived, the cover looked like a knock-off version and the paper quality was different. This is the third time I've ordered a book from amazon and it is not "real". I haven't started reading this one yet, but in another fake penguin classic, multiple sections of the book appeared doubled probably due to lazy copying. wouldn't recommend.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 29, 2017
CommentsContent: This is my fourth copy of the book. I can't get enough of it. I've always loved this novel, even when I was introduced to it at 13 by means of the most recent movie transcript posted in a magazine meant for middle schoolers. I always picture Lizzie with keirha knightly, who I always saw do the character justice. As a gamer, I see Wickham's name as wiggums because he is just as silly as the name. Though the demon possessed cat would probably disagree.I digress, this book is one of my absolute favorites. Jane Austen was a very capable writer and continues to be successful. I always love returning to this book and forever will.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 7, 2020
CommentsContent: Beautiful book, perfect size, great font... absolutely love it. And the ribbon book mark! And of course, P&P is a wonderful work of literature.Most normal people probably don’t read in the bath like me, but be aware any moisture will cause the transfers to come RIGHT off.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 9, 2019
CommentsContent: Need I say more. The format of this Kindle version sucks but I it in paperback too. If you are reading the variations but haven't read the original you are missing out. Read all of Jane Austen's books please, preferably the paperbacks.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 13, 2014
CommentsContent: I've read Pride and Prejudice several times and it's one of my favorite novels.This edition is a must-have for P&P lovers. Personally, I'm out to collect beautiful copies of this book, so that's the sole reason I bought this. If you love the book or know someone who does, this would make a great gift.The Penguin Drop-Cap series is really lovely - the cover design is gorgeous and even the edges of the pages are dyed to give it a unique touch. The book is sturdy so you can definitely read it - but mine will remain on the shelf in a place of honor!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 9, 2018
CommentsContent: English literature from the great authors of the 1700-1800s just has a style and depth to it i don't believe our contemporary culture has the ability of duplicating.  This is my first Jane Austen book. The writing style was beautiful and at times challenging (in a good way), as were the ideas expressed throughout the book. I also gained greater insight into nobility culture of the time period.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2020
CommentsContent: Love love love! This book is gorgeous! The cover and design are beautiful and smooth the flower pattern is raised and shimmery. It feels good too. Feels a little fragile but other than that I would recommend this to anyone.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 15, 2020
CommentsContent: A truly beautiful edition but they are far too delicate and not worth the money. I have taken them off my shelves 3 times since I’ve owned them and the front and back covers are breaking apart. Very disappointed.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 12, 2019
CommentsContent: My second reading of this book was more enjoyable than the first time. Miss Austin had a remarkable talent for writing. I think her books will be treasured four a very long time. I would recommend this book and her other books to anyone who wants a well writtenAnd a romantic.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 1, 2020
CommentsContent: If you want to read this i recommend getting a regular copy bc i wouldn’t want to ruin this book and this is a great story!! I got this copy just as decor and it’s beautiful and came in good condition!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 20, 2021
CommentsContent: The actual book itself came in great condition and very quickly. I was worried that the font would be to small for me to read but it’s perfect. Not too small, not to big. The story of the book is great. I am in 8th grade and so far I have only had a little bit of trouble with the grammar while reading the book. Definitely recommend getting this book!!!

CommentsTitle: PRIDE AND PREJUDICE by Jane Austen
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 12, 2009
CommentsContent: It is beneficial at times to step away from our classics of literature, to take them down from their high pedestals and look at them without pretension. No novel, no matter how well-regarded, is universally esteemed - Twain, Emerson, and Charlotte Bronte all savaged Pride and Prejudice in print - so let us, for a few moments, stop treating it as holy writ and just look at it as a novel, at how it holds up to a modern casual reader.Pride and Prejudice (1813) is Jane Austen's novel of manners - it thoroughly explores the ins, outs and economics of nineteenth-century courtship. The novel's central character is Elizabeth Bennet, one of five daughters, whose family lives in a country village. Two wealthy, eligible bachelors move to town, and romance, confusion and animosity ensue.Austen populates her novel with all manner of flawed characters. Many of them are annoying - that is, they behave badly and are antagonistic toward the main characters - but they all show at least some depth. No one here is without flaw, but no one here is without virtue, either (except Mr. Collins, the most ludicrous of them all). And this is why the novel works: because Austen treats her characters and their social milieu gently, delicately (well, except Mr. Collins). If she had done otherwise, if she had been more cutting, she would have lost the sympathy in the reader that many of these characters engender.To the modern audience, Austen's plotting is rather sluggish, although it must be recalled that novels moved at a rather more leisurely pace then. At any rate it often seems that there is one too many side plots, or perhaps one too many visits to relatives, and there are patches that can be quite hard to get through. But you don't go to Austen for plot - you go to her for clever dialogue, for a delightful turn of phrase. That is what she thrives at, and that is what she is best remembered for. And in spite of the novel's overlength, Austen delivers a full and completely satisfying payoff. Rarely is a happy ending so fulfilling, and it may not be until the last few pages of the book that it becomes evident to the reader how masterfully Austen has set it up. And this is a large reason why the novel has such enduring appeal.Much of the nuance in Pride and Prejudice may be lost on casual modern readers. For example, the character of Mrs. Bennet is the object of great scorn from many readers, and this has only been exacerbated by the film adaptations of the novel. But while marrying for love is the norm today, then, it was not; Mrs. Bennet is the only one looking out for the Bennet family's financial future.Pride and Prejudice is, on the whole, a satisfactory and clever novel, and, at present, one whose merits are diminished mostly by readers too far removed to understand it in its fullness, or whose tastes have diverged too far.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 18, 2014
CommentsContent: I have read this book several times.  Jane Austen is a master of language and a genius at understanding and describing her society.  The characters are individuals and completely formed with all the individuality of a real person.  Each character could be a real person.  The development of the book and characters are riveting.  Jane Austen stands at the top of the list even though at the time she wrote she had to publish under a male name.  Since its first publication it has never been out of pring.  Lose yourself in a different time and culture as it comes to life of the pen of the indomitable Jane Austen.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2020
CommentsContent: Recommended reading. Fills in the missing details nicely from the movie. Renders the follow up movie, Death Comes to Pemberly insipid though.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2013
CommentsContent: One of the wittiest authors of the English language presents THE classic story best exposing the concerns of intelligent, lively young women of marrying age, as seen thru a perspective of a British environment near the close of the 18th century. Since this original has an adept use of humor, philosophy and language raising it beyond the definition of a mere romance, many inferior romance novels have copied some of the elegant plot devices over the years. It wears well over time and many readings and may be listed as the favorite novel of more women than any other. The main character, Elizabeth, is certainly a favorite among women.
