CommentsTitle: A Kindle Classic which is definitely classic!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 25, 2017
CommentsContent: Some of the way language was used when the book (1797) was written can be obtuse as to its meaning but this hardly detracts from this novel. In addition, misspellings, dropped letters (in words) and what are flat out the wrong words, a result of digitizing, also adds to the confusion. All of this however is minor considering the product.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 30, 2018
CommentsContent: I am a lover of all the Pride and Prejudice movies, so thought it's about time that I read the book. It's a lovely little volume, with the emphasis on little. I found it a little difficult to read as I'm a senior and the print was necessarily small. Other than that, it is a beautiful, quality edition that I'm proud to add to my library. If the print size is an issue for you, I'd recommend finding a large-print edition.

CommentsTitle: Scam Kindle copy should be removed from site.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 26, 2019
CommentsContent: The Kindle copy I received was obviously created by someone (or a bot) unable to speak English.Returned for refund.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 21, 2017
CommentsContent: Although written in a style due to the time and English, I greatly enjoyed the story in print. I had seen the movie from different times, the book shows the long days, weeks and months they spent together where the movies make it seem they only saw each other a few times and for only short spaces of time. I can see why it is a story that has stood the test of time with many books attempting to copy without seeming to want to.

CommentsTitle: My Fault for Not Reading Description
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 25, 2019
CommentsContent: This is one of my favorite books.  I wanted an inexpensive paperback to keep in the pocket of my car.  I failed to read the description of this product.  Instead of a neat little paperback, this is magazine size (8 1/2 by 11) and very small print.  That is exactly how it was described, but obviously I did not read that.  I will never read this particular format.  Will throw it in the garbage and go buy another copy.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 6, 2019
CommentsContent: A terrible "updating" of language - these are NOT Jane Austin's words! ridiculous and outrageous misrepresentation.DO NOT BUY this version of Pride and Prejudice. It should be removed from Amazon,

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 20, 2020
CommentsContent: Love the asides and footnotes scattered through the text. Easy to access and return to your place. I can't recommend this edition highly enough.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 29, 2019
CommentsContent: This edition is absolutely beautiful! A must have for any Austen fan!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 24, 2019
CommentsContent: Great novel. But, when the book arrived it was visibly dented and the cover damaged. I'm not happy with it. Aesthetically it's small, but the book itself (if it were in ”new condition”) is beautiful. It's a great piece of literature to own for any book enthusiast.

CommentsTitle: Great book with poor typesetting in this edition
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 1, 2017
CommentsContent: Jane Austen deserves five stars. This edition less so, hence the three at the rating. The font is just OK - at least in my experience of reading it and the setting of the book appears ragged. In addition, there are some places where a reference to a village or person is replaced by a series of ----- in the text which is just plain weird. Jane Austen's writing is a real pleasure for some people and if you are someone who loves her material then my advice would be to get a copy from a library and enjoy a good book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 30, 2011
CommentsContent: I took me years to read this book!  It started when I was 12 years old, a friend of my moms gave me the A&E version on VHS tape, you know, the one with Colin Firth!!!  After watching all 6 hours of that for day's in a row, i found it hard to sit down and read the book?But then I got my Kindle, and this was one of the first book I read!  It was great to have the details filled in that the movie left out, and also to have the image of Colin Firth in my head as Mr. Darcy!  I love this book and the A&E version of it! :  I am now 26 years old, so it took me about 14 years for me to finally read the book, but it was well worth it.  I now also own the movie on DVD!!  ;)

CommentsTitle: Jane Austen is an excellent author -- my husband gifted the edition to our ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 8, 2017
CommentsContent: Jane Austen is an excellent author -- my husband gifted the edition to our 11-year old granddaughter. The cover is pliable and comfortable in a young girls' hands; however, it doesn't look anything like the classic it is.  I would recommend it for those acquiring a full set of Jane Austen books. We will purchase again.Anne

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 4, 2017
CommentsContent: I finally finished this classic novel, by Jane Austen, set in the 18th century, and I have to say it was worth all the time I took to read it. I absolutely loved the main characters, the humor, and most of all the romance. I watched the movie and loved it also, but the book is much more detailed and descriptive.Definitely a favorite! I highly recommend it to everyone. You won't regret reading this one. 🐦

CommentsTitle: Men : this is what women want
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2021
CommentsContent: A romance story of such depth its still a favorite over 200 years later. Men should read this, they may finally figure out what women want

CommentsTitle: This book sets the standard for all true character-driven romance novels.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 4, 2015
CommentsContent: One of my all time favorites.  My 16 year old & my 13 year old really enjoy it too.  There is so much depth of story and character development.  The dialogue is extraordinary.  This is a timeless story.  You really feel like you know the characters in the end.My action movie-guy-film-loving husband has not read the book but he has watched and laughed along with the BBC movie Based on this book.  The movie is a multi-part series and we have watched this numerous times as a family and enjoyed it from start to finish.  However, being the person that I am, there is nothing like savoring the book.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 26, 2020
CommentsContent: I thoroughly enjoyed the story of Elizabeth Bennett and Mr Darcy. This book will often be read when I am in the mood for a romance novel.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 28, 2019
CommentsContent: Not st all what I was expecting. Maybe I didn’t read the description correctly before ordering. The book is the size of a magazine. Very thin. The font is very small. One two page spread contains two whole chapters. Was going to give as a shower gift but not sure everyone would be able to read it very well.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 27, 2020
CommentsContent: It is pretty good. Some words are hard to understand in modern times but I guess it’s a good opportunity to learn English and expand vocabularies.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 2, 2020
CommentsContent:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.










  
  
    
   The corner of the BRAND NEW Pride & Prejudice novel by Jane Austen, is ripped and the plastic covering over it is ripped as well. The rest of the cover and book looks perfect except for that ONE corner!!! So mad!!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 27, 2008
CommentsContent: I can imagine that Elizabeth Bennet (Lizzy) is Jane Austen herself, couldn't you?Jane Austen is a wonderful writer. She deserves much praise. With extraordinary insight into feelings and actions of characters. She does a good job of making each character distinct and well defined. The Bantam Classic edition of all of the classics is much better then the Barnes and Noble version.You must read this book even if it's but only for once (even thought there may be a possibility of you may not liking it) to give credit to what I consider a historic acknowledgement to a female writer. Men can also learn much about the fact that not all women are the same.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 7, 2021
CommentsContent: I very much enjoyed this book 📖. It was a great read. I don't read quickly but was able to finish this book in 3 days.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 5, 2020
CommentsContent: There’s dirt on the side and it smells like someone wiped their rear end with it. Other than that, it’s the book I ordered.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 30, 2017
CommentsContent: I’d never read a book by Jane Austen, but I will now read them all.I both listened and read, as I do with most books as I have a long commute every day. What a delight to hear and read the beautiful prose and intelligent interplay between so perfectly drawn characters. And what a love story, more  than one really. The next best thing to a time machine back to the drawing rooms and parlors of the early 1800’s.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 25, 2012
CommentsContent: A mother's driving force is getting her five daughters married quickly; it hardly matters to whom. A suitor proposes, is summarily rejected and marries someone else within days. A woman doesn't like men but wants to get married anyway. A sixteen-year-old runs off with a man and doesn't marry him right away, much to the dismay of both her parents and sisters. A mother has no use for her daughter's suitor but happily accepts him into the family because he is rich. The less money a family has, the more important it is that all their daughters marry and quickly. If the family lives in the country, they must work harder to get these daughters married. Sound like your favorite sitcom and/or your favorite cousin and her family? Well, it's Jane Austin's timeless PRIDE AND PREJUDICE. Here we have much ado about getting the daughters married.Everybody points out what is so unique about this novel as well as the rest of Austin's works. She does very little to place them in any given time. They are good because of what they don't tell us. Austin doesn't give us a lot of specificity about a lot of things. For example, The Bennetts are always entertaining yet we don't know much about what they eat other than "venison" or "meat." Wickham may wear a blue coat when he gets married. The young women often play music but we are never told the names of the pieces they play.The ironic first line of the novel is well-known: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife." With that great opener, we are off to the races.Parts of this novel will make you smile; others will make your laugh. My favorite character is the father, Mr. Bennett, who is quick to see and point out his wife's and others' foibles but never sees his own. Somehow it seemed Jane Austen anticipated the future when much of her character's behavior would be seen as folly, though we certainly have follies of our own today.

CommentsTitle: I simply enjoyed the book and like romantic novels.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 15, 2020
CommentsContent: Sometimes the English of that period made it difficult to understand.  Nevertheless, the novel certainly demonstrates how people lived at that time.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 10, 2019
CommentsContent: This review isn’t for the content, but this format. I clearly didn’t read the description to see the size, but it was so cumbersome. I couldn’t keep up with the instructor because he would list off page numbers and of course they weren’t the same. If you’re buying for a class, don’t purchase this version.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 11, 2017
CommentsContent: I have read this book so many times. It is my go-to book. From Elizabeth’s visit with the Collinses, to her visit to Mr. Darcy’s home and then back to Longbourn, I just love reading of the progression of the love and affection between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’m going to go watch the movie after I’ve now finished reading the book again. :)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2006
CommentsContent: This book was truly a delight to read (and to re-read many times)! Jane Austen is a literary genius! "Pride and Prejudice" is a heartwarming tale with a beautifully woven plot, filled with witty dialogue and, of course, a charming love story. It is no wonder that this book has been so wildly successful!Reading over the negative reviews of this book, I am very surprised that anyone could not like this story! I certainly don't know what these people were thinking when they decided that they didn't like "Pride and Prejudice". This has certainly surpassed all other novels as my favorite book of all-time. Perhaps some might find Jane Austen's language difficult to understand, but as a 14-year-old, I didn't think that it was that way at all. This book will certainly remain dear to my heart forever, and I can certainly see myself reading it still 30 years from now.Elizabeth is a delightful heroine, and there is nothing quite as satisfying as the humbling of Mr. Darcy. I only wished that there was more (or that I was assigned to read it for my English class, which I would do with much pleasure)!In conclusion--read this book, for goodness sakes! You won't be sorry.

CommentsTitle: Great edition, book was in perfect conditions
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 5, 2017
CommentsContent: Great edition, book was in perfect conditions, and if you haven't already read it... it's amazing! You don't have to be a romantic to love this book, I know I'm not and despite having been skeptical for years, due to the social setting of the story, it has become one of my favorites. Austen sucks you into her novels... truly an amazing author and an amazing book!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 8, 2014
CommentsContent: I can't seem to stop buying copies of Pride and Prejudice, and there are enough reviews out there, so I just want to say I purchased this book purely for the cover design. It's a beautiful watercolor design and looks lovely on my shelf! The book itself is a nice sturdy paperback. My only wish is that all 6 books were available in this cover style, instead of just this, Emma and Sense and Sensibility - I'd love to have a complete set! If you're just looking to add another copy of this book to your collection, it's worth it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 30, 2020
CommentsContent: I was captivated by the reality of the conversations. I loved seeing the evolution of the characters of Elizabeth & Darcy. It was a good glimpse of time and place. I missed reading this book in my younger years, but I believe I could appreciate even more the whole essence of this beautiful book!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 1, 2016
CommentsContent: What can I say about a story that is a classic, filled with fun and intrigue and words I sometimes have to look up. I love this story of such delightful and sometimes annoying characters. I've now read it about 6 times, and found it such a fun read as to be my go-to when I can't find anything else to interest me. Make no mistake, Austen's representation of love and marriage, designs and schemes is a satirical look at Victorian courtship.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 28, 2019
CommentsContent: Absolutely beautiful edition. The nicest P&P edition that I've seen. No complaints whatsoever. Love the pink, the way it shines in the sun, the endpapers, the quality, the gold sprayed edges, the chapter illustrations... perfect for a collector!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2020
CommentsContent: One cannot help but love Darcy and Elizabeth. Their whirlwind relationship, which plays well off of those around them, makes for a dizzying and satisfying story. It goes to show that whatever is meant to be will be, first impressions are not always correct, and happiness can be found even after one believes it to be lost forever.I kick myself for waiting so long to take part in this lovely classic. However, I know I'll be indulging in this book again and again.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 23, 2012
CommentsContent: Jane Austen's works are always engaging, entertaining, heart-warming, and funny. So well written and so much more true romance than any dime store novel ever could attain to be. The only downside is that this copy seems to have some glitch where it will double a sentence and place that 2nd sentence a few paragraphs later but it's in a way that it's obvious it doesn't belong there. The only thing I could figure was that in the hard copy there is some book print style picture with a quote from the book under it as would be typical in many books of this type and that in the kindle version it just doesn't show the picture.

CommentsTitle: Classic Boy Meets Girl - the one that started it all
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 14, 2014
CommentsContent: A classic. The first real boy-meets-girl romance ever written.Jane meets Darcy. She overhears some snobbish comments from him. He falls for her. She spurns him. She has a change of heart...but is is too late?Take some time to ease into the language - some people give up too soon in this. It's a bit challenging to read the formality of her writing. But the story is sparkling, the humor subtle and universal.Read this, and then read Persuasion - the story of what MIGHT have happened to Jane and Darcy.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 21, 2020
CommentsContent: The first time I read Pride & Prejudice I was 16, and I must confess that at the time I hardly understood any of the words that I was reading. However, I had fallen in love with the movie adaptations and pressed on to finish it. Ten years later, I have found it much easier to read and enjoy. Jane Austen's story-telling still holds a special place in my heart and I'm going to push to read all of her novels this summer.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 2, 2020
CommentsContent: I've never highlited a novel before... but it was just so funny. So many quips I wanted to remember and reference.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 7, 2019
CommentsContent: Why is this size even an option? These needs a picture showing the scale of the book, not just the front and back of the book. When you purchase a book you automatically think it's a typical book size. I have never seen a novel like this.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 2, 2021
CommentsContent: This was a gift for my niece. She started reading it today and the pages are falling out. Disappointed the return date has passed. I won't recommend this product to anyone.

CommentsTitle: Always a wonderful thing to read!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 16, 2016
CommentsContent: I love this book, and all the movies made of it. Of course, this book is better than the movies! Of all of Jane Austen's works, this one is, by far, my favorite. She peoples her world with such real characters, with folks you know, and shows how silly and how serious they are. She was an excellent observer of the human condition, at least within her country world, and one could go far in studying Austen's work!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 20, 2018
CommentsContent: When I went to order this book I knew the story was fantastic already so the main goal was to find an addition with an attractive cover and a comfortable size. I think everyone knows the difficulty of reading a tiny book. So when I stumbled across this, I got pretty excited. When it arrived from the seller, though, it didn't resemble the picture. It was a bit smaller than I had expected and the cover was totally different which, not gonna lie, was a letdown. Ultimately, I didn't feel like sending it back, though. In whatever form, Pride and Prejudice is a classic and deserves a read. Just don't be surprised if the version you get isn't the one in the picture above.

CommentsTitle: Required reading for every adolescent girl
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 10, 2013
CommentsContent: Thoroughly enjoyed Pride and Prejudice. I only wish Miss Austen lived in the age of writing a series of novels. I grew so fond of Elizabeth and Darcy...I was sad when I read that last page. I so wanted to know what happened next to these charming characters.In a world where movie characters too often end up in bed on the very day they meet, this old story is refreshing in its portrayal of two people who grew to love each other.  I can't help but think a love story like this is something every teenage girl should read...it may be an idealized love for sure...but what is wrong with that?

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 4, 2014
CommentsContent: The incredible quality of Jane Austen's story to have held it's place for over 200 years! I just discovered her this year, and how she has enriched my life! Her understanding of people is a wonderful gift. I had downloaded P&P on my Kindle, and realized I needed a hardcopy. I chose this book strictly because of the price. I would not choose this copy again because it is difficult to read. The type is small and faint. I will watch used book stores for a better copy. But at least I have this one for insurance.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 5, 2020
CommentsContent: A delightful read. The story, the characters, the language, the descriptions of countryside.  So much scope for the imagination in this book!

CommentsTitle: Good enough, but prefer most other Jane Austen titles.

I just don't find this to be her best work.  I would much rather read Persuasion (my personal favorite), Sense and Sensibility, Emma or Northanger Abbey. CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 16, 2020

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 23, 2020
CommentsContent: If you like romance then this novel is for you. I've read it over 10 times now and fall in love deeper each time I read it.

CommentsTitle: One of the best books of all time
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2014
CommentsContent: A classic! I first read this book in high-school, my 11th grade year, in my AP literature class and I adored reading this book! I honestly didn't think I'll like this book, I'm not into historical romance books, book this book surprised me.The characters are very well developed and I loved the story-line. If you're wondering whether or not to read this book, do yourself a favorite and read it! It's amazing and you will love it.I recommend this book to everyone!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 9, 2017
CommentsContent: Jane Austen is one of my favorite authors.  Pride an Prejudice is my favorite, not only of her books, but of all the classics I have read so far, of which there are many.  The love story is combined with enough of both humor and class to cater to all types of readers.  The characters are complex and well defined.  Their dialog is stunning.  Many of my favorite quotes are from this book.  I highly recommend it for anyone who loves vivid, well written historical fiction.

CommentsTitle: My favorite love-hate story of all time
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 11, 2012
CommentsContent: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a reader would find that books worth reading are worth reading twice and Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is definitely one of them.Pride and Prejudice is actually the first classic book I've ever read from cover to cover. Since I'm not used to reading classics during that time, it took me ages before I get the hang of the story and eventually finish it. Nevertheless, I was able to appreciate the story and it instantly became my favorite. Well, who would not fall in love with the story of Lizzie and Mr. Darcy?Three years later, this book was chosen as the featured book for the October face-to-face discussion of my book club and so I decided to read it again since I wasn't able to retain most of the details of the story in my memory. It was worth reading twice indeed for I find it sweeter the second time around. For some weird reason, I am really a fan of love-hate story and it was only when I read this book the second time that I realized that this is the best love-hate story I've read so far. It was also in my second time that I was able to appreciate more the care-free character of Elizabeth Bennet, the snob-outside-but-soft-inside character of Mr. Darcy, the annoying character of Mrs. Bennet and the cool father character of Mr. Bennet.Pride and Prejudice is truly an enduring classic so no wonder it became one of the most popular books in English literature and inspired most of the novels of today and became the favorite subject for film and tv adaptations.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 1, 2021
CommentsContent: Enjoyed reading through this book again over Christmas break.  Great story, and the print isn’t too small!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 28, 2020
CommentsContent: It's a romantic classic.  Exceptional world and character building.  Austen such a treasure.  Superb romance.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 17, 2014
CommentsContent: I'm not going to say much about the actual content of this book. I've been a Jane Austen fan for years - I just read this book for the 4th time - obviously I love it. Her work isn't for everyone though - but there are enough other reviews out there for you to be able to figure out if you want to check her out or not (you should just give her a chance anyway).I just want to comment on this edition of the book. It's wonderful! I actually saw a picture of this on Instagram and HAD to find out where to buy it (turns out it was hidden in the depths of Amazon).I'm a Pride and Prejudice collector. I'm pretty sure I have 10 versions now - so when it comes to getting new versions, I'm all about judging the books by their covers. I also love Colin Firth, so the moment I saw this, I knew I had to have it. I love the classic pulp style of the cover and the techniques they used to make it look a little worn. The edges of the pages are a bright red - really eye catching. Other than that, it's a solid little paperback. Something I can see myself reading and reading again - on the beach, on vacation, while it gets a little more broken in each time - and the more worn it becomes the more I'll love it.If you're looking for a unique copy for your collection and maybe you're not ready to invest in a nice hardcover, I'd say go for this. I believe I got it for about $6 on Amazon.

CommentsTitle: Such a perfect book for the age.

Much better as I have gotten older.  Austin must have had a delightful sense of humor to laugh so genteelly at herself and age.

CommentsTitle: Oldie is still a great read
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 10, 2014
CommentsContent: Would give this 5 stars,  but I am old and typos bug the heck out of me.  That said,  the numerous editorial comments are helpful to making this easier to read.  Many references to things we moderns know nothing about are rapidly explained in good humored fashion.  Once accustomed to the positioning, roughly alongside the corresponding text, it was placed in a non disruptive fashion (as opposed, for instance to footnotes).  As for Jane Austin,  there is nothing I can say about her writing,  other than there is a good reason she remains famous.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 8, 2016
CommentsContent: My first time reading this book.  Actually, my first Austen novel!  This one is a keeper.  Austen is a master at character development.  In this book she explores people's perceptions about others from they see, perceptions from what they hear about others, and then reveals the realities of each character.  My favorite character has to be Mr. Collins because Austen seems to have used him to add humor to her novel.  Great comic relief.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 12, 2005
CommentsContent: When I opened up my copy of Pride and Prejudice, I didn't know what to expect.  I had heard from my friend that it was good, but I really didn't trust her taste.  I am forever thankful to her.Elizabeth Bennet, a young woman in a middle class society, and her sisters must marry in order to be guaranteed a comfortable life.  When Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy (two upper class men) come into town, Mrs. Bennet is determined to make the men fall in love with her daughters.  This leads to conflict, etc (sorry I don't want to give away too much!)I think the main reason why I love this book is that it is difficult to put down.  Austen's witty characters bring to Merrytown, never knowing what is going to happen next.  This book was, "Impossible to imagine; it was impossible not to long to know"(59).

CommentsTitle: Seriously - It's Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice - you ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 24, 2017
CommentsContent: Seriously - It's Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice - you shouldn't need my opinion to read this book.  It's more than a classic.  It's the prototype.  Just read it.  It will change the way you read.  It's so full of reality, told with such humor and subtlety and brilliance, you'll begin to gobble the other five novels she wrote in her short lifetime.  You'll understand why she turned down all of the suitors she had in her lifetime because she knew that it was more important for her to write than to make babies.  Just read it!

CommentsContent: I always intended to read Pride and Prejudice, but never followed through until now.  The characters were, in fact, extremely well developed and the tension created between Elizabeth and Darcy fortunately overshadowed the cloying Jane.Thoroughly enjoyed the book, but the side notes in this version were annoying.  Their placement interfered with smooth reading of the text.  The information presented in the side notes was neither appropriate, nor did it lend to the enjoyment of this novel.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 6, 2015
CommentsContent: I am usually not a big fan of classical literatures. I often found them too slowly paced and devoid of action to my taste. My reason for reading Pride and Prejudice was a wish to improve my writing skills and I did not expect to enjoy it. I am glad to say that I couldn't have been more wrong.The story's theme is obvious upon reading the first page, that's it chiefly about marriage and scandals. I can't say that I was surprised by any of the plot development either. However, despite all of these I still thoroughly enjoyed the characters' developments and how they gradually grew closer together. It's nice to read a story where most character can find their own happiness - I am a bit sick of mordern television shows where the director feel compelled to kill off the audiences' favourite characters one after another.I am afraid that I do not fully comprehend the story, especially the writer's view on marriage and obedience. Partly because I am not well versed in the historical background of the story's settings, and partly because I was in too much of a hurry to find out the conclusion of the two main characters' relationship. I am not a patient reader. I would like to read the story once more to understand it better, but right now I wish to seek out more classical literatures that may interest me in the same way.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 13, 2018
CommentsContent: This was my first time reading a classic, willingly. I never read Pride and Prejudice in high school or college but I really enjoyed it. There were some parents that made me extremely annoyed but I think it was based on the time period rather than the story or the writing.

CommentsTitle: A great introduction to classic literature!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 13, 2006
CommentsContent: Perhaps the mother of all romances, this classic crème de la crème Jane Austen story stands as a model that many modern romances seem formulated upon. Not a pure romance however, Austen offers so much more to her readers in P&P: realistic relationships, interesting characters, comical situations and compelling subplots force readers to think in many directions and entertain far and beyond boy loves girl. This particular copy of P&P would make a perfect little gift for anyone just introduced to the story or Austen through this latest movie version (or as a companion to the movie) and is a wonderful beginning to immersing oneself in the English language of 200 years ago. To be certain, this sort of old classic literature may be a challenge to peruse at first, but rest assured that it becomes easier to assimilate the more you read it.

CommentsContent: The content is quite boring, yet the writing is pretty good.  If you want to learn English writing, you might consider the option of reading this novel.  For Penguin classics, I would prefer to read  "The Count of Monte Cristo."

In the end this is a rare yet reasonable romance that can relate to the real and the true hearted in anyone Enjoy this Timeless Classic!

CommentsTitle: Great read! Delivered on time in good condition at an excellent price
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 22, 2019
CommentsContent: What can I say about my favorite Jane Austen classic work? I have read it several times and it continues to impact me and the world with it's timeless romantic intelligent wit

CommentsTitle: True Classic!  Wonderful!  There's a Reason This Book Endures!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 31, 2011
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice by Jane AustenRecently I went on a drive home to California and back.  It's about 7 1/2 hours each way (because I actually go the speed limit!!!) and I wanted to try something new while driving.  So, I decided to try an audio recording.I found one from my local library of Pride and Prejudice.  :  Why not go with a classic book for the drive home?So, I listened to Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen.Pride and Prejudice is the story of the Bennet sisters, Elizabeth and Jane.  Both are of marriageable age but do not come from the wealthiest of families.  However, they live in a time when marriage to someone with wealth is of utmost importance.Since they have no brothers, when their father dies his estate will go to another male relative, as they are unable to inherit.One summer a new family comes to live nearby, and Mrs. Bennet, their mother insists that Mr. Bennet make an acquaintance with Mr. Bingley, the new bachelor who is very wealthy.  At a ball one evening he is immediately taken with Jane Bennet who is admittedly beautiful, of a sweet nature, but perhaps below the standard of wealth into which he is expected to marry.But the problem really is his friend, Mr. Darcy.  A haughtier more proud man has never existed, and though that same night at the ball many women did not have partners as men were few, Mr. Darcy makes it clear that he thinks pretty negatively of Elizabeth Bennet.  He is cold, unfriendly, and seemingly unkind . . .Mrs. Bennet is determined to see her daughters married and encourages Jane and Mr. Bingley, but is desperate to make a match for Elizabeth, including pushing her to accept the proposal of marriage from her most insipid cousin.We follow the story of the Bennet family as others do everything they can to keep Jane and Mr. Bingley apart, and Elizabeth is forced into close proximity with the awful Mr. Darcy repeatedly.Will Jane and Elizabeth ever find true love that others will accept?  Or will their less wealthy state be their destruction?Read Pride and Prejudice to find out!This is a total and complete classic.  There are over 2 million copies sold worldwide, hundreds of editions, and quite a few different audio recordings, not to mention TV and movie versions of this story.If you haven't actually read Pride and Prejudice you simply must!  It's a beautiful, wonderful story full of lively characters with personality oozing from them.  Mrs. Bennet is incredibly silly, a trait which seems to have rubbed off thoroughly on several of her daughters.  But Jane and Elizabeth took far more after their father with much more sense.  It's the story of how pride and prejudice can keep you from truly seeing another's character, and how opinions can change when someone is given a true chance.I highly recommend this book to everyone!5 out of 5 stars!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 5, 2012
CommentsContent: I must say I never imagined I would enjoy reading a 19th century romance, but it turns out that 'Pride and Prejudice' is an easy, pleasant and surprisingly engaging read. The story is set in rural England of early 19th century and is centered around Elizabeth, second daughter of the Bennets, and her evolving relationship with 'proud' Mr Darcy. The author has done an excellent job keeping the pace of the story, while painting excellent character portraits.--A minor note:Some people observe that the name of the county where the military regiment is settled appears as "----shire" throughout the book. Strange as that may seem, it is not a typographical error; it is actually how it appears in the original (you can check the free online editions of the novel on Project Gutenberg or Google Books). According to an annotated version by David M. Shapard, that was done in purpose by the author to avoid naming a particular county, although the reason is not known for certain.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 15, 2016
CommentsContent: This book has been on my "must read" list for years, and I finally made it through. It is a refreshing story of a thoughtful, intelligent young woman who knows her own mind. That sounds a bit pompous, but it is true nonetheless. Take some time to enjoy this book; it is not for hurrying through.

CommentsTitle: Those were different times. The characters were nearly developed ...

CommentsContent: Love this classic.  The book itself is just gorgeous!

CommentsTitle: Not a reader friendly version of this classic.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2020
CommentsContent: The print and the structure of the chapters are not as easily read as other versions I’ve read of this book.

CommentsTitle: Rating for the story content- not the formatting for Kindle
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 11, 2014
CommentsContent: Great book, obviously, but the Kindle edition has extra letters, spaces, and is formatted in a way that makes reading difficult. Some of the footnotes were helpful, but most were just lame and distracting. Get a different version of the book if you want to avoid the irritation. I got the book when it was free, so I didn't mind too much, but if I had paid for it, I would have been more annoyed. (I would give the Kindle format and extra notes 3 stars.)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 8, 2000
CommentsContent: Why is Jane Austen's work so popular even today?  Because she was just the best! This is on my personal top ten list. I've read it at least ten times and probably will read it several times again. It's funny, it's smart, it's  romantic, and Elizabeth Bennett is my all-time favorite fictional heroine.  You can read this book when you're 16 and every ten years after that. All  of Jane Austen's books are good, but this is her best - and a classic that  should be part of every woman's education and every woman's personal  library. It's also proof that a book can have sizzle without any explicit  sex.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 7, 2020
CommentsContent: The book came as described and I was able to use it for my AP Lit course. Totally good buy.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 24, 2013
CommentsContent: Does anyone write like this anymore?  Of course not; that era is gone.  A slow-moving novel about people's pride, their prejudices, and how these adversely affect their personal relationships.  I marvel continuously at Austen's ability (like Eliot; like Proust) to so vividly portray people, manners, affects, relationships, thoughts, neighborhoods, customs...  With subtlety and tact is each character drawn so that, as with all good novels, when we reach that last page it's as if we had spent a good month visiting with intimate friends and now it was time to go.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 24, 2010
CommentsContent: Even though I am a guy who had accompanied his wife through every film relating to "Pride and Prejudice," I enjoyed reading the book. Jane Austin gives details of the characters' thoughts that make the story, especially the development of the two main characters, convincing. The other characters are amusing and vivid. The dialogue is delicious with treats like, "Is not general incivility the very essence of love?"In my Kindle version random line breaks occur. For example, one often encounters "Mr. [line break] Darcy," even when "Mr." is almost the beginning of the line. Although this is a little annoying, the Kindle version can't be beat for price and convenience.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 1, 2017
CommentsContent: Good story, but the physical book itself is ridiculous.  It's 8.5 x 11, has no illustrations (regardless of what some of the reviews say), minuscule print, and won't even fit in my bookcase.  I'm glad I didn't pay much for it, but it's going back nevertheless.  I never thought I'd have to check the size of a book, but apparently I must.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 30, 2020
CommentsContent: Absurd.  The book is tiny! I expect a book to be book size, not smaller than my hand! You have to be so careful when ordering online. Amazon should require sellers to clearly state when a product is not standard size.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 17, 2021
CommentsContent: Was listed as “Used-Like New” and that is just laughable. Returning for a proper copy instead.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 20, 2014
CommentsContent: Maybe it should be.Don't expect a barn burner here. It after all a product of its time.I read this with an open mind to try and envision life back then, and found myself engrossed with the formality that was the norm.They certainly had a much stronger command of the written word than is seen in much of today's writing.I wonderful, slow, relaxing (by modern standards) story. I love period pieces that are well written. This certainly qualifies!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2015
CommentsContent: I adore Pride and Prejudice, but this edition is totally non-readable on my Kindle.  I can't even see the type except when it is actually in the process of loading the page.  Once loaded, it's so grayed-out that I am unable to see it.  I am certainly glad that I got this free rather than paying anything for it.  Believe the reviews that say THIS edition is horribly done for the Kindle.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 24, 2003
CommentsContent: Being a 20 something male, I was not sure what to think when I picked up this novel.  I knew that girls had always loved this book, so I set myself up for a girlie novel.  Elizabeth, the protaganist, is anything but a simple girlie character though.  This book attacks the social structure of Austen's days.  The characters are deep and well written.  Some are characatures for comic relief, but you still come away with the feeling that you have known someone like that in the past.  This book is a classic for a reason.  I recommend this book to anyone, not just love sick teenage girls.

CommentsTitle: Beautiful Edition of a timeless classic
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 3, 2019
CommentsContent: I am very proud to present this new, beautifully printed book to a young member of our family.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 5, 2015
CommentsContent: If you ever wanted to read pithy, sharp and incessant insults, all cleverly disguised as politeness, this is the book for you.  This is a throw back to when language was intended to communicate complexities, long before bumper stickers and short poetry replaced critical thinking and historical fact.  The dialog is marvelous and will enrapture the imagination while engaging the mind wonderfully.  A touching, but very humorous tale.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 23, 2019
CommentsContent: The very best story ever written.  I have read it so many times, I can almost quote  it. I would have loved to keep reading about Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. It makes me understand why so many have attempted it and at the same time regret that none have done it justice.

CommentsTitle: To put this book down felt wrong
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 4, 2013
CommentsContent: I thoroughly enjoyed this book, from the detail of the characters, their witty remarks and the sure ease of read. I found it hard to put this book down - it just felt wrong. The characters hold their own with such vast differences and sometimes seemingly defects that I found i could relate to some of them in many ways. I greatly admire both Darcy and Elizabeth equally and favour neither over the other. I also find myself relating to the worries of Mrs. Bennet - and over time, though she seems very much a pain to Elizabeth and the family, she does justice to them all as a mother. Her sole focus is the attention to her children and ensuring that they marry suitably and are secured for the future - though for her, this security is based around financials. Mr. Bennet is a very "chilled" guy, and his character really does reduce the tension that plagues the family. He also relates incredibly to Elizabeth, and is proud of her independence - I think he sees a lot of himself in her! I could go on and on about the story, but to all who have read it will understand and to all who haven’t and are planning too, I envy you. In any case, this book is by far, my most favourite book. Period! And now that I have written this, I think I will read it again...and read it annually as well!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 25, 2014
CommentsContent: I have probably read this book about 5 times over the last 10 years and each time am drawn in by Austen 's colorful, complex and delightful characters. Each time, I mourn over Lydia's poor choices, laugh with Elizabeth at Mr Collins, and fall in love with Mr Darcy (to my husband's dismay). For those who enjoy witty comebacks, romance, and the Victorian era, you will absolutely love this book.  If you think you know it all because you've seen the movie, think again and give the book a chance. You won't regret it!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 17, 2019
CommentsContent: Good plot twists...definitely some lessons to lesrn. Pay attention to details.  Make sure sources of info reliable.  Don't be afraid to change your 1st impressiom

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 17, 2019
CommentsContent: I really enjoyed this classic. At times, the use of language was difficult to translate but at the same time I love the old style of expressing oneself. My only dislike, and this happened in the beginning more than later in the novel, was the inability to know who was speaking.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 3, 2017
CommentsContent: Words cannot explain how I feel about this amazing read!!! I know I watched the movie first and that is why I just had to buy this book! I have had the biggest crush on Mr. Darcy, since like early high school! If you are not into detailed story lines or comments then this probably isn't for you. I had to search up some words constantly because some of them are uncommon now a days, but I love the storyline and characters. Yup, especially the characters, they are full of life and each have their dispositions and personalities.

CommentsTitle: Officially tied as my all time favorite novel
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 3, 1998
CommentsContent: In case you are wondering, the novel it tied with is Dostoevsky's THE BROTHERS KARAMAZOV. I have read this three times in three sittings.  In case that is not clear, I mean to say that I have sat down to read PRIDE AND PREJUDICE on three separate occasions, and did not get up until I had finished it.  I once stayed up all night long to finish it. Actually, I read it a fourth time, aloud to my then 8-year-old daughter Elizabeth (who was delighted to find an Elizabeth in the book).  She liked it so much that she in turn read it twice.  Just one of the great, irrestible book in the English language.

CommentsTitle: Great product. Great seller. Arrived sooner than expected.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 13, 2020
CommentsContent: Great product. Great seller. Arrived sooner than expected.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2021
CommentsContent: bought this for a granddaughter for Christmas - she reads a ton and loved getting this book

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 14, 2016
CommentsContent: This Oxford version is enjoyable to read, goes fast, and has good notes.  A good, alternate version of P&P is David M. Shapard's book.  It has a page of notes, maps, and drawings for each page of text.  It can enhance the reader's knowledge although it takes longer to read the book.  If you buy Shapard's book, get the updated 2012 edition instead of the 2008 edition.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 10, 2013
CommentsContent: I've always quite enjoyed reading the classics, especially the Bronte sisters ones, and anything by Jane Austen. I enjoyed this book as well, though not quite as much as I loved Wuthering Heights. The characters are well developed, though they take some time to really get in to. Once Mr. Darcy comes onto the scene, things heat up a little, but most of the book seems to be about anticipation. This can be quite enjoyable for someone that loves to analyze and anticipate things, however I can not see people who only love action and adventure being able to get past the first chapter.Still, I would read it a second time for the same reason I read Jane Eyre again, it's enjoyable to get to the heart of a character and feel with them, wait with them, and try with them!

CommentsTitle: A mixture of subtlety, acute observation and romantic self-indulgence
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 22, 2019
CommentsContent: Jane Austen - as always - writes with harmony and good sense. She draws memorable, believable characters, and the plotline is marked by an adult view of the world. But the whole thing is too neat: The fates of the characters are wish fulfilment. Still, probably one of the better books in the Western canon.

CommentsTitle: I loved it. Very slow reading
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 2, 2015
CommentsContent: What can I say? This has been a classic for two hundred years. I loved it. Very slow reading, as many words are not in common use today, the sentence structure is often complex and requires rereading, and the social structure was different. Doing some additional research on the time of the story helps a lot. All the characters grow significantly throughout the story and it took me over a month to read it, enjoying every minute.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 22, 2018
CommentsContent: I had never read this classic, although acquainted with the title and subject.  A friend of mine gently chided me for not having read it and I downloaded it somewhat from shame.  I’m glad I took the time to read it!  This is a great read, no matter the century.

CommentsTitle: I would highly recommend this book and so glad they made movies from ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 2, 2016
CommentsContent: I would highly recommend this book and so glad they made movies from it, I like the movie with Colin Firth as Darcy and Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth Bennet, the older one in black and white was good, too, I didn't care for the new one. You need to read the book it goes into more detail and is great from start to finish, I would place it equal to "Gone With The Wind".

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 29, 2020
CommentsContent: The cover art is used without permission nor crediting the artist. Copyright infringement filed. This is my art and I was not credited. The original art is by Veronika-art at deviantart.The tumb still appears and I have no credit.  Awful Amazon and editors... shame on you.

CommentsTitle: The tolerance of her behavior and choices because she was a "sister" showed great kindness. Glad that I re-read it
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 21, 2014
CommentsContent: I found the language and sentence construction very interesting.  Having read this book in high school, I had a different perspective on it this read.  Austen's description of the mother's characteristics made me have a lot of disdain for her, two sisters were totally into themselves with no regard for others especially Lydia d(uck).  The tolerance of her behavior and choices because she was a "sister" showed great kindness.  Glad that I re-read it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 31, 2017
CommentsContent: I chose this rating because this is a classic.  I found the writing style  a bit difficult to follow due to the fact this book was written long before modern times. The  description of the characters' appearance was minimal and many were one dimensional. Nevertheless, it was worth reading this book by an author who has gained so much popularity, especially in today's world.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 3, 2018
CommentsContent: I never do reviews but when this popped  up in my email I couldn’t ignore. I tried to read this book, but it was hard. It’s the exact same story with roles reversed. I know that’s what it claims to be, but I was expecting some creative license or interpretation by the author. Nope. Nothing. Same story just trade boys for girls and sons for daughters. I feel like the theme of gender reversal is rich ground for metaphor, social commentary, and story and this failed that potential greatly. Sad, because I was so looking forward to it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 6, 2021
CommentsContent: Love the book itself but this cover is beautiful.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2008
CommentsContent: One reviewer (Jane Stewart) thanked me for my input on the "revised" setting of P&P.  My reasoning came after my desire to have the setting be the end of the beautiful 18th Century - not the industrialized 19th.  Jane Austen wrote the book in 1796, and it was published 17 years later, but it was the SAME book, and she naturally wrote about her time period.  So I deducted 17 years from 1813, which equals 1796.  (Note: An astute reviewer on Amazon also pinpointed the timeframe of 1794-1796 with a French action that Jane Austen mentioned, related to P&P.)

CommentsTitle: This classic is worth a reread.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 16, 2019
CommentsContent: It's been many years since I first read this book. It's just as enjoyable, even better because it wasn't required reading! Because of the writing style it took more time than my usual to read it.

CommentsTitle: Classic novel worth reading multiple times!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 22, 2019
CommentsContent: Love, love, love this book! It has been one of my favorites for many years, and I got this one because I lost my original copy. It’s a classic that won’t disappoint!

CommentsTitle: I bought this for the illustrations
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 24, 2014
CommentsContent: I own a number of P&P books, but not the illustrated ones.  So I just had to have this to add to my collection.  I got a great kick out of how funny some of the art work was.  But since I consider P&P as a very funny book, that really worked for me.  The characters and expressions are wonderful.  I will be going through this book a number of times in the future as this makes for a more complete part of the Jane Austen legacy.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 8, 2020
CommentsContent: The cover images and words are pixilated and blurry, almost as if I printed the cover out on my home printer...also the cover came bent which is frustrating as I ordered it new to avoid bends in the pages....But other than that it’s in good condition and smells nice and new.

CommentsTitle: Screw the errors, this book is amazing.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 11, 2012
CommentsContent: I read the bad review which were generally about the errors in this version. Any errors aside, this book is incredible, one of my favorite books of all time. Readers will fall in love with Elizabeth Bennet, a young girl with a big personality and an insufferable family who learns that love can mean learning to accept the person you choose, flaws and all. If you are a fan of subtle romance novels that are well written and hold messages about the nature of mankind, then Pride and Prejudice is the novel for you.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 15, 2013
CommentsContent: An improvement on 'Sense and Sensibility' but still slow-moving due to the English social customs and manners of the 18th century.The (modern) direct approach of the characters talking to each other openly is taboo - instead we get agonised speculation drawn out over many pages.  Again here a DVD/TV version is probably better - or read Mansfield Park first.  Again here we have 'cipher' characters, one representing Pride and the other Prejudice, and modern credibilities are stretched as the characters are kept strictly within these moulds.

CommentsTitle: Would make the perfect gift for the reader in your lfie
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 5, 2020
CommentsContent: This book is a beautiful classic and I’m so glad I got it!

CommentsTitle: Pride And Prejudice Dover Hardcover Edition
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2010
CommentsContent: There are literally thousands of review of Austen's seminal classic Pride And Prejudice out there already. This is a review of the Dover facsimile edition based on the 1894 copy.From the beautiful Hugh Thomson illustrations, to the embossed floral end pages, this edition is top notch. The cover is red cloth with gold foil lettering and peacock on the spine.The first page showing the opening line with huge flowing peacock is a work of art unto itselfIf you are a fan of Pride and Prejudice and long for a well made, permanent hard cover edition of the book, this is the edition for you!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 26, 2014
CommentsContent: Several friends recommended this book, but I tried three different times to read it.  All of the names sounded alike to me, and I was having difficulty following the plot.Then a friend suggested I watch one of the many movies based on this book.  My friend said it really was a great story.Some of my confusion was that husband and wife called each other Mr. Bennett and Mrs. Bennett.  Once I understood this, I enjoyed the story much more.  Many parts are hilarious!  I'm glad I made the effort to try reading it for a fourth time.  I liked it so much, I didn't want it to end.Have downloaded another of Miss Austen's books;  I have become a fan!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 19, 2020
CommentsContent: This book was awesome and the great condition

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 17, 2017
CommentsContent: I also bought the audio to go with this. Enjoying it so, This is of course one of my favorites, I never seem to tire of itI would recommend the audio , whisper sync , good reader with great voice changes from character to character, and the price is right for sure.

CommentsTitle: I can see why it's a classic
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2017
CommentsContent: I've seen the movies and the spin offs. I've read the satires and the retellings. I thought I knew Pride and Prejudice. And for the most part, I did. I can honestly say I didn't quite seen the appeal of Darcy until I read the book. He has so much more heart than I expected. Elizabeth reminds me of Jo March from Little Women.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 12, 2020
CommentsContent: I have been attempting to read this book since high school and only now, as a more mature adult, can I truly appreciate the magic of this captivating tale. One of the best books I have ever read!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 14, 2020
CommentsContent: I bought this book to read (as opposed to buying the book to watch it), but my wife stole it as soon as she saw it. It is very well bound. A charming and pleasing copy of an amazing classic. Has beautiful illustrations and a ribbon to keep your spot. The size is amazing for traveling.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 10, 2020
CommentsContent: I love the built-in bookmark and the gold edged pages. I did touch the side of the book (the golden sides) when my hands were a bit damp and the gold smeared off. Still looks OK, just strange.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2015
CommentsContent: I love this book.  Read it many times.  Some times the old English writing is difficult to follow and you have to re read a paragraph  but the story is defiantly worth it.  The characters are wonderful Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy are a romance you will never forget.  Elizabeth's family are memorable and the story reminds us how pride and prejudice can be such a part of our lives - even when we do not realize it.  Would defiantly recommended, worth the read.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2018
CommentsContent: I usually read books twice.  Two pages into this, I swore, IF I made it to the end, there was no way I would re-read this book!I woull love to find a modern-day language version of this story - I understand the words, but get tangled in the language I am unaccustomed to.But the story pulled me in and the deeper I got, the more enjoyable it bacame.  The best love stories often start out turbulant.  I knew they were destined to be.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 26, 2019
CommentsContent: ...about Pride and Prejudice? Basic book format but still a classic. My fave of all times. The price on this one is almost free. Love it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 1, 2016
CommentsContent: I have read Pride and Prejudice many times and consider it a familiar favorite.  Even though I know the ending I don't want Charlotte to settle for stuffy Mr Collins. I worry Lydia will be left stranded by Wickham even though she brings all her hardships  on herself. I am beyond glad for sweet Jane. Elizabeth and Mr Darcy continue to capture my attention with their timeless love story. God bless Mr Bennett for his exceedingly good humor and patience with his wife. High praises to Jane Austen for bringing the story of the Bennett's to life.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 8, 2017
CommentsContent: Since most of you are familiar with the story, this review is more about this particular edition. I am very pleased with it! They call it a "gift edition" and I would agree that is an accurate description. The cover art is beautiful and it's an authentic version. Do yourself a favor and splurge!

CommentsTitle: It's a classic for a reason!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 11, 2018
CommentsContent: This is a classic! It's been on my reading list for ages and I'm finally glad I got around to it. There are parts where I had to listen twice due to the diversity of the language, but that was expected and worth it!

CommentsTitle: I eventually decided that it'd be a fun challenge for me as well as not wanting to ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2017
CommentsContent:
I will freely admit to some trepidation in reviewing such a well-known book. Being as it is my first classic that I have considered reviewing, and one that has garnered much praise and censure that I believe I will not be able to add anything new, I did indeed waffle back and forth on whether or not it'd benefit me or anyone in my sphere to do so. I eventually decided that it'd be a fun challenge for me as well as not wanting to break my recent habit of reviewing every book that I read.

Be forewarned, I have watched the BBC version of this story many times for somewhere in the ballpark of 15 years. This means the story as a whole was not new to me, though the particulars were.

I did realize before reading this book that there were bound to be aspects which seemed odd to me, or that I may dislike, that would be considered part of the time period and other such nonsense. Basically, in stating what I did not take pleasure in, I hope not to draw criticism in the form of "Well, that's part of what makes it a classic." or "That's the way stories were told back then and is beyond critique."

I'll start with my minor annoyances, since they were so few and far between as to hold little impact on the whole and should not take much time to convey.

Early on I noticed a penchant for -- certain words either partially or in their entirety. At first I thought Austen was too lazy to type out those words and therefore just expected me to know what went there, but then I thought, "If she was perfectly content writing out this long of a book, I highly doubt she'd lower the quality of the story by being lazy on a few words." So yes, I did some research and found it was a habit of writers of the time to dash words so as not to offend people who may live on those streets, or in those towns, or who were part of those militias, etc.

Though I know understand the reason behind the "dashing", it was still an irritation and I think omitting a word, or part of one, so as not to offend the sensitivities of someone who might feel slighted that an author is casting any sort of undesirable traits to an area a person may be connected with is silly. And I read what is before me so every time I'd come upon one such instance I'd go, "The (blank)shire" or "the something that's in Hertfordshire." I wouldn't make up my own town, or street, or whatever I was supposed to supply.

I winced at every "chuse" and "shew". I get it. It was most likely the way to spell show and choose at the time, but ugh, my mind wanted to slay every usage of the two.

And really, that was all the negative I have to say.

The story itself didn't hold much mystery, as I am very familiar with it. I can't speak on the storyline, the characters, or any other such aspect which I feel best qualified to judge when the story is new to me.

I was most pleased that the tv miniseries was, for the most part, faithful to the novel. I felt some hesitancy in reading this initially, in case it did lessen my enjoyment of a long time favorite movie.

Some conversations were moved, or shorten, or even omitted. There were scenes that didn't exist in the movie. The greatest alteration that I detected was from the point where Lizzy meets Darcy on his property until the end of the book. There was a great deal that'd been altered or added, deleted. Things such as Darcy diving in the lake and appearing half-dressed, Lizzy and her family continuing their tour of the grounds after that meeting, and lots of little things. Georgiana was much more a background character in the sense that I didn't really get a feel for her. In truth the movie did a much better job of highlighting the secondary characters such as Mary, Kitty, Georgiana, Louisa, etc. Not that all secondary characters need such illumination, but I enjoy getting a sense of them.

Despite a fair bit of differences in the last part of the book from what I'm used to, the story was engaging and I maintain that the BBC version did capture the essence of the book.

I particularly found the conversations that I wasn't privy to in the movie to be the most interesting aspect. My favorite part of the story has always been the dialogue. I love the banter that goes on between the characters. The subtle jabs that can be seen, even wrapped though they are in politeness and proper manners. The embarrassment Lizzy must of felt by the actions and speech of her family was so apparent because the sense of the time and what was proper was so thoroughly portrayed throughout the book. I found several little pieces here and there of where Lizzy is ruminating on something that I found particularly delightful because I've been in a position to think something along those lines myself.

I feel like the mortification surrounding Darcy and his actions to her, and hers to him, and the impact her family had, came through much stronger in the novel than in the movie. I enjoyed getting more into Lizzy's head with that.

Jane was much more annoying to me as her insistence on seeing no evil was so much more dwelled upon that I wanted to smack some sense into her.

The father, I always knew, had several faults and had done the family many a disservice by his actions or rather lack of action, but with the book it was much more blatant and I think above all the characters, his was the most changed in my estimation upon conclusion of the story.

Overall, yes, this is a book that you need to slow down and savor to get the full effect of what lies inside. It is a story that focuses on the everyday life of a family and can be slow in terms of plot if you're not stopping to smell the roses. It won't be for everyone, and as a reader who primarily enjoys fantasy, I can understand that, but this is one of those historical pieces that engaged me throughout and never did I find myself skimming or bored. I loved how the ending wrapped up everyone's lives more tightly than the movie did, and I shall now be able to see I've seen both the movie and read the book and enjoyed both. Rather than diminishing my pleasure of the former, the latter has only increased the depth of it. I'll now watch and now what is going on that I do not see.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 31, 2020
CommentsContent: Even though it uses the same old english style of the times that I typically can’t stand, I enjoyed reading this book. It helped even more that I love the movie and could see the scenes clearly in my head as I read, even if the movie took a few liberties and left a lot out.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 23, 2020
CommentsContent: gorgeous edition--came with protective jacket and in perfect condition. Looks even better in person.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 24, 2011
CommentsContent: I recently had a chance to see the full Masterpiece Theater production of Pride and Prejudice (if you have never seen Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy, you haven't lived) and loved it as much as ever.  Now that I have a Kindle and many of the classics are free I couldn't resist.  I recalled that the dialogue in the series was almost verbatim from the book but I hadn't read the book in so many years that I couldn't recall how well the rest matched up.  They are different because the book does a lot of narration that in the film had to be shown by activity, so it gives a different insight into your favorite characters.  I was delighted to find so much in the book not in the series.The book is a perfect delight and it obvious why this treasure by Jane Austin ranks so high in the lists of English literature.  Austin's skill at dialogue, character and plot development are unmatched.  I had intended to just skim the book to pick up the pieces I wanted but I read every word and was delighted with the extra sections in the book not in the series.  I highly recommend it.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 18, 2020
CommentsContent: It's Jane Austin's best. What more can you say.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 6, 2018
CommentsContent: Still hunting for this edition of Pride and Prejudice. Ordered this one thinking ‘this is from Prime surely it will match the descripton.’ It did not. Instead I was sent a $10 copy of the Barnes and Nobles edition. I just want this  edition! Even the new copy isn’t exactly as it says.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 1, 2005
CommentsContent: I bought the set of audiotapes with no particular expectations, and I am pleasantly surprised. Ms Sharon Williams's reading is amazingly smooth, natural, and she depicts the personalities of each character with the intonations of her voice so perfectly that it always sound like there's more than one person reading, even though she doesn't alter her voice. I am particularly amazed by her rendition of Mrs Bennet. I can almost see the woman when I hear the talk!As an American, I am not fond of British accents, and I am happy to hear that Ms Williams read with some British influence, but it is overall pleasant and easy for me to understand. (In contrast, I dislike the accents on the Harry Potter movies.)I highly recommend this product.(If you haven't read Pride and Prejudice yet and is wondering if you should, the answer is yes! The classics are usually a drag to read, but not Pride and Prejudice. It moves fast, it is witty, insightful, and the language is easy to understand. I think it is the best book among the classics.)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 29, 2010
CommentsContent: By far one of Jane Austen's most celebrated novels, Pride and Prejudice exists as a groundbreaking novel that paved the way for entertainment today. Think of Pride and Prejudice as a 19th century daytime soap chock-full of deceit and motive. Without the novel, we would probably live in a world free from "Gossip Girl" and "The Hills". Well, I guess that wouldn't be such a tragedy. But overall, Pride and Prejudice displays Austen's precise use of the English language, coupled with intricate interpersonal relationships that are sure to keep readers amused. Pride and Prejudice centers on the Bennets, a middle class family living in 19th century rural England. The protagonist, Elizabeth Bennet, is witty and attractive while her older sister Jane is shy and sensible. Their younger sisters, Mary, Kitty, and Lydia exist as foils; as they are immature and ridiculous. Also in contrast, Mrs.Bennet is scatter-brained and judgmental, while Mr. Bennet is serious and dislikes any frivolity. The Bennets' world is turned upside down when a wealthy gentleman named Mr.Bingley arrives at his country home in a neighboring town. Accompanying Mr.Bingley are his snobby sisters and his impolite friend Mr.Darcy. It is when the Bennets, particularly Elizabeth and Jane, begin to intermix with their upper class arrivals that the drama is truly set in motion. The characters from both economic classes experience love, heartbreak, deceit, loss, and the side effects of pride and social standing. For those readers who seek an action packed, plot driven novel, Pride and Prejudice is not for you. The novel relies on character development and there are several chapters where the plot remains stagnated. Also, it is difficult at times to decipher some of the text, due to the fact that it is written in antiquated English. Again, this book is not for you if you do not wish to interpret phrases such as "she fancied herself nervous" (page 7) or "a mixture of quick parts" (page 7). Although it is more of a difficult read and is often stagnant, Pride and Prejudice has remained a classic for a reason. The novel's romanticism and elaborate depiction of characters has and will continue to make it a favorite among readers.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 1, 2007
CommentsContent:
I enjoyed this classic totally.  I thought the way Jane Austen developed the characters personalities was incredible.  I have reread it many times.  I am amazed at how much an author can get across without the overuse of sex and violence (that we see way too much of today).  I have also enjoyed her other works Emma and Sense and Sensibility.  I have not read the others.I have found the Pride and Prejudice movie from A&E with Collin Firth to be one of my favorite movies and I think is an excellent addition to have.  The Annotated Pride and Prejudice is very helpful and enjoyable by David Shapard.  The World of Her Novels by Deirdre Le Faye is also very helpful though at times seems a bit heavy.  It gives you a real feel for the era and thus the settings of the book.A word of caution.  When you enjoy something you don't want it to end.  Of the countless spinoffs of the original I totally disliked one and am in the middle of another.  Mr. Darcy takes a wife is unbelievable and totally devoid of character.  Seems there are sex scenes on almost every page in the beginning.  I grew disgusted.  The account of things from Darcy's point of view by Pamela Aidan has been enjoyable.  I am only half way thru the first book, however.

  
The Annotated Pride and PrejudiceJane Austen: The World of Her NovelsMr. Darcy Takes a Wife: Pride and Prejudice ContinuesAn Assembly Such as This: A Novel of Fitzwilliam Darcy, Gentleman (Fitzwilliam Darcy Gentleman)

CommentsTitle: Don't judge a book by it's age
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 5, 2000
CommentsContent: It is a common tragedy that many high-schoolers and even adults do not read old books because they believe the books are not relevant. My words for them: human nature has not changed one bit since Jane Austen crafted her magic. Many people begin their reviews with "Once you get past . . ." but if any element were left out of this book (victorian society, language, high formality) it would diminish the book. Austen has shown through her characters the importance of valuing a person for who they truly are while 1) making fun of prudish victorian standards 2) showing gossip for the destructor it is, and 3) being one of the first writers to promote free thinking women as opposed to silly girls. Pride and Prejudice is called a classic for a reason: it will always remain a literary treasure.
