CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 12, 2000
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice was the book that introduced me to Jane Austen. I find the love story between Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth simply irresistible. Will they get together? That kept me in agony. I have to admit that it was hard  to follow at times, but it still kept me in suspense. It is so obvious that  today's female (and some male) writers emulate Austen's writing, writing  touching romantic comedies. This is definitely one of the books that I'm  proud to keep on my bookshelf.

CommentsTitle: One o the best classic books of all time!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2014
CommentsContent: I love this book!  Mr. Bennet has 5 daughters but no son to inherit his house, lands, furniture, and silver.  Naturally, these girls will all have to find  husbands--no mean feat when there is no dowry and there aren't many eligible bachelors in their neighborhood.  I wouldn't want to  spoil the book by telling you more.  After all, the novelist Nabakov said he would give $10,000 to have back the first time he read Pride and Prejudice.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 19, 2011
CommentsContent: This is a very good copy of the book.  The outside is very pretty and very sturdy (definitely not cheapo cardboard). Also, the paper is high quality.  Looks like an antique book without the antique fragility.Received much sooner than expected too, in two weeks instead of the month Amazon said it would take.

CommentsTitle: Read and listen to audible version at same time

CommentsContent: I've read this at least 6, possibly 10 times. This is possibly the best novel ever written. This time around, I had the good fortune of listening to the Audible version by Carolyn Seymour -- and read it, while she narrated. Without a doubt one of the most enjoyable experiences I have had.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 27, 2020
CommentsContent: Classic nice book

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 25, 2016
CommentsContent: Love this book! But really, how can you not? This cover is beautiful, the pictures online don't do it justice. The second one did not have any issues though, and Amazon gave me no problems about it.

CommentsTitle: I found the flowery expressions used were almost like learning a new language by immersion
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 27, 2014
CommentsContent: Once I got accustomed to the language, the story line was very engaging.  As a 21st century American, I found the flowery expressions used were almost like learning a new language by immersion.  It was very interesting to learn about the culture of that time. Who knew the gentry did so much walking?  Politeness, extravagant flattery and social climbing was unrestrained!  Most judgmental remarks by the characters were refreshingly tempered by an effort to give the person the benefit of the doubt.  All the plot twists made it a page turner.  Independent thinking Elizabeth could certainly qualify as a modern woman.  It was a very good read.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 18, 2018
CommentsContent: This is a difficult read  f old English literature but in the end it's a very good love story of two proud and stubborn persons who mellow with time and become lovers in the end.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 2, 2018

I've always loved the Pride and Prejudice (2005) movie, so I decided that, since books are always better than the movie, I should read the book! Definitely recommend!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 22, 2020
CommentsContent: The book itself is extraordinary and I love it. I have already read it in the past but I wanted a new copy of it. The package came early and it wasn’t damaged at all. Overall i love it

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2002
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is a great classic and should be read by anyone who enjoys Victorian Romance. The beautiful, intelligent, head strong Elizabeth Bennet has finally met her match in the arrogant, proud Mr. Darcy. Their tumultuous romance is extremely humorous and delightful to read.Although Jane Austen was a talented novelist, she was harshly criticized during her day for writing about marriage and the social life of well-bred, 19th century British women as opposed to more serious topics such as the French and American revolutionary wars. I however, believe that Ms. Austen was ahead of her time, exploring the world of gender politics with every witty heroine she created.Pride and Prejudice is a timeless tale that is just as enjoyable today as it was centuries ago.  In fact, You may notice that this story is very influential in modern films and books, most recently in Bridget Jones's Diary. I recommend it highly!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 26, 2006
CommentsContent: What can I say about Pride and Prejudice that hasn't already been said? I read this when I was in junior high and didn't really like it. What was I thinking? It's been my all-time favorite novel for the past ten years or so. Its themes are the basis for hundreds of novels, movies and plays. Just think of how many stories you've read or seen that have the two main characters disliking each other, bickering and finally realizing that they love each other. If you just can't get enough of Pride and Prejudice, I suggest reading Pamela Aidan's series which tells the same story from Darcy's point of view.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 4, 2017
CommentsContent: The old-fashioned English made it very difficult to read. The best scenes were spoiled by replacing dialogue with summary. Yet, this is a classic, immortal story and it's a must read. The authentic peek into life in the 19th Century makes it worth it.

CommentsContent: I shopped around for a good copy of Pride and Prejudice for a long time before coming across this one. I ordered Pride and prejudice and Jane Eyre. CommentsTitle: What a difference two centuries make!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 6, 2012
CommentsContent:
I've read this beautiful novel only three times. A British Prime Minister read it 26. My novel, "The War Less Civil" 

  
THE WAR LESS CIVIL









  
  
    
  , deals with issues Miss Austen would be shocked, and in some cases, horrified by. But never would she fail to understand the unchanging character of the human condition that I wrote about in 19th & 20th century America. Her insights into the human spirit and behavior in the early 1800s, seemingly so simple and commonplace, are as deep as the most profound novelists of any age. If one desires a book offering endless pleasure, one that could be reread once a year for a lifetime, then I strongly urge one to read "Pride and Prejudice."

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2017
CommentsContent: My spouse and I took turns reading the book out loud to each other.  We had both read the book previous to this time and wanted to read again before watching the Masterpiece version.  It was exciting,romantic and very entertaining. It almost makes you wanted to go back in time and relive the events along with the characters.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2021
CommentsContent: I give this a rating of 4 only because the electronic version may have skipped some words. I found various misspellings.  Overall it's a great read. The writing style is very unique. The story line is beautiful.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 22, 2019
CommentsContent: I think there is a problem with the edition I purchased. It repeatedly uses the word e-book, and I can find no such term that would have existed in Jane Austen's time. Further, I believe I saw at least one other modern reference that seemed inexplicable. Having never read the book before, I am concerned that there are other errors as well.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 18, 2017
CommentsContent:
This novel may not ‘take you in’ immediately... persist -- by the fifth or sixth (short) chapter you will have ‘caught on’. Author Jane Austen is illustrating (ridiculing?) the ‘manners’ and mannerisms of the British aristocracy of the era. First published in 1813, the pace and dynamics of the story and its characters are slow by modern measure. I lit into the read without a bit of knowledge of the book beyond its high place in great literature and it can be too easy to judge 19th century literature by misplaced 21st century expectations. Even a wikipedia article’s worth of preparation would have focused the read earlier for me, nonetheless, once oriented to Jane Austen’s objective the reader becomes an interested spectator, often surprised, or amazed, or appalled by the cunning, slyness, and occasionally viciousness of the characters intentions constrained by the language (snarky?) and manners (starched) of the Regency Era.The novel is a ‘must read’ if you are interested in serious literature.______________________Try to find another publication if you read this book on a kindle. A digital scan of hardcopy followed by a slap-dash plunge through Optical Character Reader (OCR) software with little or even NO follow-up editing produces the sloppy text you will have to put up with throughout this poorly done version. 

  
Pride and Prejudice









  
  
    
  On nearly_every_page_you will find this (3 superfluous underscores) followedby an inane line break.Miss Austen would be aghast!  And you can do better, even at the  $0.99 price-point!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 27, 2016
CommentsContent: I would rank this book with four stars, and I highly recommend it to one who enjoys mature novels with comedic aspects within it. It explains of a dynamic character, Elizabeth, and her journeys of choosing a citizen to marry. People who are entertained by satire-impacted stories will enjoy Pride and Prejudice.

Pride and Prejudice is so tight and every time, you just can't wait for his disasterous proposal and the subsequent series of events.  If you have no patience, just see the very fabulous and faithful BBC version starring Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy and Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth Bennett.

CommentsContent: I could not get past the style of very early 19th century writing.  What I could discern, however, was the humor behind the book.  Gave up trying to read it, however.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 20, 2019
CommentsContent: Always a favorite. I read it because my sister mentioned it to me, I have since read three of her other book and feel no less happy with them all.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 12, 2012
CommentsContent: What can I say about this book that hasn't been said before? The story is so well written that it's timeless, one of those few that I will keep and read over and over again. Elizabeth Bennet is smart and sassy, Jane is good and even angelic, Mr Darcy is dashing and brooding. The cast is full of well developed characters who you can't help but embrace. The Bennets, a glass of wine, and a comfy chair. Bliss.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 8, 2013
CommentsContent: This is most certain a timeless masterpiece in which Jane Austen achieved perfection. Pride and Prejudice is a reading bliss with its unique and beloved plot. The unsuspected decisions and changes of plot keep you on your toes wishing for more. The description and personalities of the characters is extraordinary and you feel yourself intrigued within the story, and falling in love with Mr. Darcy alongside Elizabeth. The end is perfect in every way possible, but you can't help yourself wishing for it not to end though. Her vocabulary and formality may at times be more difficult but it makes it all the more interesting. It's a timeless classic which I love and adore, and never tire of no matter how many times I read it! ~A.C.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 4, 2016
CommentsContent: One of my all time favotire books.  I've read it so many times and continue to go back.  I love the character development and the storyline.  Time period peices will always be my favorite as getting lost in the settings, dress, and mind set of the characters of the time is part of the enjoyment.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 9, 2018
CommentsContent: I love Pride and Prejudice, the plot gets 5 stars. However I'm thoroughly unimpressed with the delivery of the book. The book arrived with several imperfections on the cover. I momentarily thought I had ordered a used book because of it. The inside of the book appears to be intact, but the cover was very disappointing.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 20, 2020
CommentsContent: I have never been into literature, but this book has completely changed my mind. I could not put it down! I recommend this book to anyone who loves romance! I can only hope that I find another book just as good now that I’ve finished this one!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 17, 2014
CommentsContent: I avoided this book like the plague. All my life I have not heard the truth about this book. I did NOT know this was a classic. The title always suggested to me this was a mid 20th century love story. UGHGH! 20th century love stories are based on sex and not true affection and I'm not interested in those stories. Not one person ever told me otherwise. I would see the title in tv stories or in articles, but nothing to lead me to believe this was a classic. Because my mind was convinced this was a 20th century book I paid no attention to the book and I don't think I related Jane Austen to this book. Recently a coworker and I talked about how we have these "special weekends" with movies and her special weekend is with the PBS version of Pride and Prejudice. This was the first time I learned this was an old world love story from the 19th century. Well that was all I needed, I devoured this book in 3 days! LOL I cannot tell you how much I enjoyed this story and can't wait to read Jane Austen other books.

CommentsTitle: I ordered this book as I am an avid Jane ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 17, 2017
CommentsContent: I ordered this book as I am an avid Jane Austen fan and wanted to see how her story was presented by a different person.  It has been quite a few months since I read the book so I cannot remember how it was narrated.  It was a satisfying read.

CommentsContent: it was  a little hard to follow because of how the book is written, high english and some sarcasm was lost to me and other parts meant to be humorous because of the style of writing but when watching the mini series on HULU I understood. anyways loved the book and its relatable 100+ years later

CommentsTitle: Lizzy is a smart, thoughtful girl but she have given her judgments ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 22, 2016
CommentsContent: This story was written more than about two hundred years ago, yet the values it brings are very true and may last forever. One should never judged others without walking their shoes or at least knowing something about them. Lizzy is a smart, thoughtful girl but she have given her judgments too quick. Mr Darcy, well I suspect he is just a highborn guy, possesses good qualities but just not as sociable and vocal. The journey that the two main characters go to explore themselves and their other half is written in a beautiful way and full of surprises. Reading the story then watching the movie is such a great experience for me.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 7, 2007
CommentsContent: This classic is wonderful, but there were too many grammatical errors.  This is apart from the dialect and writing style of Jane Austen.  There were letters, words, and sometimes parts of words that were missing.  In some cases parts of words were replaced with '---'.  This is irritating, but doesn't detract from the context of the story.  Just know to expect it if you purchase this version of the book.  It would be a smoother read if the errors were corrected.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 17, 2020

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States November 16, 2014
CommentsContent: This was my first time to read this classic. By the end I was in love with the book like so many in my book club. It was hard at times to read but I hung in there and made it through. In the end I was very glad to have read it and enjoyed it immensely. I would recommend this book to anyone who missed reading it in English class,  like I did.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 20, 2017
CommentsContent: A very engaging love story, so true to its title! The virtue of pride and the vices of prejudice, vanity are depicted perfectly in the story. The style of writing, however is very complex and reflects the 19th century time it is based on. Sentences are long with multiple clauses, verbs are followed with negation (contrary to the current practice where negation precedes verbs) which may escape attention and twist the meaning of the whole sentence. Hence reading this book is a good way to practice focusing on the task at hand and increase concentration!

CommentsTitle: Jane Austen is a great writer. Even though her books were written over ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 18, 2015
CommentsContent: Jane Austen is a great writer .Even though her books were written over 100 yrs. ago ,she knew people and they haven't changed that much . Pride and prejudice is my favorite of her books . Her wit and humor is great. It is also a great way to find out about history and how people lived in the 1700s .

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States September 1, 2019
CommentsContent: Love the book, and can’t resist such a lovely copy!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 3, 2014
CommentsContent: This classic novel is as relevant today as it was when it was written many years ago.  There's a lot of silliness in the chatter of the young ladies but not nearly so much as in the movie version.  You will be taken back into a long-ago era in which all mothers of teenaged girls fretted over how many pounds a year the potential suitors of their daughters could expect to live on.  It reminds us that casual conversations overheard can lead to great misunderstandings and potential heartbreak. The language is refreshing, for no one talks this way today.

CommentsTitle: A classic to be read by all

CommentsContent: So refreshing to read a classic written more than a century ago. Civility the core of being.A great read to revisit after years of absence.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 19, 2015
CommentsContent: To my English teachers and friends who have raved that I should read this. Check. Done!  My grade for this book is a C- and that was with the help of Carolyn Seymour, the narrator. Glad I read it so I could say I did, but I was not wowed like others.I couldn't have gotten into it as a tree book, even on Kindle with text-to-speech I couldn't get there. Though  the reader did add a lot to the experience, in the beginning, I'm afraid there was no help.The first half of the book seemed centered around bickering, gossip, and how women of the time could climb the status ladder. Ms. Seymour's varied voices just made that part even more irritating. I felt sorry for the reader as there was no way to vary the voices enough within that family of females. Lizzy and Jane's father was probably easy to do. And the voice of Darcy felt unique. But other than those voices, I couldn't tell whose voice belonged to whom.As for the book itself, I felt that the real book started about 3/4 in. That's where it all started to get exciting. I suddenly cared for a few people. It may be that the passive voice that seems to live in most so-called classics that made this less than wonderful. I plan to watch a couple versions of the movie next. Then there are possible book two by more recent authors. And... I'm not done with Jane Austen. I do plan to read them all, somehow. After all, these follow my main goal of reading books by females with strong female leads.

CommentsTitle: Pride and Prejudice is one of my favorite books and I’ve read it many times
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 24, 2016
CommentsContent: Pride and Prejudice is one of my favorite books and I’ve read it many times.  It’s a book that my best friend hates and we often talk about whether it’s romantic clap trap (my friends opinion) or a book that was the leading edge of feminism in its day (my opinion).  I think people forget that Jane Austen wrote this as a satire; she is making fun of the social atmosphere of the day.The opening of Pride and Prejudice reads “It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.”  This set the tone for the story and the thinking of the day.  Women had a lot fewer options and marring well was a big deal still and considered a good life decision.  When the original manuscript was written in the late 18th century a women’s options we few and a women that could read and write was still look upon unfavorably by many; they were referred to as bluestockings and Jane Austen herself had to publish under a pen name because she was a woman.  Even though there is a romance that goes through some interesting twists in this book and that is what many people think this book is about its ultimately about women, their expected lot in life and Austen making fun of it.  It was books like Pride and Prejudice that was the foundation for women standing up for themselves and women’s rights.  Pride and Prejudice is not only one of my favorite books because Darcy had to work for it and learn from his mistakes but also because it’s a great reminder of how far women have come.Yes I think the romance that happens is sweet but it is Elizabeth that turned down an extremely rich guy, something that would have been shocking for a young lady to do, that I really love.  Elizabeth who was willing to follow her own mind and be herself, something that many women would not have braved in that day, that really draws me in.  Jane Austen used her books to show women are equals and I thank her for writing that reminder for future generations.

CommentsTitle: For the dudes on the fence about this one
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 12, 2014
CommentsContent: Almost every woman I've known loved to watch at least one of the many adaptations, especially the one with Knightley, and then they go on to tell me that there are certain classics one simply must read, recently one actually threw the book at me, so at long last I got around to it, thinking there was simply no way I could enjoy such a chick flick. Wrong! Austen is delightful (just had to use that word, with an English accent of course) and funny in her witty sort of way. By modern standards, the characterization leaves much to be desired, blah blah blah, if you're looking for straight story without any of the frills, look no further. Her writing style was way before her time, especially with handling the inner thoughts of her characters. And yes, guys, although this is no doubt a chick flick (common ladies, the most dangerous thing to happen was someone running away), it does have its moments, and the most kickass character was a dude: their dad was a trip. Anyone who is serious about writing should at some point pick up this book. Austen knew exactly what she was doing and you just might learn a thing or two.

I first read it at school around 70 years ago, and re-read it again last year. I was honestly surprised at how much I enjoyed it.

CommentsTitle: Well crafted, some humor,,, will expand your vocabulary
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 26, 2016
CommentsContent: Pretty good book, sort of a nineteenth century chick-flick I think you'd say. It'll take you a little while to pick up on some of he language usage of the era, but you'll have that within a chapter or so.  To me the most challenging part was the complexity of the sentences at times, almost seems like they're having a competition to see who can come up with the longest, multi-part sentences that still make sense.  You get used to that after a while too, but at first I found myself going back to the beginning of a sentence and starting over as i was losing track of the commas and what goes with what.  They were all perfectly written, of course, just takes some focus.Character development was alright, though as I said, a little predictable, at least for the main characters.  I think I enjoyed some of the supporting characters more, a little more quirky and downright funny at times.  Also a good glimpse into the mores of the times (Victorian times I think) and obviously they put more emphasis on certain standards of behavior than is the case today (that I know of anyway)

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 19, 2014
CommentsContent: I try to look at everything in an unbiased manner, even school assignments. Jane Austen has a way with words to make even the most humorous event seem boring and dull. She weaves words in such a way that makes me believe that every character is a robot with a pre-set plan. Even Mr. Collins who could be an exceedingly embarrasing and funny character just comes off as another tired asset to a book only hoping to increase its word count. Just because it is old doesn't mean it's a "classic". I have read many of Charles Dickens' books and found them delightfully entertaining, so while the writing style may have been different back then, that's no excuse for a book to be exceedingly dusty and dull. The only character that saved this book from getting one star was Elizabeth's father, who constantly torments her mother any chance he gets.

CommentsContent: As an avid reader, an English major, and a teacher, I somehow missed this novel. I couldn't put it down for two days! CommentsTitle: This reproduction is lacking in quality.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 10, 2013
CommentsContent: Note: I am reviewing this particular edition, not the story.Let me start off by saying that the original Hugh Thomson illustrations are beautiful, especially the peacock cover. However, this paperback reproduction is amateurishly laid out. The images (scans of a copy of the original hardcover from 1894) are generally low-quality. Most are grayish and slightly soft, not black and crisp-lined like ink drawings should be. At least one is horrendously pixellated (page 291, which is unfortunately and probably intentionally not in the 'Look Inside' preview). The cover is also very slightly fuzzy, although it isn't noticeable from a distance. It's lightly embossed like the hardcover, but you are not likely to notice unless you turn the glossy cover to the light. The edge of the front cover's image extends onto about a fourth of the spine, which reveals either messy laziness or the work of someone unfamiliar with laying out book covers.The text is 1.5x or 2x spaced, and there is a little room in the margins to write, which makes it a decent choice if you need to annotate it for class or something of that nature. The italics, oddly, seem to have been replaced with all caps. I can't say whether this is the way it was in the hardback or not, but it seems a little weird.Overall, I'm disappointed in the quality. I bought this as a gift, and I'm actually debating on whether to give it or not. At the price it's at right now, (about $19) I'd say skip it. It's definitely not worth that. Maybe $10. Maybe.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 25, 2014

CommentsTitle: Pride and Prejudice - best book ever!!

Jane Austen is a wonderful writer... Lizzy is an amazing character to follow and fall in love with. Mr. Darcy... so dark and mysterious and stern. I love reading about the social and societal customs and ideals... it's so very interesting, so different from life today. No matter what mood I'm in, I can flip to Pride and Prejudice and feel warm, cozy, and content within minutes. Favorite book of all time. Weeeell.. Pride and Prejudice is in direct competition with Harry Potter.. for the spot of 'favorite book of all time.' But it's definitely right up there. You can't go wrong - read this book!!

CommentsTitle: If you only read two things...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 31, 2007
CommentsContent: I've been a fan of Miss Austen from day one; and I firmly believe that she has a bright future ahead of her as a novelist.Don't buy all the "critics" commentary and praise regarding "Persuasion" and some of her other works as being superior to P&P. That's pure contrary-ism at its worst.If you only read two of her books, then read this one twice. And then resolve to read more than two and check out her other novels, because they are great as well.The A&E miniseries for P&P is outstanding and comes highly recommended.No, I don't own stock in A&E; but I am over the age of 13... in a few weeks.

But all of these things have been said or done in the thousands of reviews written about this novel over the course of the last 202 years, which just goes to show that all of the things about this novel can be summed up in one word: Timeless.

CommentsTitle: The expectation was high as it has been a long standing favorite in the literary world
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 4, 2018
CommentsContent: This is the first time in my reading life that I have ever picked up or even attempted to read a classic such as Pride and Prejudice. The expectation was high as it has been a long standing favorite in the literary world. I knew going in that I would struggle with comprehending the use of language, but it didn't deter me from reading it.I will say this, I did enjoy this novel, but found at times I just simply lost interest. My lack of interest didn't stem from the use of language, but more so to to with the fact that, that some scenes I simply found unnecessary. There were time that I found it over-written (if that makes sense) and I simply got bored.I will say I did enjoy Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy's story. I loved watching as their story unfold, from a love that was never going to happen, to a love that simply flourished.I also liked Jane and Mr. Bingley's story.Overall I enjoyed this read, but not sure how in this day and age it should fit into a school curriculum. I could almost conclude that while it's a long standing classic, more up to date reads should be implemented to keep young adults interested in reading.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 22, 2017
CommentsContent: I saw the movie 1st, which is not my normal way. But I loved the movie so much, I figured I'd love the book. I do love it. I do have to admit that they way ppl spoke back in that day almost reminds me of Stephen King's books The Dark tower series when they talked about the "high speech". It takes a bit of getting used to. But the more I read, the better I loved. I normally am only into horror books so my love of this one is so wonderful to me.  Mr. Darcy is an "upper crust" rich man and Miss Lizzy is full of high spirits and she can't keep her mouth shut.  It didn't take long for her to hate Mr. Darcy.  Mr. Darcy of course fell in love with her. And so the love story goes.  It has no sex in it, no horror, no wars, and yet sure has enough to keep me coming about to this story every night.  Give it a try.

There were new paragraphs where no paragraphs should be (...Mr. (praragraph inserted) Darcy...),  this was only a minor distraction, but it did become a bit annoying, and it is an easy problem to fix. CommentsTitle: don't get me wrong because I really enjoyed the book
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 9, 2015
CommentsContent: I finally read this! This book has been on my mental to read list since I was a teenager. I have heard so much about it and the main characters, Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennett. The romance, Mr. Darcy, and blah, blah, blah. Now, don't get me wrong because I really enjoyed the book. I just think that a lot of people probably talk about it when they have not really read it. For one thing Mr. Darcy hardly says a word in the first half of the book and I found myself wondering...what romance were these people talking about and what is so great with Mr. Darcy when he barely talks. The second half of the book picks up and is way more entertaining. Mr. Darcy becomes more prevalent and endearing. Once finishing the book I now see that the first half was important to getting into the mind set of our feisty Ms. Bennett. This is definitely one lady I would not want to get into an argument with!

I can almost quote dialogue but still am totally absorbed by the plot/s each time. The selection of language used throughout the book is superb and sometimes makes me think I wish we still spoke that way. Shame so much swearing and slang has entered our english language, that maybe high school students should read it to learn a new selection of words, or to have it reinforced that there are thousands of delicious words out there that far create more meaning than slang! A classic and always will be.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2013
CommentsContent: I was worried when I first started reading the book because my friend told me that it was slow paced. the courtship between two people was different back then than it is today so you have to be prepared for it. other than that small detail I completely loved the book. Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth are a great couple. I enjoyed it so much I read it again. if you are the kind of person to wonder how dating or romance happened then read this book; you will absolutely love the chemistry between the two.
